column2: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 20 -- Improvised weapons and two holes several feet deep were discovered today during a search by 1,000 British troops and Northern Ireland policemen at the Long Kesh internment camp about 12 miles south of here.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The Senate Finance Committee agreed today to bring out welfare reform legislation this year, but minus the annual guaranteed income that President Nixon is seeking.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 20 -- Mrs. Margaret McCann, a widowed mother of three, sits each morning in a crowded launderette in the bleak Divis Flats, a Roman Catholic housing project.

BRUSSELS -- The international monetary crisis which was partly settled in Washington last month has seriously affected the European Economic Community. Various speculative conclusions can be drawn from the events leading to the crisis concerning the future of European monetary integration.
DUBLIN -- Who knows what the effect will be on the traditional cuisine of Japan, but the Irish dairy industry is delighted that the Japanese seem to be acquiring a taste for Irish cheddar.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

CINCINNATI, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Elvin Hayes, Stu Lantz and Calvin Murphy combined for 75 points tonight as the Houston Rockets broke a Cincinnati foar-game winning streak with a 104-87 victory over the Royals in the National Basketball Association.

The new First Lady of the United Nations has begun her unofficial and nonsalaried job with what might seem like two strikes against her: She can't stand the interminable round of diplomatic cocktail parties, and she's no fan of Viennese pastries, either.
Italian artist Giorgio de Chirico has often been given to paradox and contradiction in his work and his life.

President Nixon's tougher stance on expropriation of American property abroad is probably designed as much to appease Congress as to warn foreign governments. It represents no major change of policy; but Mr. Nixon's clear threat to withhold new economic aid and to oppose loans by international agencies to countries that expropriate without compensation may head off fresh attempts by Congress to tighten existing laws in this area.

ATHENS -- The money has been pouring in from abroad and at home into Greece's shipyards, oil refineries and tourist hotels at such an accelerating rate that in this final year of the muchtrumpeted "five-year plan," the country's ruling generals may even approach their flashy projections of 1968.

Tonight's "Prospective Encounter" by the New York Philharmonic has been transferred from Martinson Hall in the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater to the New School Auditorium, 66 West 12th Street.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 20 -- More than 700 members of the Croatian region"s Communist party have resigned, been expelled or relieved of their duties in the last month in a continuing purge of nationalists.

STERLING, Colo., Jan. 20 -- A young man saying he had a bomb hijacked a jetliner today, obtained two parachutes and a $50,000 ransom, bailed out over Colorado and was then captured near his parachute, silent, mud-splattered and injured.

Following the visit of Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans to the Soviet Union, many Americans are taking a new look at East-West trade. Americans are not the only ones contemplating new approaches.
The credit markets continued to slump yesterday, affected chiefly by Treasury Secretary Connally's acknowledging that the Federal budget deficit for fiscal 1972 would be about $40-billion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- A provisional study group started an effort today to revive a national Spanish-speaking political action coalition. The group announced plans for a national convention in Washington on April 29 and 30.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -The Department of the Interior, unable to meet a deadline, called off today a sale of oil and gas leases on more than 300,000 acres in the Gulf of Mexico off eastern Louisiana.
JERUSALEM -- In 1971 the guns along Israel's frontiers were silent -- but economic pressures were there to take the place of the military pressure at the top of the nation's worry list.

TUCSON, Jan. 20 -- Charles Owens, an unusual golfer with an unusual style, shared the lead today in the $150,000 Dean Martin-Tucson open golf tourney with George Archer at 65. Owens, a black professional, is a former United States Army paratrooper.
America, you may not believe this, but a lot of Australians don't like you.
It may be a little early in the year for you New Yorkarea folks to be thinking about swimming pools, but it's just right for Stanley E. Lebow.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's address on the State of the Union to a joint session of Congress yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- This cosmopolitan capital overlooking the Mediterranean is the center of Middle East action. It is the playground of Persian Gulf sheiks and a listening post for international diplomats, foreign correspondents and master spies.
PARIS -- The managers of the French economy had some solid reasons for satisfaction last year. They also had reasons for uncertainty in 1972.
Dr. Daniel Ellsberg scoffed last night at the President's promise of a generation of peace, saying, "He's winding down the war like he's winding down my indictment"

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Prospects for House approval of the Gateway national recreation area brightened considerably today when Donald E. Elliott, chairman of the New York City Planning Commission, assured key Representatives that the Federal Government would not have to finance major costs to transport people to the park areas.

AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Jan. 20 (UPI) -- A student court found 16 Air Force Academy cadets guilty of cheating and failing to report violations of the academy's strict honor code today. The cadets resigned, Lieut. Gen. Albert P. Clark, the academy's superintendent, reported tonight at a news conference.

The New Lafayette Theater on Seventh Avenue at 137th Street is one of New York's most admirable cultural enterprises. It is a true community theater, in touch with its audience, and nurturing actors, playwrights and technicians in surroundings that are flexible and stimulating to the theatrical imagination.
In tournament play the "right" bid may depend upon the quality of the field.
BRUSSELS -- The Belgians faced 1972 with the prospect of sharply increased prices and taxes.

More than 1,000 trade fairs and specialized exhibitions have been scheduled during 1972 in more than 60 countries, according to a compilation by the United States Department of Commerce. The following listing is a sampling of the compilation.
CHICAGO, Jan. 20 -- A violent internal struggle, perhaps the start of a push for change and new leadership, is under way among the nation's Black Muslims.

History without tears and without fears is Robert Bolt's stock-in-trade "Vivat! Vivat Regina!," which arrived with proper pomp and circumstance at the Broadhurst Theater last night is a new and persuasive theatricalization of Elizabeth Tudor and Mary Stuart.

Gifford Pinchot Jr.'s recent letter concurring with The Times' opposition to the Tocks Island Reservoir project conveniently exaggerates its negative aspects and obscures the vast benefits to the region's millions of people.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- The local pair of Bill Shettle, an amateur, and Jimmy Dunn, a professional, advanced to the semifinal round of the United States Open court tennis doubles championship today by defeating the Boston team of Philip Stockton, an amateur, and Joe Crane, a professional, by 8-0, 8-4, at the Racquet Club.

WESTERN EUROPE, too, is being burned by the Rising Sun. The industrial competition from Japan, and, to a lesser extent, other Asian countries, which has been producing anguished laments in the United States, is now beginning to give pain to European countries in their own markets.
" I don't think you'll find someone in these days buying complete plants in the United States and paying for them in cash."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Personal income of all Americans jumped by $8.9-billion in December, the first full month following the wage-price freeze, the Government said today.
The chairman of the General Electric Company said yesterday that he was "impatient" with the present economy.
State Supreme Court Justice Michael Kern meted out long prison terms yesterday for murders committed in Brooklyn in 1970 by three 23-year-old men.

W. R. Grace Co. announced yesterday the election of Robert M. Coquillette and Carl N. Graf as executive vice presidents. Both were vice presidents. Mr. Coyuillette will be responsible for corporate administration reporting to the president and Mr. Graf becomes deputy group executive of the company's chemical group. Both men are directors.
CARTERET, N. J., Jan. 20 -Forty-two thousand gallons of oil spilled into the Arthur Kill near here early today after a 669-foot oceangoing tanker, the Atlantic Prestige, hit a submerged object.

Detectives in Queens arrested a 27-year-old man with a history of mental illness yesterday in connection with the murder of his mother, who was found decapitated in her Flushing apartment earlier in the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Congressional Democrats plan to answer President Nixon's State of the Union Address with a live televised phone-in program tomorrow. Five House members and four Senators will serve on the panel.
The following interview with the French anthropologist Claude LeviStrauss is excerpted from Diacritics, a Cornell University quarterly.

LANSING, Mich., Jan. 19 -Michigan will cast 132 votes at the Democratic National Convention in Miami Beach next July. It will count for something. But to see the way it has been treated the last few months by the Presidential hopefuls, you would think it was the Canal Zone (three votes).
Policemen played both sides in a cops and robbers game in the Bayside section of Queens yesterday. And since it was a simulated bank holdup, the cops won.

Higher labor costs, the sluggish condition of the general economy and such adverse factors in the aluminum industry as excess productive capacity, brought a decline in the 1971 earnings of the leader, the Aluminum Company of America, and the runner-up, the Reynolds Metals Company, from those of the previous year.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Secretary General Kurt Waldheim appealed to member nations today for "an advance of up to $20-million" before the end of March.

Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Tauber of Chevy Chase, Md., celebrated their 11th wedding anniversary by sending a contribution of $11 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. And John Carrara, an evangelist of Sparta, N.J., wrote: "Today is my birthday and I am making a gift of $25 to the Neediest Cases Fund."

Declaring that policemen had "over-responded," the commander of the 24th Precinct on the Upper West Side yesterday rescinded his controversial order setting minimum quotas for the issuance of summonses.

VIENNA -- It looks as if Austria's dream of the 100 million and one nights will come true, and that would mean $1.5-billion in cash, for the nights mentioned are the number tourists are expected to spend in Austria this year.
A White House aide warned here yesterday that legislation before Congress could "gravely" affect the global competitive position of the United States.

Like the sun moving in a reverse direction, the 62d National Boat Show opens at 10 A.M. tomorrow on the heels of a record-breaking performance set by the San Francisco Boat Show, the first one in the country this year.

The McGraw-Hill Book Company and Life magazine decided yesterday to defer publication of a purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes pending an investigation of a disputed Swiss bank account alleged to be that of the eccentric billionaire.

Taxpayers of the world, unite! Or, at least, take heart from the recent -- and successful -- taxpayers' revolt against "Decree No. 1943" in Lebanon. The decree raised customs duties on 350 imported items that the Government called luxuries.
Manhattan Community Planning Board 1, which covers lower Manhattan, criticized the city's master plan yesterday as a whole and as it applied to its area.

BERLIN -- In 1971 the new East German Government of Erich Honecker began to cast off its cloak of consumer-product drabness and recognize that stylish apparel, color TV's and stereo systems are not necessarily contradictory to the ideologies of this Communist country.
Tape-recorded testimony on the cigarette-smuggling operations of one man -- called "Mr. X" -- revealed yesterday how he reportedly cheated the state and city of $844,775 in tax revenues.
Dr. Steven Muller, a 44year-old political scientist, was elected yesterday the 10th president of Johns Hopkins University.

The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that it had "no further proposals" after the reported rejection of its last offer by officials of the Communications Workers of America, which represents the 35,000 telephone craftsmen who have been on strike for more than six months.
Stock prices fell sharply in the final hour of trading yesterday to more than wipe out earlier modest gains.
RISING prices, higher wages, unemployment and fear of recession -- these labor problems, not unfamiliar to the United States, were shared to some degree by most of Western Europe in 1971.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -Oil-producing countries in the Middle East reaped record revenues last year with the rise in oil production and prices and are expected to do even better in 1972, barring any major confrontation.
Two lawmakers yesterday proposed a city "health tax" on "pernicious substances" -cigarettes, gasoline, liquor, beer and electric power -- to help support the 18 municipal hospitals.
The city commission investigating state-city relationships got a head start on its state counterpart yesterday by holding a hearing on government reorganization.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 20 -- Concern about the unusually powerful and early Communist offensive in Laos has grown so intense that the United States Government has lifted much of the secrecy it maintained over its efforts here and is saying that, far from doing too much, the Americans are doing too little and the Administration may ask for more money.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Administration sources said tonight that Kenneth Bush, United States Ambassador to West Germany, had been selected for the No. 2 job at the Pentagon.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie assailed President Nixon's State of the Union Address today as "empty" of substance and devoid of hope for the troubled American cities.

ROME -- Nearly everybody here seems to be talking about foul air, dirty water, adulterated food, forest fires or the massacre of birds and animals by throngs of weekend hunters, but only the lower echelons of the Italian judiciary are doing anything about it.

TRENTON, Jan. 20 -- The New Jersey court order striking down the state's system of financing public school education as unconstitutional was described today as the most important legal victory thus far in the nation in the campaign to achieve education equality for the urban poor.
ROME -- The Italian economy is going through a bitterly cold winter, variously described as a deep recession, a structural crisis, or a climate of widespread pessimism.

The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra's concert in Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was to have been conducted by its music director, William Steinberg. The scheduled program included Elgar's "Fal-staff" and the first act of Wagner's "Die Walktire," with Marilyn Horne as Sieglinde, William Cochran as Siegmund and Ara Berberian as Hunding.
ALBANY, Jan. 20 -- A total of 505,000 residents of New York State were without jobs in December, the State Department of Labor reported today.

In about two weeks some of the most beautiful photographs ever shot and some of the most carefully chosen words ever graven on costly dull-finish paper in elegant type will begin to find their way into the nation's mailboxes.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Jan. 20 -- Even though they hit on a torrid 58 per cent of their floor shots, the New York Nets were forced to break away from a tie in the final two minutes tonight to post a 124-122 American Basketball Association victory over the Carolina Cougars before a crowd of 4,289 at Island Garden.

CAIRO, Jan. 20 -- Egypt's new Premier, Dr. Aziz Sidky, and his war-economy Cabinet accelerated work today on an austerity and mobilization program as students continued meetings to demand a militant and unequivocal line of action.

Using heavy interest charges as their tool and court congestion as their excuse, New Jersey's courts are about to embark upon a controversial program aimed at goading insurance companies into quick out-of-court settlements of the thousands of accident suits filed there each year.

" He has a terrible toothache. Dizziness is his medium." He is perhaps 7 years old, drunk, and adrift on the Bowery. He is played by a remarkable young actor named Jonathan Leeds. And he is the subject, probably the object, and maybe even the hero of "For Example," a new film by the conceptual artist Arakawa, with narration by his wife, the writer Madeline Gins.

Governor Rockefeller's proposal that the State University take over the City University, with the latter dropping its 125-year-old free-tuition policy, revives an issue that has long separated city officials from the Governor and many upstate legislators.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Bill Lesuk slammed in a 12-foot goal in the third period as the Philadelphia Flyers defeated Chicago, 3-2, tonight for their fourth National Hockey League triumph over the Black Hawks in 4 1/2 years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has encountered fierce criticism from members of Congress on its plans for restructuring the stock markets. As a result, it is reconsidering major sections of its report on the matter and may be unable to get the report out next week, as originally planned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, asked the Justice Department today to file suit against the Reserve Mining Company to force the company to stop polluting Lake Superior.
LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Cliff Richey and Clark Graebner advanced to the semifinals of the Rothman's international tennis tournament with victories today.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market declined for the second consecutive session in active trading yesterday.
An apparent malfunction in the computer locking devices yesterday allowed hundreds of Offtrack Betting Corporation customers at 34 OTB shops to wager on Bowie races that had already been run.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20 -- Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist and civil-rights advocate, has petitioned the Kremlin for the release of a 29-year-old dissident, Vladimir K. Bukovsky, on the ground that his recent trial had not been public and that the defense had been given no opportunity to call its witnesses.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Nixon appealed to an election-year Congress today to set aside partisanship in the interests of "high statesmanship" and the swift enactment of programs "which deal with the urgent priorities for the nation."

A member of the New York Stock Exchange made a personal but futile appeal yesterday to the exchange's governing board to permit stock specialists to compete with each other on the exchange's trading floor.

PARIS, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -The United States today presented to the Hanoi delegation at the Vietnam peace talks a list of 14 American pilots shot down over North Vietnam and asked why they were not on the North Vietnamese list of United States prisoners of war.
There is no question that foreign stock exchanges re-acted negatively to President Nixon's new economic policy last summer.

Mayor Lindsay signed into law yesterday a bill that will permit uniformed firemen to engage in political activities. Fire fighters wilt be permitted now to join political clubs, but are bound by the same restrictions that cover other municipal employes.

PARIS -- Speeding from Zurich to Paris the other day in the bar car of the Arbalete, a California professor enjoying his sabbatical on a Eurailpass confided to a fellow American, "You know, when it comes to railroad travel, we are an underdeveloped country."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 20 -- The proposed settlement of Rhodesia's rebellion against Britain is coming under growing pressure caused by unexpectedly strong black opposition to the terms of the agreement, by mob violence and by tensions between the white Rhodesian Government and a British fact-finding-team.

The United States has a "fighting chance" of achieving a trade balance this year, Harold B. Scott, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for domestic and international business, said yesterday. He was making this statement, he said, despite the estimated $2-billion deficit in 1971.

TIGNES, France, San. 20 -Jean Brechu, the young owner of the Ski d'Or, one of the many neat, new hotels in this high Alpine resort, started to search tonight for his contrary-minded but adored St. Bernard named Schuls.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Senior United States officials said today that Secretary of State William P. Rogers was planning to cut the State Department's intelligence bureau by about a third.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark -- Balance-of-payments problems, a low level of capital investment, rising unemployment, falling profits, inflation -- these are some of the problems that have been afflicting Sweden, Denmark, Norway and Finland.

ANKARA -- Last year was good for sunflowers, tourists and wheat in Turkey, but it also brought a bumper crop of economic problems, especially for the country's opium farmers, who planted what is supposed to be their final crop at the end of the year.
Prices of soybean and grain futures rose on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, with soybeans advancing 2 3/8 cents a bushel.
The mutual fund industry's net sales position narrowed further last month to $42.7-million, according to Investment Company Institute data published yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -Money, or talk of it, permeated much of the political debate today along the campaign trails of the major aspirants for Presidential nominations.

Christopher Isherwood is lucky. At 68 he is able to perform an act of piety, make a gesture of reconciliation to his parents he would not have been able to make when they were alive and he was younger. By delving into the diaries of his mother (kept over a period of 70 years)and the letters of his father, he has been able to relive his own life and re-create theirs.

HAMBURG, Germany -- Among the many formulas for survival tried by the magazines of Europe, those in West Germany seem to be the surest; the competition from television is so limited that the advertisers have no place else to go.

Otto Klemperer, the 87-year-old German-born conductor, will retire from the concert platform. "There will be no fuss and no farewell concert," said a spokesman for the New Philharmonia Orchestra of London. "This is as Dr. Klemperer wanted it."

The lives lost at Willowbrook State School will not have been wholly wasted if they shock New York State into far-reaching and long-overdue changes in its system of care for the severely mentally retarded and mentally ill. More positions and funds, though absolutely essential, are not the fundamental solution.

After less than six months in the auto insurance business, the Prudential Insurance Company decided yesterday to terminate a multimillion-dollar contract with the Kemper Insurance Group and to expand on its own.
BONN -- One peculiar aspect of most expert forecasts concerning the West German economy for 1972 is that they sound exactly like the predictions made one year ago for 1971: they add up to recession.

Sears, Roebuck Company announced yesterday that it plans to market this year complete videotape television systems for home use. The company demonstrated a complete system -- 25-inch color cartridge reecording-playback attachment and black-and-white camera with a 100-foot cable -- in the Hotel Pierre.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20 -- "I've never seen anything like it," said Emile Francis, erstwhile goalie, now coach and general manager of the New York Rangers.

OTTAWA, Jan. 20 -- With 53 major airports virtually deserted and 14,000 airline employes laid off, the effects of the four-day-old strike by air traffic controllers spread today to hotels, travel agencies and taxicabs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- President Nixon's State of the Union address is a reminder that most men can easily agree when they concentrate on the objectives and goals of life. Republican and Democrat, Socialist and Communist, Christian, Jew, Moslem and Hindu, all unite in their yearnings for peace, security, equality, and mutual respect in a unified society.

President Nixon experimented yesterday in presenting two messages to Congress on the State of the Union, one a long, detailed written message and the other a comparatively brief, highly generalized talk. It was not a happy experiment.

It is a world with a seemingly endless fascination for some 50 million viewers who together make up a market of more than $300-million annually for which the three major networks battle tirelessly.

Those who love Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande" remained after the Wednesday-night curtain at the Metropolitan Opera to venerate cast, conductor and the other participants in the new production. SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 20 (AP) -- Ten thousand or more South Vietnamese troops have reportedly begun a sweep 45 miles northwest of Saigon to disrupt any enemy plans for an offensive near the capital.

SAIGON, Jan. 20 (UPI) -Five American servicemen were killed in the Indochina war last week, the same number as the week before, United States spokesmen said today.

Armed with a no-knock search warrant and a pair of sledgehammers, Nassau County rackets detectives battered down the door of a luxury apartment in Great Neck Plaza, L.I., last night and seized two men and detailed records of an alleged $75-million-a-year book-making operation.

GENEVA -- It is not quite true that the Swiss are making more money but enjoying it less. They did not make, quite as much last year as they did in 1970, and the slight setback predicted for 1972 is already being felt.

A larger Europe, a more unified Europe, a stronger Europe --this had been the great dream behind postwar American foreign policy.

He received a solid education at Amherst College, the University of Bristol and the University of Pennsylvania (where he wrote the dissertation from which the present book was expanded). He has worked in Washington for two Congressmen.

In a recent letter, Prof. Jeffrey O'Connell, a law professor and leading proponent of "no fault" insurance, charges that trial lawyers refuse to represent car accident victims unless the other driver has insurance.

BUFFALO, Jan. 20 (UPI) -- Don Luce scored a first-period goal and Roger Crozier gained his second shutout of the season tonight as the Buffalo Sabres beat the Vancouver Canucks, 1-0.

BETHPAGE, L.I., Jan. 20 (AP) -- The Grumman Corporation expects to lose about $65-million in completing a contract for 86 F-14A Tomcat jet fighters and has told the Navy it considers options to buy more of the planes invalid, the company said today.

The pharmaceutical-chemical producers fared well last year, judging from results issued yesterday by the Warner-Lambert Company, Smith Kline French Laboratories, Inc., Richardson-Merrell, Inc., and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 -- The United States and Israel are nearing an agreement under which 18 more F-4 Phantom fighter-bombers would be delivered starting this spring, probably in March, according to well-placed administration sources.

ROME -- This is the year Italian women have taken pants to town. They've always worn them in their mountain and seaside resorts and on their yachts, but the hemline controversy just got too much for them.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 20 -- Orange County's Republican leader spoke out in praise of Newburgh's newly suspended Police Chief today, but the ranking Democrat here endorsed the suspension as a step toward erasing the city's reputation as a "cesspool" of crime.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 20 -President Salvador Allende Gossens accepted the ersignation of his Cabinet today in order to form a new one.

LONDON -- Nineteen-seventy-one was a year of far-reaching change, for Britain no less than for others. We have seen the dramatic set of economic measures announced by-President Nixon on Aug. 15; the emergence of the People's Republic of China as a member of the United Nations, and agreements in principle over such long-standing problems as West Berlin and Rhodesia.

The leader of President Allende's Socialist party in Chile says defeat of the Government coalition in two Congressional elections last weekend means it must "radicalize its program." A much more plausible explanation is that the results demonstrate just the opposite. They indicate that a majority of voters in both districts already have had enough of Dr. Allende's program to "construct socialism" in Chile.

How often does one get to hear solo mandolins at a symphony concert? The question answers itself. Thus there was at least some tonal curiosity about the Vivaldi Concerto for Two Mandolins and Orchestra, which led off Thursday night's Philharmonic program conducted by Bruno Maderna.

A vast army of fierce African honeybees, the descendants of 26 accidentally released in Brazil 15 years ago, has spread through much of South America and threatens eventually to invade North America, a committee of experts commissioned by the National Academy of Sciences has found.

ROUVREL, France, Jan. 18 -- Up to the middle nineteen-fifties there were no telephones in this isolated farm village on a plateau in northwestern Picardy, and the villagers carted water home from a communal well.

Under the name Sunny Jim, J. E. Gaines has acted to great advantage in many plays by Ed Bullins. Gaines is also a playwright, and a work of his called "Don't Let It Go to Your Head" opened Thursday at tile Henry Street Playhouse.

HOUSTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Lee Otis Johnson, a black militant sentenced to 30 years for giving an undercover policeman a marijuana cigarette, did not receive a fair trial because of racial tension in Houston, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

Hunger is no stranger to any land. Even in the United States, despite food surpluses and general affluence, there are thousands who suffer from malnutrition as a result of either quantitative or qualitative food deficiencies. But in America there are available the resources -- if not always the will -- to undertake programs that will alleviate hunger: food-stamp plans, school lunch programs, surplus food distribution, welfare assistance.

PRINCETON, N. J. -- For most inmates in New Jersey prisons, there is another prison -- its walls more formidable, its confinement more restrictive, its sentence harsh and unjust. The walls are the printed word, the confinement is the inability to read, and the sentence has been imposed by a discriminating judge -- American education.

A 7-year-old daughter of divorced parents has been ordered to live with her father in New Rochelle, N. Y., because a Family Court judge ruled that the Lower East Side, where the girl lived with her mother, was unsafe for children.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that it had charged nine men with violations of Federal insider-trading regulations in connection with their alleged dealings in shares of Harvey's Stores, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange.

GENEVA, Jan. 21 -- The oil-producing countries started their talks today with a dozen Western oil companies on the new request by the nations for "participation" in company subsidiaries extracting oil from their territories.

The director of Bellevue Hospital says he will be forced to close 14 wards containing 20 per cent of the 1,800 beds there in order to comply with an employe attrition policy the city hospital system describes as minor belt-tightening.

ATHENS, Jan. 21 -- Deputy Premier Stylianos Patakos said tonight that after nearly five years of rule by the military-backed Government of Premier George Papadopoulos, the Greek people were still tired of elections and wanted a rest.

Warren M. Shapleigh, 51 years old, has been elected president of the Ralston Purina Company, St. Louis, Mo. He formerly was an executive vice president and a director of the company and president of its consumer products group. The announcement was made by R. Hal Dean, chairman of the board and chief executive officer. The company's administrative organization has not included a president since 1970.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- A bill was introduced in the Senate today to repeal the tax check-off plan approved by Congress last year to finance Presidential election campaigns.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 21 -- The "H. R. Hughes" who opened an account in the Swiss Credit Bank here was not the idiosyncratic billionaire but a German-speaking blonde in her early thirties who used a forged Swiss passport as identification, Swiss banking sources said today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Justice Department said today that it was suspending financial support of an Alabama-based program to train policemen as helicopter pilots because of poor results and a question over $100,000 in expenditures.

NEWARK, Jan. 21 -- Essex County Prosecutor Joseph P. Lordi said today that his office had joined the investigation into the Jan. 14 shooting of Ron Porambo, a television newsman and author of a book about the 1967 race riots here.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Jan. 21 -- John Sherman Cooper, who has served nearly 20 years as a Republican Senator from Kentucky, formally announced today that he would not seek re-election this fall.

Recent prison uprisings, unfortunate as they may seem, have in a very dramatic way provided the impetus for a massive grass-roots look at our criminal-justice system and specifically the failure of our correctional agencies to correct. It is difficult to find fault with those who say that prisons are schools for crime or that correctional institutions should in fact be charged solely with rehabilitating and not penalizing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The TV Code has been amended to reduce by 25 per cent the time devoted to commercials and other nonprogram material during weekend television programs designed mainly for children.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21 -- Byron Dyce, who said, "I felt very powerful at the end," recorded his fastest indoor mile, 4 minutes 1.8 seconds, en route to an impressive victory in the Philadelphia Track Classic tonight.

A correction officer, a policeman and four other persons were under arrest yesterday on narcotics charges following police raids on the Brooklyn Community Release Center in the Granada Hotel, 268 Ashland Place, and on an apartment at 557 Putnam Avenue, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area.

Subtle and abstracted gesture along with fastidious surface finish is the stylistic lingua franca of Murray Louis's choreographic works. Thursday evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music his company presented the first performance of his fluidly calm work "Continuum."

LONG BRANCH, N. J., Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The Long Branch Daily Record announced yesterday that it was discontinuing Jack Anderson's Washington column because of the publication of information from purportedly top-secret documents of the Central Intelligence Agency.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- John Havlicek and Jo Jo White scored 28 points each tonight in leading the Boston Celtics to a 110-105 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Representative Frank T. Bow, the ranking Republican member of the House Appropriations Committee, today became the ninth high-ranking House Repubcan to announce that he would not seek re-election this year.

VIENNA, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- A 64-year-old former Nazi SS (Elite Guard) officer charged with complicity in the murder of Jews at Auschwitz said today that when he had discovered the camp's deadly purpose he begged to be transferred.

An arbitration board ruled yesterday that the Texas Rangers of the American League must pay $360,000 to the Texas League Spurs as a result of moving into the minor league club's territory, according to baseball commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

ROME, Jan. 21 -- Take a good long look at all those snug-fitting, tight-arm-hole clothes around. Pretty soon they're going to be obsolete. Loose tops with raglan shoulders and armholes as deep as the waistline are the coming thing. Valentino says so.

The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday that prices for goods and services in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area rose three-tenths of 1 per cent in November, marking the 56th successive monthly price advance in this area.
BOSTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Three persons in the Boston area, working independently, have decided that Franklin Delano Roosevelt wrote in code in his diary in Groton, Conn., on Nov. 22, 1903:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The Indian Government has appealed through the United Nations to the world for $50-million to $60-million in additional aid to help care for East Pakistani refugees still in India over the next two months.

For the last 15 years the art of Cy Twombly has been heavy with childhood allusions. In his "hand-writing" canvases the artist produced what looked like scribbling and graffiti to some and blackboard penmanship exercises to others.

Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally expressed strong opposition yesterday to legislation before Congress that would hamper imports into the United States and restrict the freedom of American companies operating overseas.

Cosme Rosado, the president of an airport union awaiting trial on Federal charges of racketeering, was fined $75,000 yesterday for "acts of vandalism and sabotage" that forced the closing of the elegant Restaurant America at Kennedy International Airport more than five months ago.

OAKLAND, Calif., Jan. 21 -- The rugged Rangers from New York man-handled the gallant California Golden Seals tonight and shut them out, 5-0. The Seals, playing before a record crowd of 10,478, tried hard, but they just did not have the muscle to stop the Rangers or the plays to capitalize on scoring opportunities.
Stock prices moved lower yesterday, extending the decline that began in the final hour on Thursday.

Letitzia Dolce is the head pasta maker at the Grand Hotel in Florence, Italy, but for the next two weeks she will be turning out fettucine, tortelloni, cannelloni and other pasta shapes for the Rainbow Room's Italian Fortnight.

At the Oakland Army Terminal, in California, Specialist 4 Christopher J. Jimenez received a unique honor: an official ceremony proclaiming him the 1,750,000th American serviceman to return from Vietnam since 1961, when the first American troops were sent there.

JUAREZ, Mexico, Jan. 21 -- A United States Government crackdown on black - market amphetamine operations along the Mexico border is driving up prices here and threatening to increase them elsewhere in the country.

"How did you people meet each other?" "What decided you to marry a foreigner?" I can't remember how many times I ran into these questions when I was an actress with the Shanghai People's Art Theater. Now, just arrived in America, the questions arise again.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Howard A. Cohen, who handles Congressional affairs for the Environmental Protection Agency, has put together political strategy for the administration on some controversial environmental bills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The new president of the National Congress of American Indians said today that the Administration's "new direction" in Indian affairs was "the typical kind of snow job all too often put over on Indian country."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senior Administration officials said today that it was now inevitable that Israel, given United States assurances in recent weeks of additional F-4 Phantom jets and of Washington's neutrality, would soon agree formally to resume negotiations on an interim Middle East agreement opening the Suez Canal.

The International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association tentatively agreed last night to a new set of working conditions in the port, including provisions for tighter policing of the guaranteed annual income.
The scene changes yearly with each staging of the Winter Antiques Show, but the imprint remains unmistakable, not withstanding dropout longtime dealers who had achieved a kind of landmark status.

The loan exhibition from the Cooper-Hewitt Museum at the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory serves as a good introduction to what the museum will contain when it reopens sometime in 1973.

To help consumers determine the actual price of a product or service in an advertisement, the city's Department of Consumer Affairs has promulgated a regulation requiring that hidden charges or special conditions be printed in nothing smaller than 10-point type.
"The Life of Leonardo da Vinci," a five-part dramatic series produced in Italy, will be televised this season, probably in midsummer, on the network of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Jan. 21 -- Counterattacking enemy forces overran some Government positions on a ridge overlooking the American-backed base of Long Tieng, and hand-to-hand fighting was reported today for control of the installation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 21 (AP) -- An intensified bombing campaign by United States B-52's continued for the fifth day today with attacks on suspected troop concentrations and supply dumps in the Central Highlands of South Vietnam near the Laotian border.

BOSTON, Jan. 21 -- For some time now, organized labor and big industry have been at loggerheads over whether the growing use of foreign factories by American companies throws American workers out of jobs and aggravates the balance-of-payments problem.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- A year-long intensive study of Lake Ontario, the most ambitious research effort ever directed at any of the Great Lakes, will begin April 1, United States and Canadian organizers of the program announced today.
TOKYO, Jan. 21 -- Japan has agreed in principle to yen-denominated bond financing by the Australian Government in the Tokyo capital market, Japanese and Australian Government sources have disclosed.
Shakespeare in modern dress is a commonplace in the theater. But Michel Fokine's "Chopiniana," otherwise known as "Les Sylphides," with no costumes, no set, no orchestra and even no overture?

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The draft lottery for the two million young men reaching age 19 this year will be held Feb. 2, earlier than any of the three previous drawings, the Selective Service System announced today.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 -- The Soviet Union acknowledged today that its all-out effort to develop the newest generation of electronic computers was lagging behind expectations. Computer development is a key goal of the current five-year plan.

Seventy-one persons were indicted yesterday in a steal-a-car-to-order business that allegedly operated out of an Army and Navy store in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn and sold more than 4,500 luxury autos in the last three years.
More than 16 miles of the Hudson River south of Albany were covered from shore to shore with 60,000 gallons of light fuel oil yesterday.

Mary Ann Pistorio had the first of her five children when she was not quite 16 and the last just five and a half years later. Immediately then she went looking for work and found a job as a "store maid," vacuuming and dusting in a fancy chinaware shop.

NEAR FIRE BASE MELANIE, South Vietnam, Jan. 18 -- In the field -- which means elephant grass, bamboo so thick and so tough a man must hack his way through it and heat that makes it punishing to walk a few hundred yards with an 80-pound pack -- the infantrymen wait for a helicopter that links them to the outside world every three days.

ST. GERVAISE, France, Jan 21 (AP) -- Annemarie Proell of Austria won the first leg of a giant slalom today and moved into a position where she could take over the lead in the women's over-all World Cup ski standing just before the Winter Olympic Games.

Among shows worth visiting this week there are a couple at the Metropolitan Museum and another couple at the Whitney. Give me one to keep for my own and I'll take the Metropolitan's collection of 95 drawings acquired during 1969.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Senator Robert J. Dole, Republican National Committee chairman, criticized the leading Democratic Presidential aspirants today and proposed that a special Congressional committee investigate the Vietnam war "to place the responsibility where it lies."

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Competitors in the 41st Monte Carlo Rally faced deteriorating weather conditions in France as they set off today from nine cities throughout Europe on the first stage of the grueling seven-day event.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- Mayor Lindsay opened a driving attack on Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama today, calling him a symbol of "repression, division, segregation" and challenging him to a statewide television debate before the Florida Presidential primary March 14.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Although the Mayor of their city and one of their Congressional colleagues are running for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the Democratic House members from New York City for the most part are shying away from Presidential endorse ments for now.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Moving to close the longest dispute in its records, the Federal Communications Commission today set March 19 as the date for transferring television Channel 5 in Boston from the Boston Herald-Traveler Corporation to new owners, Boston Broadcasters, Inc.

Greater New York's Blue Cross announced yesterday evening that it would ask the state to approve a 17.9 per cent increase in rates for hospitalization insurance charged to community-rated subscribers, effective May 1.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Jan. 21 -- President Nixon asked Congress today for special legislation to stop what he called the "intolerable" West Coast dock strike.

PARIS, Jan. 21 -- France, Austria, Switzerland and other Alpine countries are reacting strongly to the latest menace to life, limb and tranquility -- the snowmobile, which has crossed the Atlantic to invade ski trails in Europe.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21 -- A 13-0 spurt starting in the closing moments of the third period enabled the New York Knicks to score a 104-101 victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight before a capacity crowd of 17,505 at The Forum.

Once again The Times has slanted the truth about the Highway Trust Fund to fit its editorial whims. Your Jan. 10 editorial "Priorities in Transit" contends that the Highway Trust Fund "will . . . have an accumulated surplus of over $4 billion at the end of fiscal 1972." This is simply not true.

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The State Department of Environmental Conservation disclosed today that it had halted the processing of plans for 157 sewage treatment projects, with an estimated total cost of $1.5-billion, because there was not enough state and Federal money for them.

The First National City Bank trimmed its base, or prime lending rate, by 1/8 point to 4 5/8 per cent yesterday and a short time later the 4 3/4 per cent rate initiated by City Bank and Irving Trust a week ago became general at almost all other major institutions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Congressional Democrats presented their own "state of the union message" today on a nationwide television program, accusing President Nixon of neglecting problems on the home front and prolonging the war in Indochina.
Monday night's gala performance for the benefit of the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library will be composed of films and reminiscences by noted dance figures as well as live performances.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The nation's economy in the final months of 1971 had more growth and less inflation than was the case for several years, Government reports disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- Following are excerpts from a speech delivered yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury John B. Connally before the United States Chamber of Commerce, the transcript of which was released today:

ALBANY, Jan. 21 -- The Public Service Commission today backed a ruling by New York City's Environmental Protection Administrator and ordered the Consolidated Edison Company to curb the operation of its coal-burning electric generator at Arthur Kill No. 3 in Staten Island so as to produce only 200 megawatts of electricity.

ACCRA, Ghana, Jan. 20 -- A week after the military coup d'etat that dissolved one of Africa's few genuine democracies, the army seems to be in complete control of Ghana -- both in the hot, congested capital, where the soldiers are out of sight again, and in the rolling cocoa lands north of here, where the peace was scarcely disturbed at all.

The racial dispute that rocked Cornell's basketball team earlier this season surfaced again last night at Columbia University's Gym, but Cornell managed to overcome the loss of its leading scorer and defeat Columbia, 71-58, before 1,054 fans.

SOUTH PLAINFIELD, N. J., Jan. 21 -- A 27-year-old patrolman was shot to death near here today in an ambulance in which he was accompanying a man from Muhlenberg Hospital in Plainfield to the Marlboro State Hospital, a facility for the mentally disturbed in Monmouth County.
TRENTON, Jan. 21 (AP) -- The State Board of Higher Education voted to raise tuition at the state's four-year public colleges to $600 a year, an increase of $250.
ROME, Jan. 21 -- The talks on military bases in Malta that began here last Saturday reached an impasse today and were suspended.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation showed a sharp drop in earnings for 1971 and in the final quarter last year reflecting "severely eroded aluminum prices, higher costs and reduced income from non-aluminum activities," the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it had approved a package of restructured fares for the Long Island Rail Road, including an average increase of 16 2/3 per cent in ticket prices and eliminating the popular 10-trip discount ticket.

The Lomas Nettleton Financial Corporation announced yesterday it has agreed to buy for approximately $35-million in cash the $655-million mortgage servicing portfolios and certain other assets of three wholly owned subsidiaries of the Kardon Investment Company, a diversified privately owned concern in Philadelphia.

MANILA, Saturday, Jan. 22 -- A fire of undetermined origin destroyed the four-story Manila International Airport building early today, forcing the diversion of all domestic and international flights to Mactan, Cebu, in the Visayas area. At least six persons were killed and several were missing.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- Dr. Kofia A. Busia, who was ousted last week as Ghana's Prime Minister, said today that the military coup d'etat had stemmed from unhappiness among officers over the loss of some privileges.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 21 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith warned tonight that if blacks rejected the terms of a new settlement of Rhodesia's rebellion against Britain, his white Government would "be happy" to maintain its present laws, aimed at maintaining white supremacy forever.
Josue Marquez of Caguas, Puerto Rico, was the recipient of some generous voting by two of the officials in last night's Felt Forum fight against Doc McClendon of Paterson, N. J.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan 21 -- Now that the shooting part of the struggle has been won, the vast majority of the young Bengali guerrillas who fought for independence against the Pakistani Army are laying down their arms and turning to the jobs of reconstruction.

President Nixon paid scant attention to the war in Vietnam in his State of the Union messages, perhaps because he genuinely believes he can make that interminable conflict a nonissue in the Presidential campaign. That is most unlikely if the President clings to the policy he briefly reiterated in his written message.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market finished lower yesterday in moderate trading.

Your editorial of Jan. 11 on Howard Hughes might have been appropriate in the nineteen-thirties but is not of any value in 1972. WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Senator Fred R. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma, accused the Coca-Cola Company today of overcharging the public 3 cents a bottle on every dime Coke.

The Offtrack Betting Corporation, in a move to beef up its handle, will begin taking place bets Monday on Bowie races. OTB will conduct its own place pool, as it has been doing for win betting, exacta wagering and the daily double, which comprises the eighth and ninth races.
Judged as political dialogue rather than show business, the skillfully produced Democratic reply to President Nixon's State of the Union Message was less than successful.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- The number of cadets found guilty in the Air Force Academy's third cheating scandal within a decade increased to 39 today, and an academy spokesman said officials had also turned up evidence of marijuana smoking among the cadets.

ADELAIDE, Australia, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Evonne Goolagong, The Associated Press female athlete of the year, ecstatically accepted the honor today, then coolly whipped her opponent to advance to the final round of the South Australian state tennis championships.

In the Metropolitan Opera performance of Verdi's "Rigoletto" given Thursday night, Anna Moffo made her first appearance of the season with the company as Gilda and Enrico DiGiuseppe took the part of the Duke for the first time.
ROME, Jan. 21 -- President Giovanni Leone formally asked Premier Emilio Colombo late tonight to succeed himself as head of another center-left coalition government.

LONDON, Jan. 21 -- After years of repression and stillness, the Africans of Rhodesia have found their voice. Anyone who believes in the integrity of the individual human spirit will be moved by their courage in facing the guns of Ian Smith's policemen and army, in demonstrating, in shouting no to the proposed settlement between Britain and her rebel territory.

ATLANTA, Jan. 21 (AP) -- Hong Kong flu is beginning to take a toll in the current epidemic, according to the national Communicable Disease Center, which has reported that the disease is widespread in eight states, New York City and the District of Columbia.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 21 -- A British soldier was killed today, four days after his arrival in Ulster, by a guerrilla mine detonated from the Irish Republic.

BERKELEY, Calif., Jan. 21 (AP) -- Dave Maggard, the track coach at the University of California, became the school's athletic director today and immediately named Mike White, lured away from rival Stanford, as the Bears' head football coach.
PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 21 -- Representative Edith Green said today that she would not run for the Senate seat held by Mark O. Hatfield, a Republican.

LONDON, Jan. 21 (UPI) -- Clark Graebner gained a controversial default victory over Ilie Nastase of Rumania today in the semifinal round of the Rothman's indoor tennis tournament after a stormy first set in which the two players traded insults.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 -- The dock strike bill was introduced today by Republican Senators Bob Packwood of Oregon and Jacob K. Javits of New York.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy promoted Inspector Anthony V. Bouza to deputy chief inspector yesterday, transferring him from a division command to the Inspections Division and empowering him to investigate the efficiency of any police unit in the city.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 21 -- George Archer, who shared the lead yesterday, had it alone today in the $150,000 Dean Martin-Tucson open golf tourney. The former ranch hand from Gilroy, Calif., scored a 71 for a 36-hole aggregate of 136.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Jan. 21 -- They reached the end of the line at Remington Rand's sprawling old typewriter factory here after nearly 37 years of operation when an executive of the parent Sperry-Rand Corporation announced today that all production operations would be phased out by April 1.

AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 21 -- The Glastron Boat Company, Austin, has agreed with Chromos-Katran-Ketrilan, a leading chemical producer in Yugoslavia, to provide technical assistance in building a glass fiber boat plant in Zagreb.

BONN, Jan. 2l -- On the eve of a signing ceremony in Brussels expanding the European Common Market to 10 members, from 6, the West Germany Foreign Minister, Walter Scheel, said today that steps should be taken to strengthen the operating processes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- Colley Windflow, dean of American political analysts, yielded a moment of his day. Turning from a hot typewriter, he displayed his latest analysis of the political situation.

Terry Matson, the athletic director and basketball coach at Franklin Pierce College in Rindge, N. H., isn't too keen about having his team play Windham College of Putney, Vt., tomorrow night if Windham insists upon playing "that girl."

Contributions from an unemployed woman, a newspaper delivery boy and the priest in charge of a mission in Nenana, Alaska, were among the 255 recorded yesterday that added $9,234.95 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Jan. 24 (AP) -- An exhibition of American products from skillets to spacecraft opened today and thousands of Soviet Georgians jammed the pavilion to question Russian-speaking guides on how everything works.

OTTAWA, Jan. 24 -- The air traffic controllers tonight rejected by a 5 to 1 vote a tentative settlement of the strike that has grounded all domestic airline operations and barred international flights over Canada.
Mel Pender is more concerned about who will be pulling the trigger for the start of the 60-yard dash Friday night in the Millrose Games than the rivals who will challenge him at the finish line.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- The Soviet recognition of Bangladesh, announced here in a brief dispatch by Tass, the Soviet press agency, had been expected following the Soviet diplomatic and material support for India in her war against Pakistan.

BERKELEY, Calif. -- To a Westerner, life in new China may appear earnest, sober and rather serious. We heard no firecrackers and saw no fireworks. We saw no Buddhist monks or Taoist priests. Nor did we see a single bridal procession or funeral cortege. The pigeons in Peking no longer have whistles that hum as they fly, but the sparrows are coming back.

HATTIESBURG, Miss., Jan. 24 -- Former Gov. John Bell Williams refused to accept a subpoena here today to appear before a grand jury investigating his recent release of 14 youthful drug offenders, but later Mr. Williams, who left office last Tuesday, voluntarily went before the jury.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), the world's largest petroleum enterprise, announced yesterday a 15 per cent increase in 1971 earnings and higher indicated fourthquarter profits.

MONTE CARLO, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The first stage of the Monte Carlo auto rally ended today with 219 of 264 cars surviving the three-day grind across Europe and drivers hoping the final stages will be "more interesting."
A national policy statement on the country's growth and development was released by the American Institute of Architects yesterday over the strong protest of some of the institute's members.

ZAGREB, Yugoslavia, Jan. 24 -- A Croatian historian was trying to recount the tangled background of his people a few days ago when he paused to smile at a visitor's confusion. "Our history is like a crime story," he said.

In what would be a major advance for women in politics, about half of the state's 278 delegates to the Democratic national convention are expected to be women, Joseph F. Crangle, the newly elected Democratic state chairman, said yesterday.

Two prisoners handcuffed together were shot, one of them fatally, after one of them slashed a Federal marshal with a sharpened spoon in the marshal's car in front of the Federal courthouse in downtown Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Jan. 24 -The Federal judge in the conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan and six others charged with plotting the abduction of President Nixon's advisor on foreign policy matters, Henry A. Kissinger, threatened today to exclude the news media from the jury selection if they ignored his request to withhold publication of the names of the prospective jurors and their answers under examination.

Like its Russian counterpart, the Polish art song is a bit confined -- the general flavor tends to be either excessively sad or excessively merry. Still, it was intriguing to hear a collection of them so idiomatically and knowingly interpreted by Andrezej Bachleda Sunday afternoon in Carnegia Recital Hall.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Air Force said today it had tentative plans to dispose of 23.4 million gallons of a defoliant called "Agent Orange" at commercial plants near Houston and in Sauget, Ill., near East St. Louis.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Jan. 24 -A Syrian military spokesman was quoted by the Damascus radio today as having said that Syrian air defenses drove off Israeli fighter planes that attacked a guerrilla base north of Dera.

Directors of the New York Shipping Association approved a new agreement yesterday with the International Longshoremen's Association on working conditions in the port, and the union called a meeting for tomorrow at which its wage scale committee is scheduled to vote on the package.

ALBANY, Jan. 24 (AP) -New York State lottery officials today postponed next month's sale of million-dollar "special" lottery tickets until the summer so the sale will not compete with the lucrative weekly drawing, which was started last week.

ATHENS, Jan. 24 -- Two Greek Orthodox bishops are under ecclesiastical investigation on charges that may lead to expulsion from their sees. The accusations arise from their demands for the restoration of democratic rule in the church, suspended in the church as well as in the state after the military coup of April 21, 1967.
KIRKWALL, Scotland, Jan. 19 -- For more than 800 years St. Magnus Cathedral, begun by the Vikings, has withstood the buffetings of countless Atlantic storms and the corrosive effect of salt spray.

Prices of copper futures on the Commodity Exchange in New York yesterday closed 1/20 cent higher to 1/10 cent lower, with the nearby March, 1972, contract at 48 1/4 cents a pound, up 1/20 cent from the previous close. All other contracts closed lower.

With the hot-pink-and-canaryyellow boards surrounding the infield forming a backdrop, Steve Hernandez capped a noisy, smoky and exciting evening by capturing the $5,000 first prize in the Yamaha Silver Cup motorcycle competition in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -Total borrowing from the public by the Treasury Department and Government - sponsored agencies will be just less than $30-billion in fiscal 1973, President Nixon estimated in his new budget today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 24 -President Salvador Allende Gossens named a new Minister of Interior today, filling the chief political post in the Cabinet in the first step toward reorganization of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The new budget contains the first endorsement by President Nixon of "deregulation" of freight transportation -- a plan to ease government controls and stimulate competitive price reductions that lacked Presidential support last year and was nearly smothered in Congress.
Eight teams remain unbeaten in the Greater New York Bridge Association's double knockout team championship for the Von Zedtwitz trophy from an original entry of 64 teams.

Three hundred enthusiastic but orderly gypsy cab drivers and industry officials alternately booed and cheered yesterday at a City Council hearing on legislation that would regulate their business for the first time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -The theme runs throughout President Nixon's budget that additional taxes are going to be required soon if the Federal Government does not stop getting into new programs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Nixon Administration's new budget calls for increases, dramatic in some areas, for social needs. But the gains are largely a result of legislation already enacted or long pending. The budget discloses little in the way of major social initiatives.

SHARJA, Tuesday, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- The ruler of the Persian Gulf state of Sharja was found shot to death inside his palace today after an attempted coup by his cousin, the former ruler, and 18 followers.
LONDON, Jan. 24 -- There can be no doubt that the violence that has accompanied Lord Pearce's presence in Rhodesia has sorely dismayed him.

Theater as mystery and ritual -- the theater as a nonverbal experience of tragedy -- this is what Andrei Serban's cryptic reworking of "Medea" at the La Mama is all about. It is a potent theatrical event, and it offers deep insights into the nature of the dramatic experience.
TEL AVIV, Jan. 24 -- Israel reported today that her jets flew 20 miles into Syria this afternoon and dropped the first bombs on Syrian territory in 19 months.
Two-thirds of the tenants in the city's 1.2-million rent-controlled apartments will owe a total of $87-million more in rent this year, city rent officials estimate.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -Administration forces in the Senate, capitalizing on the absence of two Democratic Presidential candidates, succeeded today in holding back a proposal to give strong enforcement powers to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -Gov. Milton J. Shapp of Pennsylvania will announce tomorrow his support of Senator Edmund S. Muskie's bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

ADELBODEN, Switzerland, Jan. 24 -- It's off to Sapporo now. The last World Cup ski race before the Winter Olympics turned out to be a fogbound affair today that left the situation in the men's giant slalom about as clear as the weather.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- Femininity is returning to fashion with a vengeance. Make way for flowering chiffons, flaring skirts, bare shoulders, tiny waistlines and all the other blandishments designers forgot about in the last few sad, bad years.
ABOARD IRANIAN FRIGATE MILANIAN, in the Persian Gulf, Jan. 13 -- Iran is reinforcing her position as the dominant sea power in the Persian Gulf.
TOMS RIVER, N. J., Jan. 24 -- How far can the state restrict a man's use of his own property before it must buy it from him?

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Jan. 24 (UPI) -- The new Intelsat 4 communications satellite shifted into its final stationary orbit high above the central Pacific tonight and engineers started preparing it for coverage of President Nixon's visit to China next month.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Jan. 24 (AP) -- Rosemary Casals of San Francisco used a strong net game to wear down Francoise Durr of Paris and win the Long Beach women's professional tennis tournament last night, 6-2, 6-7, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -Federal expenditures for health care will continue to rise in the fiscal year 1973, but the Administration is hoping that the galloping inflation in medical costs may be slowed next year.
A fair assessment of the success of the nation's price controls cannot be made until April, Robert F. Lanzillotti, a member of the Administration's Price Commission, said yesterday.

Phillip E. Goldfein stood on the teak-textured deck of the white-and-blue fiberglass Concorde 41 double-cabin flyingbridge power yacht yesterday and patted the stainless-steel railings as if he were the owner. The funny thing about it, he was.

Part of a four-piece pipe bomb that the police said "could have caused death or serious injury" exploded at 10:15 A.M. yesterday in an empty stairwell of the Portuguese Airways office at 601 Fifth Avenue. The damage was slight and no one was injured. Minutes earlier there had been people on the stairway.

" Strong military defenses are not the enemy of peace, they are the guardians of peace," said President Nixon in his State of the Union Message, as preface to his announcement that he would ask for an increase in the defense budget. Undoubtedly, the Russians see it the same way, at least as regards their defenses, but the real question is not strength, but how much strength?
" C'est tres exagere," -- it's very exaggerated -- exclaimed Manhattan Borough President Percy E. Sutton yesterday after reading of a Paris newspaper's descriptions of the perils of New York.

State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger charged yesterday that some landlords in Long Beach, L. I., were exploiting welfare recipients and that the Nassau County Department of Social Services was at least lax.

The ill-starred war in Laos is proving a disaster. An early dry-season offensive of unprecedented strength by the North Vietnamese has taken a heavy toll of American airpower diverted to several Laotian fronts. Embarrassing defeats have been inflicted on Americandirected Laotian and Thai forces. The drive has approached Thailand's Mekong River border with Laos in the south, and apparently has activated Chinese antiaircraft crews against American planes in northern Laos.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -After 111 years of being kicked around as a clothing warehouse, an Army office building, a courthouse for aggrieved citizens and a convention hall for pigeons, the Renwick Gallery finally has become what it was meant to be -- a home for the arts.

Senator Jacob Javits' recent letter concerning the so-called national health crisis employs oft-repeated and warped statistics which rank the United States "thirteenth in infant mortality and 22d in life span for men." He is apparently unaware of the great variations in statistical methods of recording infant mortality.

The year 1971 both began and ended with unemployment at 6 per cent. Will 1972 be any better? Much of the growth of output which is expected in 1972 will be accomplished through the increased productivity of those already at work.
The president of L. W. Frohlich Co./Intercom International has submitted his resignation to the board of directors because it has kept him in the dark as to the future of the agency.

TRENTON, Jan. 24 -- The nation's first statewide comprehensive noise-control legislation, designed to muffle the clamor in what has been called the country's noisiest state, was signed here today by Gov. William T. Cahill.

A recruiting effort, backed with Federal Funds, to hire black and Puerto Rican guards for the Attica Correctional Facility is being challenged in court on the ground that it represents "reverse discrimination."

" I was raised in the tradition of the Navy and I want to follow it," said Barbara J. Brimmer, who was introduced by Senator Jacob K. Javits as his nominee to the 1972 plebe class at the United States Naval Academy.
TOKYO, Jan. 24 -- Foreign Minister Takeo Fukuda said tonight that Japan and the Soviet Union had agreed on "exchanging visits" of their heads of government in the near future.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
The fare on the Staten Island Rapid Transit lines will go to a flat 35 cents on Feb. 1, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday. Federal Price Commission approval is expected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- As a result of a tie vote in the Supreme Court today, three of the nation's largest drug manufacturers secured a reversal of a conviction on price-fixing charges brought by the Government 10 years ago.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 24 -- Iowa Democrats made their way along icy roads to meetings in snow-shrouded churches, schools and homes tonight to begin the selection of the state's 46 delegates to the Democratic National Convention.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -- As every householder knows, the cost of running a house has been steadily going up. The White House is no exception.

United Air Lines has set up a nighttime escort service for its stewardesses working out of La Guardia Airport. Men employes, using a special ramp vehicle, drive the stewardesses from the aircraft landing area to their automobiles and then wait for the women to drive away.
The Telex Corporation has added its name to the list of companies suing the International Business Machines Corporation for alleged violation of the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -The nation's total output of goods and services will rise $98-billion this year to $1,145billion, according to the official Government forecast disclosed today.

A New York accountant who spent 13 months in a Mexican prison on a drug conviction that was ultimately reversed by an appellate court said yesterday that an unexpected result of United States pressure on Mexico to stamp out cross-border narcotics trafficking was the imprisonment of young Americans who had been framed or given onerously long sentences.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (UPI) -- Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. blocked today until Feb. 10 further testimony before a Federal grand jury in Boston on Senator Mike Gravel's version of the Pentagon papers.
The election of the top executives at two major companies was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 -The Government is planning to start collecting new statistics next year that will tell a more accurate and detailed story of how many people are unemployed, which type of workers are getting the biggest wage increases and what industries are the main sources of inflation.

John P. Fishwick, president of the Norfolk Western Railway, the nation's most profitable carrier, said yesterday that although the road's profits dropped sharply in the fourth quarter last year because of the coal strike it managed to increase its profits for the year before an extraordinary charge.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., the nation's largest chemical producer, reported yesterday higher earnings and sales for the final quarter of 1971 and the year as a whole.

The Rapid-American Corporation, which controls a $1-billion retail merchandising complex, is planning to expand this business through a tender offer to purchase 950,000 shares, or about 49 per cent, of the common stock of the J. J. Newberry Company.

TUCSON, Ariz., Jan. 24 -Miller Barber won the Dean Martin-Tucson open golf tourney in a new way today. After finishing the scheduled 18-hole playoff all even with George Archer, he finally triumphed in a sudden-death session that went three extra holes.
Recently numerous correspondents have been asking what equipment should be brought on a Florida fishing trip.

The accession to Europe's six-nation Common Market of Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland is likely to be remembered by history less for enlarging the European Economic Community (E.E.C.) than for accelerating its progress toward internal union and a new relationship with the outside world, especially the United States.
Two men pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to charges of grand larceny and conspiracy in the theft of more than $2million from the city's Medicaid program.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin flew to Prague today for a meeting with top Eastern European Communist leaders to put new pressure on the West to begin preliminary talks for a European security conference.

The Consolidated Edison Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The report, labeled "a tentative income statement," placed operating revenues at $1,313,862,302 for 1971.

MILWAUKEE, Jan. 25 (AP) -Bob Dandridge scored 30 points and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar 26 tonight in leading the Milwaukee Bucks to a 123-91 National Basketball Association victory over the Seattle Supersonics.

In a new accelerating competition among the nation's law schools, Columbia University has just scored a major coup: its law school, to its undisguised glee, has just bid for and won a woman for the job of full professor -- the first in its 114-year history.
A professorship in peace studies, one of the first in the country, is to be established at Colgate University in Hamilton, N. Y.

Mayor Lindsay recently announced construction of pilings for the $750-million North River Pollution Control Plant, due for completion in 1979. " It seems to be the story of my life," said Ed Giacomin with a shrug yesterday. "I'd give up three goals and then Cesare Maniago or Don Simmons or Terry Sawchuk would replace me the next game. Now it's Gilles Villemure."

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- The Rothschild women are certainly doing their bit to stiffen the morale of the couture here. Today, the Baroness Guy de Rothschild -- her husband is chief of the clan -- turned up at the Lanvin collection and chatted amiably with Maryl Lanvin, whose husband owns the house.
If some shareholders of J. J. Newberry are apprehensive over the bid Monday evening by Meshulam Riklis to buy nearly half of the shares of the variety-store chain, it is perhaps understandable.

We protest The Times' extraordinary editorial condemning Stanford English Professor Bruce Franklin. Its intemperate language, factual errors and misunderstanding of the issues sadden us profoundly. We had expected better of America's foremost paper.

MOSCOW, Jan. 25 -- The Kremlin sharply attacked Soviet art and literary critics today for what it called easy tolerance of ideological backsliding and artistic trash and ordered them to improve their standards.

Cornell C. Maler has been elected president of the Kaiser Aluminum Chemical Corporation. He succeeds T. J. Ready Jr., who becomes chairman of the executive committee and continues as chief executive officer.

A record $10,721.60 exacta, on which the owners of the second-place horse won $53,388, touched off a debate here yesterday over the regulations governing exotic wagering.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- Cazzie Russell scored 35 points and Jim Barnett added 29 tonight to pace the Golden State Warriors to a 117-111 National Basketball Association victory over Cleveland as the Cavaliers dropped their 11th game in a row.

The Gala Performance to Save the Dance Collection of the New York Public Library, which took place at the New York City Center on Monday night, should be more a matter of record than a subject for criticism.
The Conservative party of New York announced its support yesterday for Representative John M. Ashbrook, Republican of Ohio, for the Republican Presidential nomination.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations said today that it would oppose President Nixon's re-election bid this year, regardless of whom the Democrats nominated.

American Brands, Inc., attained record sales and earnings in 1971 for the fifth consecutive year despite a fourth-quarter dip in profits, Robert B. Walker, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.
