Two leaders of the management - consulting fraternity yesterday, argued -- genteelly, of course -- as to whether private firms or those owned publicly or by institutions represented the future of their profession.

On-time performances as low as 50 per cent, dirty cars and truncated scheduled on Penn Central commuter lines in New Jersey were discussed at a meeting of railroad and New Jersey Department of Transportation officials yesterday in Philadelphia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Jan. 25 -- President Tito told the nation today that the Yugoslav Communist party would undergo a major reorganization to forestall crises such as the one over nationalism that recently erupted in the Republic of Croatia.
Cheers were not the order of the day in the oil industry as a number of major companies released earnings reports for the full year and final quarter of 1971.
An off-duty motor-scooter patrolman was stabbed to death at about 5 A.M. yesterday in his girlfriend's Queens apartment.

The winds that blew through New York yesterday were obeying simple laws of nature, but because of an unusual combination of atmospheric conditions that has not prevailed in this area for three years, they blasted with near hurricane force through the city's canyons.
The United States Steel Corporation yesterday reported gains in net income for the fourth quarter despite lower sales. Sales and net income for the full year ran higher than in 1970.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The White House explained tonight that President Nixon had decided to reveal the details of secret Vietnam peace negotiations because secrecy had fostered unacceptable political divisions at home.

DETROIT, Jan. 25 -- The auto industry, in a major shift in policy, has decided to back legislation in Michigan that would divert part of the revenue from taxes on gasoline to support and develop public mass transportation in the state's major cities.
SHARJA, Jan. 25 (Reuters) -- The ruling family of the Persian Gulf emirate of Sharja totoday elected an interim Ruler to succeed the emir, who was shot to death in an attempted coup d'etat.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- President Nixon disclosed to the American public tonight a proposal to end the war in Indochina that he said had been offered in secret channels three months ago but ignored by the North Vietnamese.
LONDON, Jan. 25 -- A letter from 187 British scientists today warned of the gravity of the "growing ecological crisis."

OTTAWA, Jan. 25 -- Government negotiators met with union officials late today after 1,600 striking air-traffic controllers rejected a tentative settlement. Prospects, if any, for an end to the strike were not immediately apparent.
Eastern Air Lines, Inc., raised its 1971 net income by 4.2 per cent to $5,690,000, or 32 cents a share, from $5,461,000, or 39 cents a share, the year before, it was reported yesterday.

STUART, Fla., Jan. 25 -- From the air over Florida, the new gleaming houses spread out from the booming town, like sugar cubes in the sun. Here are the retired folks from the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal, bronzed like the man and wife in the insurance advertisements, but mortgaged to the hilt and not quite so happy.

Yields on high-quality, tax-exempt state bonds moved substantially higher yesterday, and investors decided they liked the interest rates they were being offered.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 25 -- The police here said today that they wanted to see Clifford Irving, author of "The Autobiography of Howard Hughes," and his wife, Edith Sommer Irving, in connection with the investigation into the deposit and withdrawal, by persons unknown, of $650,000 from McGraw-Hill, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- The opening round of the 1972 battle over expansion of the Office of Economic Opportunity began today with the Nixon Administration announcing its opposition to major portions of new antipoverty legislation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -President Nixon intends to nominate Robert S. Ingersoll, chairman of the Borg-Warner Corporation, to be Ambassador to Japan in an effort to upgrade the post at a time of strained relations between Washington and Tokyo, Administration sources said today.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Jan. 25 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine won the largest share of the delegates in last night's Iowa precinct caucuses, late returns showed today.

MIAMI, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The authorities were rounding up 22 persons in seven states today after indictments by a Federal grand jury in what the Government said was a $150-million mail fraud conspiracy.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 25 -The brief war between India and Pakistan last month was prolonged by a day because the Pakistani message of surrender, conveyed to India through the United States, was held up in Washington, according to authoritative reports.

The Southern Railway Company, one of the nation's most profitable railroads, yesterday announced record revenues and earnings for 1971.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 25 -- Prime Minister William McMahon announced new land rights and other benefits for Australia's 140,000 aborigines today. In effect, however, the policy reaffirms a previous repudiation of aboriginal claims to ownership of tribal areas.

Prices of the world No. 11 nearby sugar contract futures rose yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The March, 1972, contract closed at 8.68 cents a pound, up from 8.54 cents a pound on Monday. The May, 1972, option closed at 8.66 cents a pound, up from 8.51 cents a pound.

One of the oddities, or perhaps inequities, of the scoring table is the advantage to be derived by sacrificing against a grand slam when the vulnerability is in your favor. If your opponents bid to a vulnerable seven hearts, which they are due to make, you can make a paper profit in seven spades doubled, not vulnerable, if you can make two tricks in a duplicate or Chicago game, or three tricks at rubber bridge.

Richard Dixon, baritone, has improved various aspects of his performances since his last appearance here, 11 months ago. His stage manner is more relaxed, his singing has gained in emotional involvement, his whole manner exudes greater confidence.

ALBANY, Jan. 26 -- A revised bill to extend New York City's interim Board of Education for two more years and to permit Borough Presidents to appoint successors to the present incombents on the board was introduced today in the Senate.

South Carolina, with three players from the metropolitan area in its starting line-up and three others on its 11-man roster, opposes Fordham, with its pressing defense, tonight in what is likely to be the biggest drawing card of the Madison Square Garden college basketball season.

Jacques Brel was alive and well and on stage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday evening. WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission warned all brokerage firms today that it now has additional money from Congress to inspect their books more often and intends to do so.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation achieved its highest sales and earnings to date in 1971, Donald C. Burnham, chairman, reported yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its estimated net income for the fourth quarter of 1971 totaled $129,175,000, or $1.52 a share, compared with $126,888,000, or $1.49 a share a year earlier. Sales were $1,629,910, 000, against $1,346,416,000.

Two major companies announced appointments yesterday.

Port Louis has no hotels, only a few boats and a superb Creole restaurant called Chez Odette.

Americans continue to be pessimistic about the job outlook, though less pessimistic than they were in October, the Gallup Poll said yesterday. However, it said more people believed that prices would rise in the coming months.

Martin S. Ackerman, Mr. Irving's attorney, said here yesterday that the novelist had not been interviewed by agents of the F.B.I although the lawyer had urged the agency to enter the case.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- It may be in its death throes, but the couture still stands, supported mainly by the twin pillars of Valentino in Rome and Christian Dior in Paris. It's been shaken to its roots by (1) the thinning ranks of private customers, (2) the lack of interest of American store buyers and manufacturers and (3) internecine warfare.

A jury that was later described by eight of its members as "hopelessly deadlocked" 7 to 5 in favor of acquittal was dismissed yesterday, and the third trial of four young defendants charged with the 1964 murder of a Harlem shopkeeper was declared a mistrial.

Williams Company, recently acquired by Nabisco. Robert M. Schaeberle, president of Nabisco, has also been elected chief operating officer, while Lee S. Bickmore, chairman, remains chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON -- Victorian taste is still as exotic and unfathomable to most Americans as the puberty rites of far-off tribes, but it has been officially endorsed in the Smithsonian Institution's new Renwick Gallery, which opens to the public today.

Although Willis Reed's return has been postponed indefinitely, the New York Knickerbockers are still fighting for first place in the National Basketball Association's Atlantic Division. They meet the division-leading Celtics in Boston tonight.

MEXICO CITY -- Mexico suffered her worst economic slowdown in more than a decade last year as the Government of President Luis Echeverria Alvarez sought to give a social orientation to development. His policies have not won many friends among Mexican businessmen.

OTTAWA -- The United States could have forced Canada to repeg her dollar at the Washington monetary conference last month if Treasury Secretary John B. Connally had not "overplayed his hand," according to a well-informed Canadian.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- A clandestine laboratory equipped for the production of heroin was reported discovered today in Marseilles by French customs agents. At the same time what was described as an important stock of equipment and chemicals used to turn morphine base into heroin was seized there.
BOGOTA, Colombia -- World monetary revaluation, while aimed at setting aright trade relations between the major powers, has drawn a demurrer from Colombia.

WASHINGTON -- About 1,400 Vietnamese refugees were recently moved from wretched refugee camps in Quangtri Province of I Corps, the northernmost region of South Vietnam, to another camp 450 miles to the south. Vietnamese refugees have never before been resettled so far from their former homes.

The cruise ship Island Venture became the first new liner to enter the port this year when she was brought into her berth yesterday at Pier 92, North River.

A decision permitting rent increases for 800,000 controlled apartments in the city was issued here yesterday by a Federal judge who had temporarily blocked the scheduled rise in rents. The city promptly announced that the first notices would be mailed next Monday to inform tenants of the rent increases, ranging up to 7.5 per cent, retroactive to Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -President Nixon accepted the resignation of Maurice H. Stans as Secretary of Commerce today and nominated Peter G. Peterson, the White House assistant for international economic affairs, to replace him.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that despite Hanoi's public denunciations, he was "somewhat encouraged" by the absence of a North Vietnamese rejection of President Nixon's latest Vietnam peace plan at the Paris talks.

A coalition of community groups declared yesterday that the imposition of tuition charges at the City University would remove "one of the few remaining incentives for white, middle-class families to remain in the city -- the opportunity to send their sons and daughters to the tuition-free City University."

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 26 -- An American-owned company here is buying blood plasma from impoverished Haitians who need the money and exporting 5,000 to 6,000 liters of it every month to the United States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 17 -- Two weeks ago, when White House aides first approached Robert S. Ingersoll about becoming Ambassador to Japan, he says, he was not interested. He already had a challenging job as board chairman and chief executive officer of the giant Borg-Warner Corporation, which has its international headquarters here.
BUENOS AIRES -- The economic storm that had been gathering over Argentina since 1946 burst last year.

Paula Fudge is 26 years old, with big brown eyes, long dark hair, a trim figure and polished fingernails. She wears gold jewelry, false eye lashes and elegant dresses. You would think she was an actress, a model, a leisurely young housewife or, perhaps, an airline stewardess.
LONDON, Jan. 27 (Reuters) -- Thieves escaped with some $78,000 worth of silver bullion and coins bound for Rome early today in a raid on a freight train in the London area.

ALBANY, Jan. 27 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that he was postponing implementation of the new statewide day-care fee schedule until March 1, in effect giving low-income families additional time to get into the program at the current lower fee schedule.

Coming down the stretch of its current City Center run, American Ballet Theater offered interesting cast changes in "Dark Elegies" and "Fancy Free" on Wednesday evening.

TORONTO -- Not since the "free trade election" of 1911 has Canada been so absorbed with the question of her economic relations with the United States. A half-century ago the electorate turned out Sir Wilfrid Laurier's Liberal Government, which had negotiated a reciprocal free-trade agreement with Washington, in favor of Sir Robert Borden and the Conservatives.

PARIS, Jan. 27 -- The Vietnamese Communists insisted at the peace talks here today that there can be no Vietnam settlement until the United States first sets a specific date for total military withdrawal and ousts the present South Vietnamese Government.

Two of the nation's biggest railroad holding companies reported yesterday higher net income, before extraordinary charges, for the fourth quarter and full year of 1971.
The hijacker of a Mohawk Airlines plane who was slain early yesterday as he tried to flee in a car with $200,000 and a stewardess-hostage was an unemployed father of seven who was deeply in debt.
The State Division of Human Rights succeeded yesterday in postponing the dismissal of 30 maids by Columbia University.

CARVILLE, La. -- Public Health Service officials are concerned about new difficulties in treating a small but growing number of leprosy patients whose infections have become resistant to sulfone drugs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Administration officials, under sharp attack for record deficit spending, said today that a deficit was just what the economy needed. But they cautioned that taxes would have to be raised if Congress added to the outlays.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States mentioned a possible figure of $2.5-billion in aid for North Vietnam out of a possible total of $7.5-billion for Indochina over five years during Henry A. Kissinger's secret talks with Hanoi officials in Paris, a White House official said tonight.
PANAMA -- Amid a confusion of political ideologies, Panama's steady economic growth is converting this "crossroads of the world" into the financial center for Latin America.

SAN DIEGO, Jan. 27 -- Gene Littler arrived at the Torrey Pines course in one of his old cars today and with an 18- year-old putter in his golf bag. When he left, it was after scoring a six-under-par 66 in the $150,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open and taking a two-stroke lead after the first round.

BOSTON, Jan. 27 (UPI) -- Phil Esposito scored three goals tonight and became the second player in National Hockey League history to score more than 40 goals in four straight seasons as the Boston Bruins defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 4-2.

Ralph Doubell, who is confident of winning another Olympic gold medal, and Martin McGrady, who is hoping to find his Olympic specialty, lead a contingent of outstanding athletes for the 65th Wanamaker Millrose Games tonight.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y. -- When Longfellow described the blacksmith as "a mighty man is he, with large and sinewy hands," he hadn't met Donna Hincher. Donna is 19, 5 feet 2 and weighs 105 pounds. She has small hands with nicely manicured nails. A pre-med sophomore at Union College, she spends all of her spare time working as an unpaid groom at the Saratoga Raceway, the harness track.

Charles-Edouard Jeanneret, known the world over as a great architect and architectural theorist under the name of Le Corbusir, a pseudonym adopted in 1918. was also a painter and graphic artist of some distinction.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Jan. 28 -- A solitary picket paced back and forth at the foot of Santa Barbara's main pier this week, waving a battered placard reading: "Union and Sun Are Unfair."

GENEVA, Jan. 28 -- The chief negotiator for the Persian Gulf oil-producing countries said today that compensation for the 20 per cent "participation" they are demanding in Western oil companies operating on their territories would be determined solely by the book value of their investments.

The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it would close down the major part of its Duluth, Minn., integrated steel mill by March 4. The shutdown would eliminate the jobs of some 1,600 of the plant's normal work force of 2,300.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Jan. 28 -- The voice of African nationalism -- muffled for years in white-ruled Rhodesia -- was heard again today as black leaders told an English peer why they oppose Britain's suggested agreement to recognize the independence of the white Government here.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Britain said today that the dispatch of forces to British Honduras was for land, air and sea exercises planned since last April and not a show of strength against Guatemala, which claims the British colony.

Characterizing the nation's prisons as a "total failure," Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy called yesterday for a revolution in public attitudes and the infusion of hundreds of millions of dollars to supplant retribution with rehabilitation in the correctional system.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 28 (Reuters) -- The 28th World Zionist Congress ended early today in a stormy session when Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, withdrew from the convention hall in protest against a resolution binding Zionist leaders to settle in Israel.

BOSTON, Jan. 28 -- After making 50 per cent of their shots in the second half to rally from a 19-point deficit, the New York Knicks could not locate the hoop in an overtime period tonight and bowed to the Boston Celtics, 122-116. before a capacity crowd of 15,315 at Boston Garden.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 28 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu agreed to the allies' new peace proposals, including his offer to resign, even before his re-election last Oct. 3, according to authoritative American sources.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The father of an 8-year-old girl who died of a kidney disorder says her body has been frozen in the hope that science later will be able to revive and cure her.

The fight over a housing project under construction in Forest Hills has focused national attention on the scatter-site program for integrating low-income families into middle-income neighborhoods. The scatter-site theory holds that only by building public housing outside urban ghettos can the problems of those ghettos be eliminated.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. Jan. 28 (UPI) -- Four youths, described as members of the Jewish Defense League, were free on $250 bond today after being arrested and charged with breach of peace for disturbing a Russian orchestra performance.
Igor M. Averin, head of the Soviet Union's Ministry of Merchant Marine, said yesterday that American ships "are welcome in the Soviet Union as soon as the necessary business starts."

Ruritan National opened its annual convention here yesterday. The organization is made up of 1,250 clubs in 31 states, and for the most part its 36,855 members are country people.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- Friday and Saturday night at Ueno Station here make Grand Central in New York look like wide open spaces.

Navy personnel in that country.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 -- Andrel A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, warned today that countries desiring friendly relations with both China and the Soviet Union must act without adversely affecting "the safety and interests" of the Soviet Union.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 -- The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., disclosed today that it was abolishing 1,965 jobs and would slash production of nickel by 10 per cent. " A midsummer nightmare," a cancer, a carnival and "creeping honky-tonkism" -- these denunciations of commercial development were hurled last night at the City Planning Commission by Greenwich Village residents who charged that the normal protections of zoning had broken down in their community.
The Knicks begin their busiest and perhaps most hazardous stretch of the National Basketball Association season tonight when they face the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden.

The business forecasters' two-month annual open season on the United States economy has just reached its climax with the Economic Report of the President and, if they are on target, 1972 could be one of the best years in our economic history.

HONG KONG, Jan. 31 -- President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto of Pakistan arrived by air in Peking today for talks with Chinese officials as China delivered an atack on India and the Soviet Union, warning that they would ultimately suffer "defeat" on the subcontinent.
The operating engineers who oversee the heating of 120 major office buildings in Manhattan went on strike just after midnight this morning.
Brooklyn did grow. By 1855 she swallowed the city of Williamsburgh and the town of Bushwick to make her the third most populous city in the United States.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- For the third time in as many years, the Assembly passed a bill today designed to end glue-sniffing by youngsters by requiring that hobby glues sold in the state contain a substance that would cause coughing and sneezing when inhaled deeply.
Fred Thompson started the Atoms Track Club of Brooklyn, "not as a track team," he said yesterday, "but as a sort of social project, an experience.
BENQUET, France -- In the secrecy of their laboratories, scientists of a number of countries are racing to invent the self-stuffing goose.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, the New York State Attorney General's office and the New York Stock Exchange have begun investigations into the hectic trading and sharp price fluctuations in shares of the Levitz Furniture Corporation.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Jan. 31 -- The Government's troubles with the Ovambo tribesmen of South-West Africa appear to be far from over.

The Federal Aviation Administration ordered the nation's scheduled airlines yesterday to put in use by this weekend an approved passenger and baggage screening system to prevent hijackings and sabotage.

INDIANAPOLIS, Jan. 31 -Though symphony orchestras throughout the country are in financial difficulties, the Hoosier capital is in immediate danger of losing the Indianapolis Symphony Orcestra, the centerpiece of its musical life for the last 42 years, because of a set of singular problems.

Art themes are nothing new to V'Soske, the carpet concern at 155 East 56th Street. But the op, Cubist and abstract patterns in the 1972 collection are quite different from the more conventional designs that the prestigious concern had produced in secent years.

While one trainer-driver took a lie-detector test, investigators theorized yesterday that tablets or a tiny palm-needle might have been used to drug two horses in the paddock last Thursday night at Roosevelt Raceway.
A 360-year-old retail concern in Japan, the Matsuzakaya Company, Ltd., expects to have one of its most difficult years in 1972 because of the yen re-valuation and the pressure on Japanese exports.

Bayard Rustin, who was arrested here late Sunday night on a charge of possessing a dangerous weapon, was released on his own recognizance yesterday after waving his right to a hearing pending action of the Manhattan grand jury.

KINGSTON, R.I., Jan. 31 -Paced by the inside scoring of Mel Davis and Ed Searcy and the outside shooting of Richie Lyons, St. John's defeated Rhode Island, 86-73, before 4,600 fans tonight at the losers' fieldhouse.
Direct-selling credit companies -- the employers of those door-to-door salesmen that call on householders throughout the country -- expect 1972 to follow 1971 as a strong year for their industry.

The United Transportation Union obtained a 10-day adjournment yesterday of a hearing on the Long Island Rail Road's application for an injunction against a walkout. The effect was to continue the current stay against a walkout.

Some nurses left hospitals, some transferred to different departments and a number went through group therapy and counseling sessions after New York State passed one of the most liberal abortion laws in the country.
ATLANTA, Jan. 31 (UPI) -Atlanta's black legislators today endorsed, with modifications, a plan to expand the city's boundaries, reducing the city's black majority to a minority.

WHITEWATER, Wis., Jan. 31 -- Encouraged by his second place showing in the Democratic precinct election in Arizona on Saturday, Mayor Lindsay of New York said today that he would enter similar contests in Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, Virginia and the state of Washington.
NEW DELHI, Jan. 31--The United Nations and the World Bank apparently are treating East Pakistan as a separate entity in defiance of the attitudes of the United States and Pakistan.

A Federal-state investigation into the possibility of fraud arising from the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes was announced here yesterday as a Federal grand jury began taking testimony in the case.

The hijacker of a Los Angeles-to-New York jetliner who was shot and captured at Kennedy International Airport on Saturday admitted his guilt in an outburst at his arraignment yesterday and was subsequently remanded to Bellevue Hospital for 30 days of psychiatric evalutation.

There is virtually no product or service that a prospective customer does not know the price of -- or get a reasonable estimate for -- prior to purchase. The only notable exception is a commodity that tens of millions of people purchase -- prescription drugs. In most cases, the customer does not even know the price of the item until he has placed the order and has the bottle or vial in his hands.
Television spots have just started to run for the first national fund-raising drive of the 28-year-old National Council on Alcoholism.

PNOMPENH, Jan. 31 (AP) -Diplomatic sources here report that the Cambodians are prepared to accept an agreement whereby the North Vietnamese and the Vietcong withdraw to sparsely populated provinces east of the Mekong River and to an area north of rubber plantations along Route 7 that is almost due east of here.
A Hempstead, L. I., village ordinance that restricted the performance of legal abortions to hospitals was overturned by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Superior court Judge Morris Pashman testified today that he had promised an accused hijacker-extortionist a light sentence for his part in an undercover investigation of then Bergen County Prosecutor Robert Dilts.

The American Broadcasting Company signed a $27-million two-year contract with the National Collegiate Athletic Association yesterday for the rights to televise regular-season N.C.A.A. football games in 1972 and 1973.

Like managers everywhere, the new men at the Department of Social Services talk of productivity, time studies, utilization rates and cost-benefit ratios. And they talk of the "bottom line," meaning the place on the balance sheet where you read the profit or loss.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The strong growth of the gross national product in the fourth quarter came without any help from the auto or steel industries, the Commerce Department reported today.

DEMAREST, N. J., Jan. 31 -- A dozen homeowners who live here in a heavily wooded crisscrossing of Duck Pond and Deerhill Roads have managed a rather neat way to cut their soaring property tax bills by more than 40 per cent.

MINGORA, Pakistan, Jan. 13 -- Pakistan's emerald mines, closed down two years ago by a blend of inefficiency, greed and bloodshed, are to begin operating again, and visions of green treasure are dancing in the heads of an impoverished and defeated people.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31 -A $450,000 weekend bank robbery, for which a left-wing extremist group is taking credit as "an expropriation for development of the revolutionary war," was the biggest robbery in Argentine history.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The Senate voted 59 to 16 today against excluding 10.1 million state and local government employes from Federal protection against job discrimination.
In advance of pro football's annual draft meeting, which begins today, trades continued yesterday with the San Diego Chargers making three.
DUBLIN Jan. 31 -- The Republic of Ireland today declared itself "fully satisfied that there was an unprovoked attack by British troops on unarmed civilians in Derry yesterday."

A team of professional safe-crackers managed to bypass a burglar alarm in a wholesale jeweler's safe Sunday morning and make off with diamonds, gold and platinum valued at $200,000, the police reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Pentagon sources report that the Soviet Union has started to send Cuba bigger and more heavily armed missile-firing patrol boats.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Sgt. Maj. William O. Wooldridge, once the Army's top enlisted man now under Federal indictment on charges of conspiring to defraud enlisted men's clubs in Vietnam, will retire tomorrow with full pension and benefits, the Army announced today.
Bowie Kuhn, commissioner of baseball, told Pete Rozelle, commissioner of pro football, yesterday to quit "kidding the people" about football being the nation's No. 1 sport.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 31 -- Stunned by the killing of 13 persons in yesterday's civil-rights demonstration in Londonderry, Northern Ireland was torn today by protests, bombings and terror.

The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it planned to close its Newark, Del., assembly plant for 10 days, beginning Feb. 7, "in order to balance production with inventory." The plant, which employs 4,900, was also closed for a week in January for another inventory alignment.

After two cancellations and postponements, E. Y. (Yip) Harburg finally got his show on Sunday night at the 92d Street Y's Kaufmann Concert Hall. Mr. Harburg appeared in the Y's series of evenings with wellknown lyricists.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -President Nixon postponed today for an additional 90 days the long-delayed start of a reduction in the tariff on window glass.

New Yorkers who have used up 39 weeks of unemployment insurance benefits became eligible yesterday for 13 more weeks of emergency federallyfinanced benefits under a new law that is in effect until June 30.

At last weekend three dance companies pulled up anchor and passed out of New York -- the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater, the Murray Louis Dance Company, which had both been giving a most interesting joint season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and American Ballet Theater, which ended its run at the New York City Center.

In an unusual ruling, a trial examiner of the National Labor Relations Board has ordered a local union that he found guilty of collusion with a Long Island employer to reimburse a competing union for its organizing expenses and attorney's fees in battling the "sweetheart" arrangement.

Mayor Lindsay proposed a $1.8-billion capital budget yesterday in which education, transportation and environmental protection would receive a total of 71 cents of every construction dollar in the next fiscal year.

WOODBURY, L. I., Jan, 31 -- A boycott of French wines, liquors and brandies in an attempt to have the French Government deal more forcefully with the heroin problem was started today by the owners of many of the top restaurants in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens counties.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- The British Government, facing a new wave of public emotion over the Irish question, today ordered an independent inquiry into yesterday's Londonderry killings.
An ambitious plan to televise 20 Canadian Football League games nationally on Wednesday nights live and in color was announced here yesterday.

Strong profit performances in domestic and foreign business combined with increases in all company areas to enable the Dow Chemical Company to post record 1971 earnings. Sales surpassed $2-billion for the first time, it was reported yesterday.

People who lunch on hot dogs and orange juice may be eating nothing more than "a sausage of fat, corn syrup and lots of chemicals and washing it down with a beverage of water, more chemicals and a little fruit juice," the city's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs, Bess Myerson, said yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered yesterday their third consecutive advance.

I read with some interest the proposal that Phase Two wage controls be followed by Phase Three, eagerly put forth on the Op-Ed page, Jan. 13, by Virgil Day, a vice president of General Electric and a member of the Phase Two Pay Board.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Jan. 31 -- After nearly a week of talks with field commanders, Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today that there was every indication that the North Vietnamese were pre paring for a major offensive in South Vietnam soon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 1 (AP) -- American fighter-bombers attacked surface-to-air missile sites, antiaircraft-artillery batteries and radar defenses inside North Vietnam yesterday in the heaviest air action over the north this year, the United States command announced today.

LONDON, Jan. 31 -- To the accompaniment of beeps, buzzes, pings, clicks and whirs, 81 American manufacturers of computerized graphics and design equipment today opened a week-long show designed to pry open the British market to their sophisticated wares.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31 -- Richard N. Cooper, a 37-year-old international - trade specialist who tutored Henry Kissinger in economics and who rides a red motor scooter to and from his office, will become the provost of Yale University July 1.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31 -- An outbreak of staphylococcal infections among newborn infants who had not been bathed with hexachlorophene has forced pediatricians to close one of three nurseries at the Yale-New Haven Hospital.

DACCA, Pakistan, Jan. 31 -As shooting between Bengalis and non-Bengalis continued for a third day in Dacca, the Prime Minister, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, offered forgiveness today to the non-Bengalis, many of whom had collaborated with the Pakistan Army, but threatened force if they did not surrender their arms immediately.
Cowles Communications is still trying to do right by the 6 million subscribers to Look.

Unhappily absent from the repertory for the better part of this season because of injury, Ted Kivitt returned during American Ballet Theater's last six performances to give a special lift to each of the works in which he appeared.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Two New York City Democratic lawmak. J ers introduced a bill today creating a "tenants bill of rights that fosters the formation of tenant organizations and re[quires landlords to participate in collective bargaining with tenants' groups.
Bhaskar and Shala, whose performances of dances from India are well-known in New York, presented a concert Saturday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall with another dancer, Sukanya, as guest artist.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- It is now obvious that the North Vietnamese are not going to get a peace settlement unless they make allowances for the ancient American concept of "face."

To the steadily growing list of endorsements he has attracted from Democratic leaders around the country, Senator Muskie of Maine has now added victories in the Presidential preference contests among Arizona and Iowa Democrats. The Gallup Poll shows him running neck and neck with President Nixon in national popularity nine months before Election Day.

The Phoenix Theater, the non-profit organization that has presented 132 productions since it was founded in 1953, has recruited a troika of artistic directors to lead it in a new theatrical direction next season, its 20th.
For the first time in a number of weeks plywood futures were traded briskly yesterday in the New York Mercantile Exchange, with a total of 2,266 trades made.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The Office of Economic Opportunity pronounced a reluctant but blunt judgment of failure today on performance contracting -- the use in public schools of private concerns, teaching machines and incentive payments in an effort to conquer slow learning by poor children.

WASHINGTON -- Congress does not want for work or problems, but more of both are headed that way unless Congress recognizes that the machinery for grappling with transportation disputes is rickety stuff that no longer works.

OUR LADY OF GEROWVAL MONASTERY, Miss., Jan. 25 -- The men who drill for oil have left their derricks and gangling slow-motion pumps in some strange places over the years, from school playgrounds to the back yards of houses to the floor of the ocean.

BOSTON, Jan. 31 -- With a group of blind persons listening and feeling in astonishment, engineers from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology demonstrated today a new computer system that translates English into Braille almost instantaneously.

Special Master Arthur H. Schwartz, in a 61-page report filed here yesterday with the Federal District Court, found that Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., owes $12,062,416 to a group of former stockholders of the General Outdoor Advertising Company.
Higher state taxes on cigarettes, liquor and gasoline take effect today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -Stagehands at the Kennedy Center are making as much as $1,500 a week under a union contract -- apparently the richest in the American theater -that has become the management's biggest embarrassment and headache.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Jan. 31 -- China and the Soviet Union staked out positions firmly behind the most militant African delegates at the United Nations Security Council meeting here today, as the lines began to be drawn for the several remaining days of debate.

TRIESTE, Italy, Jan. 16 -- The camp high in the hills above this Italian border city is only half full these days, but that is because it's winter. "Next summer it will probably be full again," the portly director says. "It is full every summer."
Harry Van Arsdale vowed yesterday to enlist the member unions of the Central Labor Council, which he heads, to defeat legislation that would license nonmedallion taxicabs.
Manhattan College has its first 7-foot basketball player, a transfer student from Dayton.

Beethoven did not compose his sonatas for piano and violin with Philharmonic Hall in mind. Granted that, what are the options available to any duo playing them in such a roomy place, with its ambiance of remoteness and acoustical factors so weighted against the chamber-music ideal?

The single sentence Fred Hechinger's Jan. 16 Week in Review article devoted to the Amish reason for resisting compulsory high school implies that nothing more is at stake for them than their rejection of luxuries. In point of fact, it is the entire religious social fabric of their community which is threatened.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 21 -The talk is still of war in the Syrian capital but the tone is more resigned than aggressive and there is a new accent on peacetime needs.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Nixon Administration took note today of North Vietnam's decision to make public its own nine-point peace plan, but declined any specific comment.

SAPPORO, Japan, Jan. 31 (Reuters) -- Austrian officials will decide whether to withdraw their team from the Winter Olympics here in protest against the expulsion of their skiing ace, Karl Schranz, after an appeal tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -Senior American analysts said today that China had started to deploy intermediate-range ballistic missiles with greater range than on an earlier nuclear rocket and with a much improved propellant system.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- North Vietnam made public today the nine-point peace program it had secretly submitted to the United States last June and charged that Washington had not seriously considered it.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that, effective today, its domestic lead price would rise to 14.5 cents a pound from 14 cents. The company said the increase would fall within the Nixon wage-price guidelines.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced yesterday the election of Gerhard R. Andlinger as chairman and chief executive officer of ITT Levitt Sons, Inc., and Levitt Sons, Inc., both subsidiaries of I.T.T.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Jan. 31 -- District Attorney Peter Veleff of Zurich Canton said tonight that the Swiss police had issued warrants for the arrest of Clifford Irving, the writer, and his wife in the dispute over an alleged autobiography of Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 31 -- The Connecticut Liquor Control Commission announced today that it had voted to revoke the liquor license of Mory's, the famed alehouse refuge of Yale men for 110 years, on the ground that it discriminated against women.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -The Food and Drug Administration proposed today strict limitations on the use of antibiotics in livestock feed, describing such feed as a potential health hazard.

On the second day of the first semester, the incoming class at the Drama Division of the Juilliard School -- fresh, eager and hopeful about its future in the American theater -- is thrown into "King Lear," or another Shakespearean masterpiece.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Jan. 31 -After 17 of her supporters were arrested by the police during a protest, attorneys for Angela Davis tried again today to have her trial shifted to another county.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Following is a comparison of the nine-point peace proposal made public by the North Vietnamese delegation in Paris today and the eight-point plan of the Governments of the United States and South Vietnam revealed by President Nixon on Jan. 25:

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- The Government of Premier Lon Nol has reportedly approached North Vietnam through the Soviet Embassy here, seeking negotiations in the hope of ending the fighting in Cambodia.

Ronald R. Evans, one of the first black teachers appointed as a principal directly from the classroom four years ago, as a result of community pressure, is taking a one-year leave of absence, starting today.
Earnings of Owens-Illinois, Inc., for the quarter and year ended December, 1971, declined despite higher sales, it was reported yesterday.

Less than a fortnight ago the voting members of the Baseball Writers Association looked with smug satisfaction on their most recent election to the Hall of Fame. They had hit the jackpot with three eminently worthy candidates--Sandy Koufax, Yogi Berra and Early Wynn. It had been ages since they made such nifty nominations and they were pleased that they had reached such a peak of selectivity.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- Prices farmers received for raw products rose 3 per cent in the month ended Jan. 15 and averaged 13 per cent more than a year earlier, the Agriculture Department announced today.
MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- The Soviet television network carried a one-hour documentary tonight showing China as a thoroughly regimentated state determined to stamp out the individuality of its citizens.

The first four Yankee contracts signed for 1972; the introduction of the team's newest players acquired in trades; the switching of Ron Blomberg from the outfield to first base, and a progress report on the city's planned acquisition and refurbishing of Yankee Stadium -- all these developments were the reason for the club's first news conference of the year yesterday at the Stadium press club.
A plan to bring rail freight service back to the Bush Terminal industrial-complex area of South Brooklyn was announced yesterday by the New York Dock Railway.

A group of demonstrators cut down the Union Jack flying in front of the British Consulate General at 845 Third Avenue yesterday and sought to burn it. They were protesting the killing of 13 civilians during a demonstration Sunday in Londonderry, Northern Ireland.

The one good thing to be said about America's deteriorating trade and payments position in 1971 was that it helped to shake the Administration out of the lethargy of its old game plan. Last year brought the United States its first foreign trade deficit since 1888, the year of the Great Blizzard. In 1971 the trade deficit was $2.047 billion and in 1888 a mere $37 million.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, Jan. 31 (UPI) -- Trinidad's colorful carnival, originally scheduled for Feb. 14-15 and considered one of the world's great Mardi Gras celebrations, was postponed today for at least three months because of a polio outbreak that has taken 10 lives.

DALLAS, Jan. 31 (AP) -Duane Thomas, the Dallas Cowboy running back charged with possession of marijuana, talked with the club president, Tex Schramm, by telephone today and Schramm said the conversation was "limited to the subject of him being properly represented."

In his discussion of the refusal of Amish parents to permit the schooling of their children beyond the eighth grade, Fred M. Hechinger omitted one aspect, to me the most important one, namely, the harm done to such children.

WHITE PLAINS, Jan. 31 -Westchester County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian, describing a county forced to near-austerity by state and Federal cutbacks, pledged today that his chief objective for the next year would be "to hold the line on expenses and to afford a measure of easing property taxes" for Westchester's 900,000 residents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -Nixon Administration officials said tonight that Daniel Schorr, the television commentator, was considered last year for the position of assistant to the chairman of the Council on Environmental Quality.
Leading stock-market averages moved lower yesterday as glamour issues were buffeted and many low-price issues showed gains.

In a confrontation that has aroused more speculation than any other game the Rangers have played this season, the New Yorkers tonight face the National Hockey League's top team, the Boston Brains at Madison Square Garden.

" WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The United States and Japan have reached an agreement limiting textile exports by the Japanese to this country for 21 months starting next Jan. 1, the State Department announced today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The State Department contended today that the President, as Commander in Chief, had constitutional authority to enter into agreements for foreign military bases without obtaining Congressional approval.

DUBLIN, June 16, 1904 -By lorries along sir John Rogerson's Quay Mr Bloom walked soberly, past Windmill Lane, Leask's the linseed crusher's, the postal telegraph office. He turned from the morning noises of the quayside and walked through Lime street.
The biggest guessing game in town is estimating how many shares, are in the Levitz Furniture Corporation's "float" -- shares actually available for trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

The Budget Director announced yesterday that city agencies and departments had made expense budget requests for 1972-73 that totaled $10.7-billion. The total was immediately assailed by City Council leaders, who warned that drastic cuts must be made.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1--President Nixon is now concentrating on his forthcoming visit to China--the great diplomatic experiment of his first term in office. He is working his way through a mountain of briefing papers, studying the transcripts of the Kissinger-Chou En-lai conversations, and quietly putting out the word not to expect too much from this month's spectacular journey.

The ten-nation United States of Europe that could evolve out of the accession to the Common Market treaty of Britain, Denmark, Norway and Ireland promises to alter profoundly the economic and political shape of the Atlantic community and the world. The American response is of critical importance.

The Federal Trade Commission announced yesterday that it has provisionally approved a consent order requiring the Lehigh Portland Cement Company to divest itself within four years of a number of readymix concrete plants it acquired in Virginia and Florida.

LONDON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- The price of gold soared by $1 an ounce in London and Zurich today, and set records on markets across Europe. The rush to buy gold helped send the value of the United States dollar down on foreign-exchange markets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -President Nixon had breakfast today with the Rev. Billy Graham, dinner with Republican Governors and in between found time to greet, salute and be photographed with astronauts, Boy Scouts, Nebraska football stars and Gov. Ronald Reagan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Porter International, an American consulting company, announced today that it had formed a joint venture with Tass, the official Soviet press agency, to issue a newsletter twice a month on Soviet economic developments.

After a bewildering series of maneuvers during the last few days, the New York Giants wound up yesterday with no Fred Dryer and no Fran Tarkenton but with Eldridge Small, a defensive back, and Larry Jacobson, a defensive end, as their two top draft choices.

JERUSALEM -- Nowadays Asia is the most warlike continent and has replaced Europe as the scene of great power competition to gain influence in the global balance. During recent years there have been successive miniwars in Yemen, along Arabia's Trucial coast, between the Kurds and Iraqis, among Pathan tribesmen, the Naga hill people and in Burma, where civil conflict is so common as to be the norm.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -Like an aggrieved citizen who thinks he has been overtaxed, the Internal Revenue Service has protested a bill of some $11-million from the United States Postal Service.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- One of the Administration's top economists told Congress today that it should not try to reduce next year's budget deficit significantly, not even by closing tax "loopholes."

BENHET, South Vietnam, Jan. 30 -- "I trust God," an American adviser to the South Vietnamese Rangers in this mountainous border outpost in the Central Highlands wrote in chalk in the bunker where he sleeps.
ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A special commission study recommended today that New York State change its Constitution and take over the multibillion-dollar field of illicit gambling.

The door that bars Broadway angels from participating in the process by which plays are made ready for the stage was opened a little -several millimeters at least -- for the backers of one show Monday evening.

Dr. Peter C. Goldmark, an electronics pioneer and former head of the Columbia Broadcasting System Laboratories, said yesterday that he would direct a Government-financed study of the imaginative uses of telecommunications in a 10town area of northeastern Connecticut.

A couple of years ago there was a magazine called Quest that was sent free to the upper-income homes that were on Metromedia's Metromail Elite list. Although the magazine was independent of Metromail, it went out of business when the list did.

In an attempt to replace George Sauer, who passed the game by, and Pete Lammons, whom the game has passed by, the Jets drafted Jerome Barkum yesterday and touched off a possible realignment of their receiving corps.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- Eight years ago a distinguished team of American judges and lawyers came to England to study the system of criminal law. Shortly after, an equally luminous English team returned the visit.

TORONTO, Feb. 1 -- Three major United States pipeline companies, hungry for future supplies of natural gas, have committed themselves to spend at least $30-million on exploratory drilling on Canada's Arctic islands.

For the last several weeks, Willowbrook State School has been getting prominent local, and even national, attention. With 5,300 patients, the Staten Island "school" is one of the largest institutions for the mentally retarded in the world.
BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 -- The European Economic Community declared tonight that it is prepared to open a new round of worldwide negotiations to liberalize international trade.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Feb. 1 -- Dr. Timothy Leary, who escaped from a California prison while serving a sentence on drug charges, has been ordered to leave the canton of Valais within a week, officials announced tonight.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- A modified "no fault" automobile accident insurance plan was announced today by Senator Bernard G. Gordon, who said the plan could save vehicle owners in the state about $300-million in premium payments during its first year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The contest between Senator George McGovern and Mayor Lindsay for the allegiance of the Democratic left -- and hopefully, for part of its center -is beginning to take on the acrimonious overtones of the 1968 race between Eugene J. McCarthy and Robert F. Kennedy.

SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 2 -Karl Schranz, the Austrian ski star who was disqualified from the Winter Olympic Games on charges of commercialism, was accused today by Avery Brundage, president of the International Olympic Committee, of being "disrespectful to the Olympic movement."
Patrolmen Gregory P. Foster and Rocco W. Laurie, who had been Marine Corps comrades in Vietnam, and who walked a beat together on the Lower East Side, were buried yesterday.
The tentative assessed value of the city's taxable real estate has jumped to a record $38.5-billion, an increase of $1.8-billion, Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -- New factory orders fell 0.4 per cent, or $235-million in December to a seasonally adjusted $59.3-billion, reversing November's downward revised 3.6 per cent gain, the Commerce Department reported today.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., Feb. 1 -- The presence of three doctors who have performed nearly 4,000 abortions since last March in an office they share here has stirred strong emotions in this old Hudson River village of 10,350 people.

He is a man whom some have regarded as hasty and heedless, but when the subject is baseball he does not go off at half cock. "That's not easy to answer," he said. He pondered a little longer.
Walt Patulski, yes. Ed Marinaro and Pat Sullivan, maybe.

Fashion and charity, an unbeatable daily double, came through again yesterday. More than 500 women, most of whom had already settled on a hemline length (the knee or just below) and a look (casual, conservative, uncluttered) jammed into the ballroom of the Plaza Hotel for the first major spring show in New York.

Thirteen inmates and three guards were reportedly slightly injured yesterday afternoon when prisoners in the Adolescent Remand Shelter on Rikers Island went on a 20minute furniture - smashing spree to protest dining conditions.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 1 -- A Paterson lawyer named as a key figure in the indictment of Robert Dilts, the suspended Bergen County Prosecutor on trial here, testified today that he had met secretly with Mr. Dilts to work out reduced sentences for three of the lawyer's convicted clients.

A Department of Transportation official disclosed yesterday that the Nixon Administration was taking a new look at the possibility of subsidizing day-to-day losses on the nation's mass-transit systems. It has consistently opposed such subsidies in the past.

Handwriting and palm-print analysis led yesterday to the arrest of a 17-year-old former Jewish Defense League activist and the clearing of a rabbinical student in connection with the firing of shots into the Soviet Mission here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -Organized crime in the nation's capital is on the rise, with narcotics, loan-sharking, gambling and hijacking under increasing control by the Mafia, according to a District of Columbia report to the Federal Government.

The chairman of the Board of Education's finance committee said yesterday that if the proposals of the special state education commission were enacted, residents here would pay more in higher taxes than the city would receive in additional school aid from the state.

PARIS, Feb. 1 (Reuters) -A new French Revolution began today -- one in merchandising -- as a new consumer protection law went into effect.

These two women, at the top of a profession generally dominated by men, have shown obdurate toughness in the world of politics and war.

In best "Perils of Pauline" fashion, welfare reform has once again been rescued from the Congressional barbecue pit. The imaginative plan proposed by President Nixon for a guaranteed Federal floor under family income had seemed dead after Senator Ribicoff of Connecticut walked away from it last week. But now the Senator and the Administration are back together in support of a plan that keeps alive all the essential elements of the original proposal.

Labeling the present method of selecting judges an "obsenity," a "farce" and a "charade," eight of the city's most prominent lawyers joined with a Republican legislator yesterday to demand a new system under which all judges sitting in New York City would be appointed rather than elected.
The five-day advance on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market ended yesterday as both lists declined in continued active trading.
James P. Gallatin has been elected senior vice president, Hugh A. Egan, vice president and controller, and David A. Plum, auditor, of the Fiduciary Trust Company of New York.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3 -- Selections taken from what was described as "The Autobiography of Howard Hughes" indicate that these excerpts could have come from previously published anecdotes about the reclusive industrialist, without any special inside information.

The Kraftco Corporation, the world's largest processor and distributor of packaged foods and leading dairy products maker, realized the highest annual sales and earnings in its history in 1971, with record fourth-quarter results, Gordon Edwards, chairman and chief executive, reported yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The Vietcong presented at the peace talks here today a revised version of their seven-point peace plan of last July that appeared more conciliatory to the present South Vietnamese Government.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- France and Israel were reported by reliable diplomatic sources today to be near an agreement under which Israel would be reimbursed for 50 Mirage fighter planes bought in France but never delivered.

Perhaps you recall the original version of Neil Sheehan's remarkable story of Lieut. Comdr. Marcus Aurelius Arnheiter as it appeared in The New York Times Sunday Magazine on Aug. 11, 1968. I certainly recalled it as I began to read "The Arnheiter Affair," Mr. Sheehan's book-length account of the commander's strange career, and I wondered seriously how the original version could possibly be improved upon.
The Boy Scouts of America is celebrating its 62d birthday this month amid plans to become more relevant and responsive to its 4.5 million young members and prospective members.

Savings and loan associations and mutual savings bank interests throughout the United States remained divided yesterday in their reaction to a decision by the Federal Home Loan Bank Board permitting a West Coast savings and loan association to convert to a stock corporation.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- Prospects for a volunteer army by the summer of 1973, when the draft is expected to end, are improving steadily, according to Lieut. Gen. George I. Forsythe.

A driving rainstorm with heavy winds swept through the metropolitan area last night, flooding some low-lying areas and imperiling motorists. The temperature rose to a high of 53 degrees but began falling around midnight to the more frigid levels that had been predicted for today.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 3 -- Roman Catholic civil-rights leaders today scheduled a big march for Sunday, a week after 13 Catholic men were killed by British soldiers at a protest in Londonderry.

Chuck Mangione is a fair-to-middlin' jazz trumpeter and a competent arranger-composer. Tuesday night he performed at Carnegie Hall with 60-odd musicians, many of them from the Eastman School of Music.

Very properly there were cheers, boos, and coughs for Jerome Robbins's new ballet "Watermill," which was given its world premiere by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater last night.

Charging that "buyers of prescription drugs in New York City get less pricing information than buyers of soap flakes," Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson yesterday held a one-day hearing on whether pharmacies should be required to display prices of the most commonly prescribed drugs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senate Republicans voted today to relieve their incapacitated colleague, Karl E. Mundt of South Dakota, of three important committee assignments, thus opening up opportunities for a younger generation of Republican Senators.

DUBLIN, Feb, 3 -- Prime Minister John Lynch, speaking to an emergency session of Parliament, today condemned the men who burned the British Embassy yesterday as "a small minority who under the cloak of patriotism seek to overthrow the institutions of this state."

Major institutional investors began preparing yesterday to join the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of the Securities and Exchange Commission's newly adopted position in favor of a limited form of institutional membership.

A new and powerful position -- special assistant district attorney for New York City -- was established yesterday. For the first time, one man was given citywide jurisdiction over all major narcotics cases, including the right to empanel grand juries and initiate investigations anywhere in the five boroughs.

In the Musica Aeterna concert at Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the Canadian contralto sang Harry Somers's Five Songs for Dark Voice so eloquently that one was prepared at the end of them to think they might be great works of lyric art.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 3 -- The refusal by the Long Island Rail Road to accept its 10-trip tickets for a year beyond the original purchase date, as stipulated on the ticket, was challenged in State Supreme Court here today.

Richard Brickner's second novel is about that side of artistic endeavor that America knows how to do best: build buildings. It doesn't always build the best buildings, but it builds the faster and in greater clusters. If we can put up the house, the theory runs, we'll find something to house -- a theater repertory company, an opera company, a movie archive, old airplanes, something.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- Inmates at all of the state's major correctional facilities will soon be able to confer with prison officials on ways of improving conditions at the institutions and on ways of improving custodial, house-keeping and treatment programs, the state's Corrections Commissioner announced today.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Boston scored two goals in the first minute and 44 seconds tonight and went on to defeat the Minnesota North Stars, 6-1, as the Bruins' Ed Johnston tied a National Hockey League record for assists by a goalie in a season.

John L. Jenkins, director of the Government's Office of Minority Business Enterprise said yesterday that "despite the dissipation of overt discrimination, minority companies have been unable to make significant inroads into the enormous inter-corporate marketplace."

William J. vanden Heuvel, chairman of the city's Board of Correction, made public yesterday a list of 14 reforms in the city's prisons that he said the advisory board hoped could be implemented within a year -- including the establishment of prison councils with inmate representatives.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson's strategists, fearing that his chances in the pivotal Florida primary have been sharply curtailed by the candidacy of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama, are renewing their effort to push forward the date of the Tennessee primary.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers told Ireland today that the United States was "not in a position to intervene" in the crisis in Northern Ireland.
DETROIT, Feb. 3 -- January's new-car sales rose 4 per cent to 609,406 United States-type autos from 585,644 a year before.

The Reynolds Metals Company announced new price schedules yesterday that the large producer said were aimed at increasing selling prices of a dozen aluminum commodity lines. The changes were being made, the company said, to bring list prices more in line with market conditions.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A hearing examiner for the Postal Rate Commission recommended a 2-cent increase in airmail rates today but said that most other mail rates should remain unchanged.

ALBANY, Feb. 3 -- The chancellor of the State University said today that a critical situation had developed in the university's libraries because state budget economies had forced a drop of more than 40 per cent in the acquisition of new volumes.
On Dec. 24, the owner of an East Side TV repair shop was shot in the head, killed, dragged to the back of the store, then his cash register was rifled and the killers escaped in broad daylight.
BUFFALO, Feb. 3 -- There was a sign hanging from the balcony in Memorial Stadium tonight that read: "Win Sabres, Try it. You'll like it."

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 3 -- While almost everyone in the ski country has been wondering whether winter has come and gone, owners of the Powder Ridge Ski Center in the central precincts of the Nutmeg State have been wondering whether a $125,000 investment will continue collecting rust.

Senator Jacob K. Javits accused Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay yesterday of letting their political feud permeate state-city dealings and said they should merge their competing investigation commissions.

Andre Previn is no longer a wunderkind, which is not necessarily a misfortune. It seems to have been that fearsome wit Leopold Godowsky who first pointed out that in the case of the average wonder-child, the wonder disappears with age and the child remains.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 1 -- Minnesota Metropolitan State College opened here today with no campus, no classes, no semesters, no classrooms, no grades, no required courses, no library, no student organizations, no tenured faculty and no teen-age students.
BOSTON, Feb. 3 -- The city of Boston got two visitors from the South today: the heaviest snowstorm of the year and John Vliet Lindsay, a Presidential candidate from New York.

NEWARK -- "I love this city," said Ron Porambo, surveying the little bars and boarded-up houses in the heart of Newark's battered and heavily black Central Ward. "I love these people."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- Military spokesmen said today that South Vietnamese troops clashed with guerrillas in four sharp battles yesterday in a sudden outbreak of fighting in the U Minh Forest, a long-time enemy base area at the southern tip of the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The House Ways and Means Committee decided today to approve only a temporary increase in the statutory debt ceiling and to make the increase much smaller than the Administration wanted.

A number of prominent black political figures who had previously sought to name a black male for the Democratic Presidential nomination have agreed to support the candidacy of Representative Shirley Chisholm of Brooklyn.
The 72-year-old owner of a wholesale barber supply concern on a busy street in downtown Brooklyn was found shot to death yesterday inside the shop he had operated for some 40 years.

A green suitcase containing almost a million dollars in cash was seized by narcotics agents when they arrested two men who were charged here yesterday with a conspiracy to distribute heroin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A Government study showed today that the United States Air Force was airlifting to Pakistan on a priority basis more than half a million dollars' worth of aviation spare parts in July, after Government spokesmen had assured Congress that arms shipments had been stopped.
TORONTO, Feb. 4 -- Marty Liquori came up short in the stretch tonight, just as he thought he might.

NEWARK, Feb. 4 (AP) -A controversial state law requiring policemen and firemen to live in the towns where they work was upheld today by a three-judge Federal appeals court.

LONDON -- Environmentalists in growing numbers on both sides of the Atlantic are calling for a total reexamination of the world drive for economic development. It is ecologically insane and morally irresponsible, the argument goes, to encourage every country upon paths of exponential economic growth when finite limits such as climate change, due to energy use and resource depletion, are beginning to loom. Is this doomish view all fantasy?
Paul Kletzki will not conduct the Cleveland Orchestra in its Feb. 16-17 concerts in Carnegie Hall as scheduled, because of illness.

HOUSTON, Feb. 4 -- When men's apparel merchants get together, the talk usually turns to mutual problems. This year's convention of the Menswear Retailers of America has been no exception.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 4 -Followers of Herve Filion, the French-Canadian harness driving ace who accounted for 543 winners and earnings of $1,915,545 in 1971, had little to cheer about in his debut tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 4 -President Kenneth D. Kaunda banned one of Zambia's two Opposition parties today, arrested its leader, former Vice President Simon M. Kapwepwe, and ordered the arrest of 133 other leaders of Mr. Kapwepwe's United Progressive party.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Democratic Presidential aspirants clashed with Republicans and one another today over Senator Edmund S. Muskie's criticism of President Nixon's eight-point peace proposal for Vietnam.

The second of the three new Merce Cunningham dances that Mr. Cunningham is presenting during his current season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music made its bow on Wednesday night. Called "TV Rerun," in its style it appears to be something of a spin-off from aspects of the highly impressive "Landrover," the major work that started off this present Cunningham season.

In recent months, the question of offshore oil drilling leases has received increasing public attention, particularly on the East Coast. This has resulted from conflicting reports emanating from the Interior Department and deep public concern for preventing a recurrence of disasters such as that at Santa Barbara.

Reform Democrats in the Bronx, looking to the June primaries, began a campaign yesterday with the announcement that Judge Lawrence H. Bernstein would be a candidate for nomination to the Surrogate Court in the Bronx.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Prime Minister Heath and the Northern Ireland Prime Minister, Brian Faulkner, issued a lastminute appeal tonight for cancellation of the planned civilrights march in Newry.

The stock market, buoyed by some good news from Europe, moved higher yesterday across a fairly broad front. Low-price issues continued their week-long gain, although volume slackened on the New York Stock Exchange. Select glamour stocks moved steadily ahead.

BOSTON, Feb. 4 -- Hector Berlioz regarded his opera "The Trojans," as his masterpiece, and he could have said of it, as was later said of Debussy's "Pelleas et Melisande," that he did not compose it to be successful.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 4 -- Pennsylvania cashed in on eight of its first 11 field-goal attempts to build up a 16-2 advantage and then coasted to an 84-60 Ivy League victory over Harvard tonight. The Quakers now share the Ivy lead with Brown.
Twenty-six guards at city welfare centers and hospitals were suspended from their jobs yesterday for allegedly purchasing and possessing handguns.

The S. S. Kresge Company has elected Robert H. Griffin executive vice president for store management. The former vice president for K Mart operations succeeds Fred K. Nieman, who retires on March 1 after 44 years of service.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -Under plans announced today, Independence Hall will lose the Liberty Bell it has sheltered for more than two centuries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations accused President Nixon today of trying -- with some success -- to get Congress to approve "narrow, conservative concerns of big business" rather than social legislation to benefit most Americans.
HOUSTON, Feb. 4 -- Sam Karoll, who will take over tomorrow night as president of the Menswear Retailers of America at its annual convention here, has a clearly defined task in mind for the next year.

DUBLIN, Feb. 4 (Reuters) -A British soldier said here today that he had deserted his Northern Ireland-based parachute unit because its troops were ordered to shoot to kill before the Londonderry Sunday march when 13 civilians were shot to death.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 4 -- Negotiators for the United States and the Common Market reached a provisional agreement today on trade, breaking a deadlock that had threatened to cause serious deterioration in Atlantic relations and renewal of currency uncertainties.

DUBLIN, Feb. 4 -- Prime Minister John Lynch appealed to supporters of the Northern Ireland civil-rights movement today not to join in the demonstration scheduled by the movement Sunday in the Ulster border town of Newry.

HONOLULU, Feb. 4 -- Bob Murphy found golf "mentally tiring" in the weird streak of weather that struck the players in the $200,000 Hawaiian open tournament today. Nevertheless he finished with a 70 for a 36-hole aggregate of 135 to lead Fred Marti by one stroke.

The Treasury, announcing the results of its $4.5-billion refinancing operation conducted earlier this week, disclosed yesterday that 68 per cent of the publicly held Government bonds coming due Feb. 15 were exchanged for new issues and 32 per cent will be retired for cash.

NEWRY, Northern Ireland, Feb. 4 -- British troops, in one of the biggest operations they have ever mounted in Northern Ireland, today sealed off all approaches to the border town of Newry, where a civil-rights march is planned for Sunday.

DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 4--Britain and nine other Western countries recognized Bangladesh today. And this country, formerly East Pakistan, announced that it was seeking membership in the Commonwealth, a loose community of former British territories.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The chairman of the House Banking Committee announced today that the Administration would send Congress next week the legislation raising the official price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce. He said hearings would begin Feb. 29.
The Horn Hardart Company, operators of the Automats and other retail food establishments, will show a loss for the fiscal year ended Dec. 25, 1971, of about $4-million, it was announced yesterday.

The American Zinc Company announced yesterday it has agreed in principle to acquire for approximately $11-million the drilling equipment division of Westinghouse Air Brake Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of American Standard, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) An organization of scientists, social scientists and engineers expressed new opposition today to United States air raids on North Vietnam.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- A year ago today, Rolls-Royce, Ltd., one of the principal props of British industrial prestige, went bankrupt in a collapse that shook the entire economy and the Conservative Government.

For a couple of decades now, Louisa Matthiasdottir has been one of the steadiest and most dedicated painters on the New York scene. Nothing about her art is flamboyant or unconventional. WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today it had suspended two persons from association with any broker or dealers on grounds of violating Federal securities laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -While President Nixon was in Florida preparing for his trip to China, Secretary of State William P. Rogers called in Ambassador Anatoly F. Dobrynin today to begin discussion of the agenda for Mr. Nixon's visit to Moscow in May.

President Bhutto's decision to take Pakistan out of the Commonwealth in anticipation of Britain's recognition of Bangladesh yesterday was largely symbolic, designed to appease those Pakistanis who still have not accepted the loss of their eastern province.

A union of unskilled and semiskilled factory workers began a series of strikes here yesterday in a confrontation between a section of organized labor and Congress, on the one hand, and the Cost of Living Council on the other.

DES MOINES, Iowa, -Lester Kavan, an Internal Revenue agent, was having a somewhat uneven time of it.

The Topper Corporation, a financially troubled toy manufacturer, announced yesterday it had reached preliminary agreement with its secured lenders and that it expected its 1971 loss would wipe out its net worth, which was estimated at between $16-million and $17-million as of Sept. 30.

HOUSTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored 41 points to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 119-112 National Basketball Association victory over the Houston Rockets tonight The start of the game was delayed 30 minutes because of a late arrival by the Rockets.

Va.

SAN FRANCISCO -- Guards are posted on the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge these days to look for motorists riding with dummy human beings beside them. Since Dec. 8, autos carrying three or more people have been able to cross the bridge free during morning rush hours -- and a few drivers have tried to evade the 50-cent toll by carrying dummies as passengers.

ON a humid North African night last summer a tall young man in Arab robes, his face half-hidden behind a swath of cloth, presented himself at Tripoli's teeming Central Hospital in a state of great vexation and demanded to see a doctor. The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace announced yesterday that it would help finance and supply offices and facilities for Foreign Policy magazine, the year-old quarterly journal of opinion on foreign affairs.

LONDON -- At 8 A.M. each weekday six buses move through London to pick up students waiting to attend the American School.
