WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Nixon signed into law today the first important reform in nearly half a century in the controversial process of financing election to Federal office.

" 1922: A Vintage Year," an exhibition of manuscripts, letters, drawings, photographs and first editions from the Berg Collection of English and American Literature, will go on display tomorrow in Room 318 of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu, who agreed to the American peace proposal that includes an offer of his resignation in the expectation that the Communists would never accept it on his terms, is apparently worried that the United States may be taking the offer more seriously.
Six men pleaded guilty in Queens Supreme Court yesterday to charges of inciting to riot during the disturbances at the Long Island City House of Detention in Queens in October, 1970.

Some artists are their own best creations and sweetest memorials, especially perhaps those roaring boys with self-destruction in their very fingernails who became dying legends in their own death-time.
LONDON, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Britain will follow up her change-over to a decimal monetary system by switching to a metric system of weights and measurements in 1975, the Government announced today.
GENEVA, Feb. 7 -- The Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies are boycotting a United Nations meeting on air pollution here because East Germany was not invited to participate.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 (AP) -- President Nixon and President Alejandro A. Lanusse of Argentina had a 21-minute telephone conversation today. China was the main topic.
The formation of the first prisoners' union in the country -- by inmates of Green Haven Prison at Stormville, N.Y. -- was announced here yesterday.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 7 (AP) -- Chris Evert, the sensational teen-age tennis star, trounced Mrs. Billie Jean King, the National Open champion, 6-1, 6-0, today in their first meeting since their famed 1971 showdown at Forest Hills.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb, 7 -- The Nassau County Commission on Human Rights criticized today what it called "the almost tacit approval of prejudice, discrimination and quasi-segregation by county government, regardless of party leadership."

The Department of the Interior did the world a service last week in proposing to add to its list of endangered animals all the great spotted cats not already included. Unless the Department reverses itself after a thirty-day waiting period, during which opponents may be heard, the ruling will go far to save the earth's remaining tigers, leopards, cheetahs and jaguars, among other seriously declining species.

Floyd Patterson, former heavyweight champion, and Oscar Bonavena of Argentina reported to Madison Square Garden yesterday for their pre-fight physical, a requirement for their scheduled bout Friday night in the Garden.

There was a time, not so long ago, when Solitron Devices, Inc., was a force to be reckoned with. The Amphenol Corporation's management cringed when Solitron, a high-flying maker of semi-conductor products, picked up a massive block of the less-glamorous Chicago company's shares with the object a shotgun wedding.
Herbert W. Beyea, chairman of the Hearst Advertising Service and a director of the Hearst Corporation, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 530 East 72d Street.
A new plan for handling narcotics cases went into effect in the city yesterday. It ran smoothly for the most part with little discernible change in the way these cases had been handled previously.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The office of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. made public today parts of what it said was a report of the Senate securities subcommittee which he heads. Republican members of the subcommittee challenged the authenticity of the report which they said was a mere staff study that they had not had time to review.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court yesterday barring further sales of apartments in Cadman Towers, a Mitchell-Lama project now under construction in Brooklyn Heights.

JANESVILLE, Wis. -- While concern has mounted in the last decade over the plight of the inner cities in vast metropolitan areas, the aging downtowns of hundreds of smaller cities have been quietly deteriorating with little national notice.

MOSCOW, Feb. 7 -- Soviet authorities, who take the official view that unemployment does not exist in this country, report that a relatively new network of employment bureaus is successfully reducing the time it takes workers to find new jobs.

These days when Henry A. Kissinger, Vietnam, Democratic Presidential candidates and l'affaire Howard Hughes dominate television newscasts, a group of viewers in northern Manhattan is being served a very different video menu.

Charles Chaplin, the master comic artist of the silent screen, has agreed to begin his first trip to the United States in 20 years with a four-day stay in New York City, during which he will be grandly feted.
Stock prices retreated yesterday, with numerous glamour issues sharing in the weakness, as volume also fell on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Presdent Nixon tonight asked the nation's businessmen not to complain about wage and price controls but instead to adopt policies that would remove the need for such controls.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Eugene Paul Wigner, 69 years old, of Princeton University, one of the scientists who helped start the American project to build the atomic bomb, was named today the winner of the Albert Einstein Award for outstanding contributions to the physical sciences.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Premier Lon Nol says Cambodian soldiers who shot at a mythical monster that was believed to be devouring the moon during a recent eclipse wasted so much ammunition the army might have run short in case of attack.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished slightly lower yesterday in active trading.

In his Jan. 14 column, "Real-politik in Sports," C. L. Sulzberger suggests that we review the role of athletics in the Western world and make use of it as part of the political muscle of a country in order to enhance its image in the world community.

The long-controversial Subversive Activities Control Board has been working since July, 1970, to prove as a "Communist front" an organization whose chairman said yesterday that he had formally told the board 14 months ago that "we move in concert with the Communist party."

BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 7 -- The top leadership of the Communications Workers of America, claiming a victory in principle, today recommended acceptance of proposed terms for settling the nearly seven-month-old strike of telephone craftsmen in New York.

MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., Tuesday, Feb. 8 -- The Madison Township Education Association, which represents teachers who have been on a two-week strike here, said early this morning that the walkout would end and that teachers would be back in their classrooms today.

The Teleprompter Corporation -- which settled its proxy fight with Jack Kent Cooke, a California sports promoter, last December -- announced yesterday the election of Raymond P. Shafer as chairman and chief executive officer.

S. J. Salmon Co., a brokerage house specializing in new issues, was placed in the hands of a court-appointed trustee yesterday and will be liquidated under the supervision of the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.

TORONTO, Feb. 7 -- Dropping the other shoe, the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., disclosed today that its sales skidded by 31 per cent in the fourth quarter of 1971 and profits plunged by 84 per cent to 11 cents a share.
Duquesne, which has one of the East's best basketball records, lost its leading substitute, Dave Roddy, yesterday when he was declared ineligible by the Eastern College Athletic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Nixon's chief economic adviser told Congress today that the Administration "has initiated the strongest program to reduce unemployment that there has ever been in this country."

Marianne Moore was a natural, in her life style, in her art. She simply went and did what a lot of women today merely argue about. She taught in an Indian school, established her own fashion in clothes and was a fierce Dodger fan, knowing the score and the scoreboard better than most customers. She was as far from the popular conception of a woman poet, a clinging diaphanous presence, as anyone could be.

Lighthouse, a Canadian rock group, made its return to Carnegie Hall Sunday night a happy occasion. Two years ago, the group was introduced at a free Carnegie promotional concert that was a musical (and nearly a career) disaster.

Senator Mark O. Hatfield visited the Soviet Union as a member of the U.S. Delegation to the Sixth Dartmouth Conference, held in Kiev. The Senate's Committee on Foreign Relations has published a report on the conference by Senator Frank Church, another member of the delegation, with an interesting appendix in which Senator Hatfield gives his impressions of the Soviet Union.
A group of Long Island Rail Road commuters has asked the Federal Price Commission to roll back the line's recently imposed 16.67 per cent fare increase, saying the rise will add to air pollution.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The typical French movie these days is shot outside of the studio, in color and at a cost of less than $200,000, according to statistics released by the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A new and potentially significant element has suddenly been injected into the early weeks of the competition for the Democratic Presidential nomination by Georgia's decision to elect most of its delegates to the Democratic National Convention on March 11.
PARIS, Feb. 7 -- The Opera Comique, Paris's second opera house, is to be made into a graduate school of operatic art, it has been announced by the Ministry of Culture.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 7 (AP) -- North Vietnamese troops reportedly overran a Government outpost in southern Laos early today as part of a drive to protect the western flank of their supply-trail network.
ZURICH, Feb. 7 -- A "contradictory" monetary policy in the United States is creating international monetary uncertainty, central banking officials charged here today.

SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 7 -- Janet Lynn came on the ice late in the free-skating program. She was in fourth place after two days of the compulsory figures, hopelessly behind the world champion Beatrix Schuba of Austria, and a long way back of Julie Lynn Holmes, the American brunette, and Karen Mangussen of Canada, the North American champion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Nixon signed into law today a much-delayed foreign aid authorization bill, but he protested that it cut the foreign assistance program too deeply and imposed too many legislative restrictions on the executive branch.

The Theater Development Fund, which was founded in 1967 to encourage the production of worthwhile plays in the commercial theater, has evolved unexpectedly into a powerful and growing agent for the development of audiences for the performing arts.
For the third time in less than three weeks, Long Island Rail Road commuters are faced with the prospect of a strike.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy's criticism of Vice President Agnew concerning a Legal Services case in Camden, N. J., was itself criticized today by Representatives John E. Hunt, Republican of New Jersey, and Mayor Joseph M. Nardi of Camden.
GREAT NECK, L. I. -- When we last left them, a month ago, Valerie and Deborah Kremniov, the stars of America's latest real life Love Story, were racing into each other's arms at Kennedy Airport.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would be "at least three weeks" before repairs could be completed on a damaged section of the combined subway-Long Island Rail Road 63d Street tunnel.

" We finally can see the light," said Ken Dryden yesterday, talking about second place in the National Hockey League's East Division. "About two weeks ago it seemed we were on a dead-end street. If we played poorly we'd finish third.

If baseball dragged its feet before breaching the color line and admitting blacks to the lily-white big league preserves, it acted in no more backward fashion than the rest of the country. In fact, the breakthrough that baseball made a quarter of a century ago accelerated a movement, the extent of whose progress is still being debated.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- President Nixon, in yet another effort to give some forward momentum to his revenue-sharing proposals, asked Congress today to approve a $2-billion manpower retraining measure.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7 -- Roman Catholic civil rights leaders, buoyed by yesterday's peaceful march in Newry, today announced the start of a campaign of sit-ins, picketing and telephone and postal disruption.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- George H. Esser Jr., an official of the Ford Foundation, has been named executive director of the Southern Regional Council.
Mrs. Marlene B. Mosher of Loudonville, N. Y., was not the first housewife to have her oven burst into flame while roasting meat in one of the new transparent plastic oven cooking bags.

SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 5 -- An ice-cold bottle of Sandeman sherry was placed on the table in the Sapporo Park Hotel bar as copies of the Third Period Hokkaido Over-all Plan for Development were passed around. This spacious city, the northernmost big city in Japan, is a planner's paradise.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- A leading White House official, H. R. Haldeman, has charged that critics of President Nixon's latest Vietnam peace plan were "consciously aiding and abetting the enemy of the United States."
MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 7 -- Mrs. Jean Weinstein Sparber, editor, writer and social worker, died Friday of cancer in Morristown Memorial Hospital. She was 48 years old and lived at 96 Ogden Place.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had offered his help to Britain in dealing with the grave situation created in Northern Ireland by recent civil strife.

NEW HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 7 -- Yesterday's snowfall, from a skier's viewpoint the first halfway decent one of the winter, contributed to the unlikely congestion here tonight--Dollar Night--at the Ski Sundown area which had been on of the best-kept secrets in Eastern skiing.

WASHINGTON -- It is always astounding and appalling when those who profess belief in the free enterprise system propose gimmicks and devices that are the antithesis of freedom in order to achieve a temporary goal.

Labor Day and Memorial Day, holidays on which business is usually at a standstill, may soon become active shopping days as a result of a decision by New York's second largest retailer to open for business this year on both days.
Long-term interest rates continued to climb yesterday as several investment banking groups underwriting new corporate bonds decided to give up the ghost.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 7 -- A take-over by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of some of Nassau County's failing bus companies was recommended today by County Executive Ralph G. Caso in his State of the County message.

Merck Co. had the highest sales and earnings in its history in the fourth quarter and for all of last year, Henry W. Gadsden, chairman of the health-products maker, reported yesterday from the company's Rahway, N.J., headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The chances of Congressional action to end the West Coast dock strike this week were greatly reduced today when Senate and House committees approved substantially different bills that would order the longshoremen back to work.

TRENTON, Feb. 7 -- Gov. William T. Cahill's tax policy committee was reported tonight to have agreed on a $1.5-billion tax package for New Jersey that includes a graduated state income tax and a statewide property tax.

The question of whether the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is suffering from an "identity crisis" came up for discussion yesterday at a monthly luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk, the association of New York theater critics, editors and reporters.

I want to record my debt of gratitude to The Times for at least two bright spots in our dull, gray January. We were cheered by the valiant rallying of widely scattered readers to the defense of the bumble brown egg and by the small avalanche of protests from outraged New Yorkers because another Britisher had innocently ventured to praise their, city.
Discovery of the smallest known disease-causing virus -- the potato spindle tuber virus -- was reported by a Government plant pathologist at an international meeting of virologists here yesterday.
HARTFORD, Feb. 7 (AP) -- A special legislative commission decided tonight to recommend passage of a modified form of no-fault auto insurance for personal injury.

Steel production for the week ended Feb. 5 slipped to 2,345,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a decline of 0.6 per cent from the 2,358,000 tons produced in the preceding week.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., Feb. 7 -- A one-year study of six of the largest harbors on Long Island's North Shore has recommended that no further sewage effluents be discharged into Long Island Sound west of Manhasset and that any further sewage discharges into these bays be timed according to the season and tides.
TOKYO, Feb. 7 -- Japanese officials are showing concern over the weakness of the dollar and the strength of the yen in the Tokyo foreign exchange market.
In a major reorganization, the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York has begun a consolidation of its 31 scattered medical groups.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- H. R. Haldeman's red brick house in suburban Kenwood, Md., may be the only place in the United States where dinner guests don't come down with instant indigestion when the host inquires: "Would anybody like to see home movies?"
HILLSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 7 -- The news in the egg business is both bad and good -- bad for farmers, processors and distributors; good for consumers.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 -- The American Bar Association endorsed today a uniform statute to permit women to obtain abortions "upon demand." The association, however, rejected a uniform no-fault divorce law.

Quite a long time ago -- it was a little after World War I -- Gabrielle Chanel won fame and fortune by putting her clients into little black jersey dresses so they looked like their maids. Well, maids have all but disappeared, even for the well-heeled clients of James Galanos, but he has something of the same idea up his sleeve.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today a new program of selling some of the mortgages it owns.

CALCUTTA, Feb. 7 -- The Bangladesh Foreign Minister, Abdus Samad Azad, held separate long discussions with Prime Minister Gandhi's principal foreign policy aides, P. N. Haksar and Durga P. Dhar, while Sheik Mujib conferred with Mrs. Gandhi.

State Senator Bernard G. Gordon, chairman of the Senate Insurance Committee, has introduced a good plan for no-fault automobile insurance that somewhat modifies Governor Rockefeller's excellent proposal but preserves its most vital features.
The National Kinney Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Starrett Housing Corporation on a share-for-share basis.
There are no marble statues around Athens to salute Chris Papanicolaou, the only track and field athlete to clear 18 feet in the pole vault.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Describing his approach to form and function in architecture, Ludwig Mies Van Der Rohe used a phrase that has since become famous: "Less is more." The officials engaged in building the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization program are apparently now adopting this same approach to what parts of the economy will be exempted from and what included in Phase Two wage price and rent controls.

The Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation was identified yesterday as the neighborhood group that has a formal proposal for private refuse pickup in its area pending before the city's Environmental Protection Administration.

The second annual International Black Cultural and Business Exposition here next fall will feature a news conference with the two major Presidential nominees, a few days before Election Day, local organizers of the event announced yesterday.

Two commodity exchanges in New York and the Chicago Board of Trade are ready to establish a futures market in gold as soon as the Congress repeals a section of the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 that has prohibited the private ownership of gold in the United States.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 7 -- The head of the British commision that is here to sound out public opinion on the settlement that London has worked out for this former colony said today that the Rhodesian Government seemed to be breaking its pledge to permit normal political activity during the soundings.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a directive had been issued to protect homosexuals against discrimination in city government hiring and promotion practices.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7 -- The 70-minute flight from London to Belfast is crowded. Baggage is checked for weapons; women's pocketbooks are searched. The standard British airline breakfast is served: a cold slice of ham, half an egg, a tomato and rolls.

The controversy over the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes and the mystery of who endorsed $650,000 in checks from McGraw-Hill, Inc., has focused attention on the science, art or craft of handwriting identification.

CHARLOTTE, N. C. -- It had rained hard most of the night, pools of water were in the meadows, the swampy places were awash and the wind was raw, but the dogs found the birds and the shooting was good.

Charging that the state was shortchanging towns in favor of cities, the New York State Association of Towns opened its annual meeting yesterday with a call for increased financial aid from county, state and Federal governments.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- France today blocked immediate acceptance by the European Common Market of the trade deal worked out in talks last week between the Market's executive commission and William D. Eberle, President Nixon's special trade negotiator.

Severio (Pic) Picariello, the Pratt coach, pointed his finger at Howie Jones yesterday during the metropolitan basketball writers' luncheon and said, "If that guy gave me one player, we would be playing at Madison Square Garden."
LONDON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Picket-line violence, transport slowdowns and strikes in automobile factories brought widespread disruption today to British industry.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Senator Margaret Chase Smith of Maine, the only woman in the Senate, announced today that she would seek a fifth term.
CALCUTTA, India, Tuesday, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Indian troops in Bangladesh, formerly East Pakistan, will be pulled out by March 25, according to a joint communique issued today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The White House released tonight the names of 87 newsmen, commentators and technicians who will accompany President Nixon on his trip to China later this month.

Dr. Andrew H. Patterson, the Knicks' team doctor, placed a cylindrical walking cast on Willis Reed's left leg yesterday. The cast, from the middle of his thigh to about five inches above the ankle, will immoblize the Knick captain's knee for six weeks.

CAIRO, Feb. 7 -- President Anwar el-Sadat returned to Cairo today from a five-day tour that took him to Moscow in quest of more weaponry and then to Yugoslavia, Syria and Libya for further consultations on the deadlocked Arab-Israeli conflict.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The House approved today a $250-million program to provide daily hot meals for the nation's elderly. The vote was 350 to 23.

New Yorkers slogged to work yesterday through the mushy remains of the heaviest snowfall so far this winter, while snow emergencies continued in a few blizzard-battered areas upstate and schools were closed in numerous communities on the fringes of the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The United States Civil Service Commission said today that it had reduced a penalty against Maj. Gen. George R. Doster Jr., commander of Alabama's Air National Guard, from separation from the service to 120 days suspension.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 7 -- When Abelardo Tellado left Puerto Rico for New York more than two decades ago, he went in search of a better life than he could look forward to in a place where per capita income was an abysmal $250 a year.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 7 -- "Controlled medication" for race horses and the elimination of undisclosed ownerships or "fronts" for undesirable persons were two of the topics discussed today at the annual convention of the Harness Tracks of America.

Asserting that centralized city government had become a "mishmash" and a failure, Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams led borough community leaders yesterday in appeals before, a state panel for a new system of neighborhood government here.

H. E. Howard has been named vice president and chief financial officer of the George A. Fuller Company, builders. Raymond C. Daly, who had been president from 1956 until his retirement in 1964, has been named special consultant and assistant to the president.

There is immeasurable relief that the march of the Northern Ireland Civil Rights Association in Newry passed off without bloodshed. The sponsors wisely changed their route so as to avoid the center of the city and the British Army wisely refrained from moving to break up the procession.

The original design for the controversial Forest Hills scatter-site housing project embraced a new approach to racial and economic integration through an emphasis on more sensitive neighborhood planning.

Some of my colleagues at Stanford have expressed their concern that Professor Franklin's "banishment is a threat to any who may in the future publicly criticize the university's policies .'' [Letter Jan. 26.] It would be deplorable if other institutions over-reacted to provocations that fall within the pale of legitimate criticism.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve System began the year fostering a policy of sharper expansion of the nation's money supply to sustain gowth of the economy, according to the minutes of a Dec. 14 meeting of the system's Open Market Committee released today.
A sixth suspect was arrested in connection with the Jan. 2 million-dollar robbery at the Pierre Hotel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7 (AP) -- Enemy forces carried out brief rocket attacks today in the Central Highlands. American and South Vietnamese officials have heen predicting a North Vietnamese offensive this month.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The United Automobile Workers announced that it had filed suit today against George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, charging that the board unlawfully blocked the payment of negotiated pay increases in the aerospace industry.

In his Jan. 14 letter, F. S. King of Penn Central stated that my earlier letter had made "several misleading statements concerning high-speed passenger train service in the Northeast Corridor." I can only wish that space might permit a detailed rebuttal of his criticisms, but I shall confine my remarks to just one.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 7 -- A 46-member panel from which 12 jurors will be selected for the trial of the Harrisburg Seven was finally completed late today.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the Police and Sanitation Departments would "saturate" Central Manhattan, including Times Square, with personnel and facilities in a campaign to free the area of crime and litter. The campaign is to begin immediately.

SANTA FE, N. M. -- Pinon logs are burning in the fireplace. There has been much snow here this winter, and the woodpile behind our adobe is getting low. Every few days I go behind the house and split a few more logs, with the axe that my wife gave me for Christmas.
MIAMI, Feb. 7 (UPI) -- Joseph Caleb, head of Miami's 6,000-member construction union, one of the largest in the nation was found shot dead last night.

A scattershot conflict-of-interest bill that would prohibit 300,000 full-time city employes from engaging in outside employment was assailed yesterday at a City Council hearing by speakers, including some who were listed as its co-sponsors.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A Connecticut Representative introduced nine bills today to update fire-fighting techniques as "antique as the bucket brigade," cut the enormous American death rate by fire and correct new perils such as "escapeproof" skyscrapers and furnishings that emit lethal smoke.

The dean of Albert Einstein College of Medicine has been dismissed by the president of Yeshiva University, the controlling institution, in an apparent dispute over the school's financial and operating policies.

Queens Borough President Donald R. Manes endorsed Edmund S. Muskie for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday, calling the Maine Senator "the man who can bring a new calm to a troubled country, new vision to a nation whose priorities have become blurred."

VIENNA, Feb. 8 -- Karl Schranz, the Austrian skiing idol who was barred from the Winter Olympics in Sapporo, Japan, for allegedly violating the amateur rules, on his return to Vienna today got a reception that dwarfed all political demonstrations this city has witnessed since World War II.
Yongjeung Kim's interpretation of the current Korean situation in his recent letter seems to me neither realistic nor constructive.
An interesting sidelight to Ted Bates Co.'s move into the Times Square area is that the city is so pleased to have the agency there that it has installed a resident red-tape cutter.
Josh Gibson and Buck Leonard of the Homestead Grays were elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday, one year after Satchel Paige opened the doors to legendary players of the old Negro leagues.

In a game that may be more important to their emotional health than their National Hockey League status, the Rangers face tonight the Chicago Black Hawks, the club that began the New Yorkers' recent difficulties.
In dictionaries of the English language, "housewife" is not finding it easy to change her spots.

CONCORD, N. H., Feb. 8 -- A special session of the state legislature opened here today to debate proposals for a state income or sales tax, with indications that the issue would spill over into the Presidential primary.

The New York Times, one of its foreign correspondents and a member of its local news staff won in three of the 11 categories of the 24th annual George Polk Memorial Awards which were announced yesterday by the Brooklyn Center of Long Island University.

SANTIAGO, Chile -- Regis Debray, the theoretician of guerrilla warfare, appears to have drastically changed his belief in rural and urban terrorism as the universal model for Marxist revolution that he and his hero Ernesto Che Guevara did much to inspire.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The Pay Board revoked its policy on merit increases today and adopted a new, tighter policy bringing union as well as nonunion merit pay within its general guideline that limits annual raises to 5.5 per cent a year.
The midtown area took on a cleaner look yesterday following Mayor Lindsay's announcement of plans to saturate it with men and facilities to clear it of crime and litter.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 8 (Reuters) -- Lord Pearce, chairman of the British commission testing the acceptability of the Rhodesia independence settlement terms, today visited R. S. Garfield Todd, the former Prime Minister, in jail, a British spokesman announced.

FAS International, Inc. -- the corporation that runs the correspondence courses known as the Famous Schools in Westport, Conn. -- and 11 of its subsidiaries filed bankruptcy proceedings in United States District Court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Bills were introduced in the Senate and House today to authorize the expenditure of $85million to help Israel meet the costs of resettling Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union.
" The Diary," a comedy by Jean-Claude Carriere, which ran in Paris for two seasons under the title of "L'AideMemoire," will be brought to the Broadway stage in April by Arthur Cantor.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The House and the Senate moved toward legislating an end to the West Coast dock strike today despite a tentative settlement of the dispute.

The women were in charge at the Music from Marlboro concert Monday night in Tully Hall. Perhaps it was sheer imagination, but one result was that the performances of the four chamber works on the program seemed to take on especially gracious, sensitively lined and lyrically poised qualities -all of which was quite appropriate for the music at hand.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The cold, complicated process of reapportionment became one man's affair of the heart today as Donald Zimmerman, the Legislature's remapping expert, came from behind the scenes and defended the latest plan from attack in State Supreme Court.
Members of the Transport Workers Union yesterday agreed to a 27-month contract with the Transit Authority by a 3-to-2 margin.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Enemy gunners fired more than 25 rockets into the big United States air base at Danang and the surrounding city early today, killing three persons and wounding 17, the allied commands said.
Prices of soybean futures declined 1 3/4 cents to 2 1/8 cents a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade and prices of grain futures were generally lower.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- "The title of my play is 'Macbett' -- two t's, please -- and it is not to be confused with the play of Shakespeare, which many people must know, I should imagine," Eugene Ionesco writes in a program note. The confusion, however, is likely to persist.

There was a time when Benjamin Friedman, the selfmade man who heads Solitron Devices, was friendly with Harold S. Brady, the investor who now heads a stockholder protective committee that opposes Solitron's management.

The Lindsay administration, playing what one key city official terms the role of "silent matchmaker," is trying to arrange a meeting between Jewish and black leaders on the controversial low-income housing project in Forest Hills; Queens.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to extend by two years the life of New York City's interim Board of Education.

DUBLIN -- If the British troops were pulled out of Northern Ireland this month, civil war between Protestants and Catholics would follow, and the forces of the Irish Republic would be drawn into that war. The death toll in such a war would be far greater than anything yet seen in Northern Ireland, and the heaviest price would have to be paid by the Catholics of the Belfast area.
SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPI) -- Santa Clara County officials eased today a ban on interviews by Angela Davis after a strong protest in court by her attorneys.

Irving Hanerfeld, 60 years old, who the police said had been arrested 81 times on gambling charges since 1934 but never spent a day in jail, was sentenced yesterday to three years for criminal contempt for refusing to answer questions before a Manhattan grand jury investigating charges of police corruption.

City officials conceded publicly for the first time yesterday that one of the key air pollutants here -- suspended particulate matter, or dirt -- had increased 7 per cent over the last three years despite stepped-up control efforts.

Adjournment to March 28 of the Soviet-American strategic arms limitation talks (SALT), after limited progress in Vienna over the past month, suggests that both sides are engaging in brinkmanship. The Kremlin and the White House both seem to be preparing to go right down to the finish line -- President Nixon's visit to Moscow in May -- before striking the rough bargain both say they want.
SAPPORO, Japan, Feb. 8 -Marie Therese Nadig has her second gold medal.

Donald E. Procknow, president and chief administrative officer of the Western Electric Company, has been named chief executive officer, effective March 1, when Harvey G. MIAMI, Feb. 13 -- Public junior colleges, once scorned as "high schools with ash trays," have exploded since 1960 into a major social force that is shaping industrial development, urban services and personal pride.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 14 (UPI) -- A new school integration plan involving massive busing was put into effect in Richmond County (Augusta) today, triggering a widespread boycott by whites.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The Food and Drug Administration hopes to resolve within the next six months the issue of whether to increase the iron content of enriched white bread and flour.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- United States officials expressed concern today about the possibility of fighting on the island of Cyprus as a result of demands by the Greek Government for greater influence in Cypriote affairs.
NORTHBROOK, Ill., Feb. 14 -- It was a bright, beautiful day here today, but the sunshine didn't go over too well with some.
The top-winning dog of 1971 keeps right on the winning trail. He is the English springer spaniel, Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, owned by Dr. Milton E. Prickett, a veterinarian from Lexington, Ky.

The director of the Queens State Training School told two Congressmen yesterday that he could triple the school's enrollment, as well as produce some wage-earners among its student body, "with more money and greater cooperation from government leaders."

" I can live off a biscuit and a sunset," Daisy Bates said, and though she did more for the aborigines of Australia than any other single person, a biscuit and a sunset were just about all the tangible reward she got from the Government. An Irish-born lady with an upper-class outlook and education, Mrs. Bates was the most unlikelylooking anthropologist the world has ever seen.

A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that a suit charging Chemical Bank with failure to disclose finance charges on monthly statements of its Master Charge credit card did not qualify as a class action.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- Mayor Lindsay has brought a carefully revised version of the media campaign that surprised politicians in Arizona into the bigger, keener, more expensive competition of the Florida Presidential primary.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Bombs set by guerrillas blasted more Belfast buildings today while Britain's chief judge opened an inquiry into the 13 deaths of Londonderry's Bloody Sunday two weeks ago.

MIAMI, Feb. 14 -- "I'm an American first, a conservative second, and a Republican third," Representative John M. Ashbrook was saying to 45 cheering supporters of his challenge to President Nixon in the Florida Presidential primary.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14 -- The deepest drum, as high as a big man's waist, began to pound at 1:45 this morning with a beat that matched the pulse and made the skin tingle.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea today ruled out action in this election-year Legislature on a proposal to impose tuition at the City University.
Joseph A. Rice has been elected senior executive vice president of the Irving Trust Company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Nixon told members of Congress today that he would take some step to offset recent Federal court decisions that require a great amount of busing to achieve school integration.
ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- The Assembly gave final passage today to a bill that extends the life of New York City's interim Board of Education for two years.

The budget that Gov. William T. Cahill unveiled yesterday for New Jersey for the coming fiscal year is a "hold-the-line budget," as he called it. It is also more than this; it is an old budget for a new year with spending levels essentially unchanged, an inadequate budget that necessitates deferment once again of real solutions to the state's pressing problems.

MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 14 -- The president of the Nassau County Patrolmen's Benevolent Association filed suit in State Supreme Court today in an attempt to compel the Police Commissioner to permit policemen to wear longer sideburns and to grow beards or goatees.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 13 (AP) -- A world record of $450,000 was set today in the auction of What A Treat, a thoroughbred broodmare in one of three sales of the horses of the late George D. Widener.
United Utilities, Inc., reported yesterday sizable gains in revenues and sales and net income for 1971.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The policy-making body of B'nai B'rith -- itself split on the issue -- voted today to solicit the views of its 500,000-member constituency on the question of extending amnesty to Vietnam war evaders.

TRENTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) -- Nonprofessional workers staged sick-call protests today at several state institutions for the mentally ill and retarded. They later threatened to increase the absenteeism unless New Jersey agreed to their contract demands.

The Bankers Trust Company cut its floating prime lending rate to 4 1/2 per cent from 4 3/4, effective this morning, bringing it into line with the First National City Bank and the Irving Trust Company. Most of the nation's biggest banks have been at the 4 3/4 level since mid-January.

The clubhouse atmosphere is gone from the Deputy Mayor's office at City Hall. Mayoral aides no longer lounge in the armchairs, talking politics, their legs dangling over the sides, as in the days of former Deputy Mayor Richard R. Aurelio, the consummate politician who quit to manage the Lindsay-for-President campaign.

At 28, has mastered Mandarin in less than two years at State Department language schools in Washington and Taichung, Taiwan . . . Also fluent in French and Spanish . . . A Washingtonian who graduated from Yale and attended the Harvard Law School, joined the State Department in 1965 . . .

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 14 -- As one machine spewed potato chips into little plastic bags, sealing them, and another nearby rapidly turned cardboard into finished milk cartons, the United States opened its first trade center in Latin America today.
DACCA, Bangladesh, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy arrived in Bangladesh to a cheering welcome today and visited areas where Bangalis' bones still lay bleached in the sun.

You're a speculator and savvy enough to know that you can usually buy unlisted shares from an over-the-counter market maker at less than you would pay if you went to a Big Board member firm that did not make a market in those shares.

A Federal Court hearing in Brooklyn on an injunction to block a strike against the Long Island Rail Road was adjourned yesterday until Thursday after both sides agreed to meet tomorrow to try to resolve their differences.

SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 14 (Reuters) -- Stan Smith of California, the No. 1-seeded player, breezed to a second-round victory today in the national indoor open tennis championships by beating a South African, Ray Moore, 6-2, 6-3.

The head of the Federal Aviation Administration, John H. Shaffer, said yesterday the nation would do a lot better investing $1.5-billion in a quiet new short-range airliner than in equipment to lessen the noise of first-generation jets.
" The Politics of Woody Allen," a satire scheduled for showing on public television, has been withdrawn from national distribution for further review and study.

There were a few eerie moments at the confluence of Seventh Avenue and 40th Street during the rush hour yesterday morning. Crowds stood speechless on the sidewalks looking down into the water like Hindu pilgrims on the banks of the Ganges and the loudest sound was the whooshing of the water.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Thousands of miners marched outside Westminster Palace today to let the members of Parliament inside know the strength of their feelings about the coal strike. Judg ing by their shouts, the bitterness was aimed mainly at one man: Edward Heath.

If any more candidates were entered in Florida's Democratic primary, the ballot would have to come rolled up like a Chinese scroll. The law of that state and seven others now is that a single functionary or a handful of them can make official those candidacies that they think, to quote the Florida version, are "generally advocated or recognized in the news media."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -The Government made official today what had been generally known from private estimates -- that the United States suffered a massive record deficit of $29.6-billion in its balance of international payments last year on one of the four measures currently used.

Louis Jennings is not your ordinary Manhattan soda jerk. He drives a dark green Jaguar Mark I. His ice cream concoctions have been consumed by Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, Joan Crawford, Senator Mark Hatfield, Carol Channnig and Joan Sutherland. He is writing an autobiography called "The Sex Life of a Calorie."

Interest rates on top-grade corporate and tax-exempt bonds were reduced slightly yesterday on the expectation that the credit market's newfound optimism would make investors buy anyway. They did not show much enthusiasm, however.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that he had decided to prosecute for a fourth time four young men accused of the 1964 murder of a Harlem shopkeeper.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Andre Malraux, the French writer who came to the White House yesterday for discussions of President Nixon's forthcoming China trip, said today that Mr. Nixon was disposed to "envisage" and "consider" large-scale long-term United States financing of Chinese industrial development if this was seriously broached by the Peking leaders.
Seven men were arrested yesterday on charges of operating a $35-million-a-year gambling network throughout the city.
Sales and earnings of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., declined in the fourth quarter of 1971 but results for the full year advanced to a record, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Senators Walter F. Mondale of Minnesota and Gaylord Nelson of Wisconsin, both Democrats, will introduce in the Senate tomorrow a modified version of a federally sponsored child development bill that was enacted last fall.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Attorney General John N. Mitchell resigned today to direct the President's re-election campaign, and Mr. Nixon immediately nominated Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst to succeed him.

Gianni Del Buono of Italy, the winner of the Columbian one-mile run here a year ago has been substituted for his teammate, Francesco Arese, European mile champion, in the Olympian 1,500 meters at the Olympic invitation meet in Madison Square Garden Friday.

The grooming area for Jane and Bob Forsyth, two famed professional dog handlers, was the busiest place in the exhibition hall of Madison Square Garden yesterday. Work on preparing dogs for the Westminster Kennel Club show ring was being done in almost assembly-line fashion.

In what it termed an "emergency conference" on the crisis in the courts, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York asked business, labor, civic and judicial leaders yesterday to join in an "ongoing alliance" for court reform.

WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 15 -Bill Torrey, who spent six months working for Charles O. Finley and survived with his sense of humor intact, took on another difficult task today. He was named general manager of Long Island's new National Hockey League team.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 -- Local Buick and Chevrolet dealers in New York have decided to enter exhibits in the auto show to be held in the New York Coliseum in early April even though General Motors said previously that it would not participate.
A large water main break -like the one yesterday at 40th Street and Broadway -- is viewed by city officials as one of New York's inevitable and acceptable crises.

A 28-year-old woman who was to have been a key Government witness in a narcotics case was found murdered 12 days ago -- four days before she was to have testified, an assistant United States Attorney disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- Industrial production rose threetenths of one per cent in January and still does not show a boom-like trend, the Federal Reserve Board disclosed today.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 15 (AP) -- Quest III needs only one victory to retain possession of the Little America's Cup, after winning her third race today at Sorrento.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The State Department stressed today that the United States was seeking home port facilities in Greece for the dependents of crewmen of the Sixth Feet, not a formal "naval base" as charged by the Soviet Union.

ALBANY, Feb. 15 -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea and his Connecticut counterpart, of the House of Representatives William R. Ratchford, today announced the formation of a bistate legislative commission to protect the resources of Long Island Sound and the Atlantic coastline.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's largest bank specializing in "wholesale" banking for the corporate carriage trade, announced yesterday a reduction in its minimum business-loan rate to 4 1/2 per cent from 4 3/4 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The oldest recorded date in the New World is, in modern terms, 31 B.C. This has been established, the National Geographic Society reported today, because a farmer found a stone fragment near tile village of Trez Zapotes in Veracruz State in Mexico

In Ohio, Gov. John J. Gilligan is supporting the Democratic Presidential candidacy of Senator Edmund S. Muskie, and heading Mr. Muskie's slate of delegates in the state primary. His son, Donald D. Gilligan, a 24-year-old high school English teacher, is supporting the candidacy of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and circulating petitions in his behalf.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- Mrs. John N. Mitchell said today that she was "very unhappy" her husband had resigned as Attorney General. Between sobs she said, "I think it is a very bad move."

After reading recent accounts in The Times about conditions in the city hospitals in New York City, I was led to compare the situation there with hospital care available in a typical, upstate community. In Tompkins County, there is a single hospital, the Tompkins County Hospital.

James Levine, the 28-yearold conductor who made his Metropolitan Opera debut last June, is being named today principal conductor of the company. No conductor in the history of the Met ever has held that title.
DETROIT, Feb. 15 -- The General Motors Corporation plans spending of $1.1-billion in 1972, up from $1-billion last year and in line with the company's capital spending in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP) -- George H. Boldt, chairman of the Pay Board, confirmed today that he and his wife had been guests of one of the board's business members for dinner and a night at the opera in New York. He said he saw nothing wrong in that.

There was not much one could take exception to in Donald Walker's piano recital in Alice Tully Hall on Monday night. The Virginia-born artist, who is a Juilliard School alumnus and a teacher at Northern Illinois University, was making his debut here, and he played with the technical control and musical sophistication that is pervasive among young American pianists today.

TRENTON, Feb. 15 -- The State Commission of Investigation, seeking to show that organized crime was no longer concentrated in the big cities, heard testimony here today on how reputed Mafia leaders were trying to infiltrate business and government in such rural areas as Ocean County, in southern New Jersey.

The appraisal by The Times of Washington's recently disclosed proposal to Hanoi was fair and objective and free from any partisan bias. However, the editorial of Feb. 8 would appear to constitute a change in approach in its statement that "the Nixon Administration's acquiescence last year in the rigged single-slate election destroyed the credibility of the American suggestion that elections are the route to a political settlement."

Ch. Chinoe's Adamant James, bought as a birthday present 3 1/2 years ago for Dr. Milton E. Prickett of Lexington, Ky., made Westminster Kennel Club history last night when the English springer spaniel was named best of 3,093 dogs at Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) -- The White House, defending its civil rights record, issued a special report today citing progress in seven areas of "civil rights and related social programs."

Edgar Snow, the American journalist who had been on cordial terms with China's Communist leaders since interviewing them as struggling revolutionaries in 1936, died of cancer yesterday at his home in the village of Eysins, Switzerland. He was 66 years old and had been living there since 1959.
An infusion of Tibetan culture, some interesting sculpture and improvisation were the elements used by Lin Lerner and Betsy Wetzig to create their joint program at the Cubiculo Monday evening.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Four high Administration officials renewed their appeals today for President Nixon's welfare reform program as the Senate Finance Committee prepared to begin putting together a massive social welfare bill.

USLIFE Corporation announced last night that Marden Miller, president and chief administrative officer, has been elected to the added post of president and chief executive officer of the United States Life Insurance Company, a subsidiary. He succeeds Richard A. Hess, who joined the company about a a year ago. USLIFE said Mr. Hess resigned for personal reasons.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP) -- Tom Seaver is likely to be missing when the New York Mets open spring training for pitchers and catchers tomorrow. The 20game winning right-hander has not signed his contract for the 1972 baseball season.

HARTFORD, Feb. 15 -- Gov. Thomas J. Meskill officially opened the $75,000 Connecticut lottery here today by selling $10 worth of tickets to a 78-year-old retired baker, who, with his son, had won $1million in the New York State lottery.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Three weeks ago, Hall of Heroes Publications presented its first "outstanding American" award. It said that the recipient's "outstanding efforts and achievements, in the public interest, above and beyond the call of his expected duties, have increased for all of us our security in and our enjoyment of our lives, our liberties, our property, and our happiness."

The biggest bridge game ever will be played next month on March 24. With more than a month to go, more than 300 clubs, a record, have applied for franchises to take part in the American Contract Bridge League's nationwide charity game.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 15 UPI) -- Field goals by Jim O'Brien and Artis Gilmore helped the Kentucky Colonels beat the Indiana Pacers, 101-99, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -- The columnist Jack Anderson asserted today that the Nixon Administration had erroneously concluded that a rear admiral was the source of secret documents leaked to him about the American role in the recent IndianPakistani war.
DETROIT, Feb. 15 -- Sales of new cars for the first 10 days in February were up 5 per cent compared to a year ago, with all four of the major auto makers showing a gain.

In the American school curriculum of today, China is no longer limited to a once-over-lightly treatment involving such obvious and sometimes quaint exotica as silkworms, the Great Wall and peasants wading in rice paddies.

OAKLAND, Calif. -- President Nixon's recent authorization of a $10-to-$14billion space shuttle has finally brought this budding program to public attention. More than $200 million has already been quietly appropriated for shuttle development. The $10-to-$14billion total required to purchase and run the system through the nineteeneighties represents a Federal outlay about twenty times that requested for the supersonic transport (SST) that was defeated by the Senate.
WESTBURY, L. I., Feb. 15 -- The superfecta, in which the first four finishers must be picked in correct order, appears to be the main attraction for the nightly bettors at Roosevelt Raceway.

A Senate Commerce subcommittee has opened hearings on bills to protect ocean mammals. Chances for passage of an effective measure are still very much alive because of the wise refusal of the House last December to be stampeded into passage of a relatively weak bill favored by commercial fishermen and hunters.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 -Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, decried yesterday President Nixon's announced intention to offset recent Federal court decisions in favor of school busing.
TORONTO, Feb. 15 (UPI) -Top-seeded Rod Laver and second-seeded Ken Rosewall had little trouble in handling a pair of inexperienced opponents tonight in the first round of a $50,000 tennis tournament.
MIAMI, Feb. 15 -- Mayor Lindsay's predecessor in New York's City Hall declared here today that Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine was his choice for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
PARIS, Feb. 15 -- France signed an agreement with Israel today by which she will reimburse the cost, with interest, of 50 Mirage fighter planes that she sold to the Israelis but refused to deliver.

PARIS, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The United States and South Vietnam formally advised tile Communist side at the Vietnam peace talks today of their refusal to attend a conference session this week and left up in the air when they would participate again.

A wildcat strike by taxi drivers protesting a labor contract negotiated 14 months ago -- but never ratified -- spread to two more garages yesterday. As a result, the job action has now idled about 10 per cent of the city's 6,800 fleet-owned cabs, but has not affected 5,000 driver-owned cabs.

Four private foundations announced yesterday the formation of a national Drug Abuse Council to provide information, program evaluation, research -and independent leadership -- in the divided and confused field of drug-abuse prevention.

Valery Ivanovich Markelov, a United Nations secretariat editor arrested Monday night on espionage charges, had extensive technical engineering training, records indicated yesterday.

Steve McQueen spent perhaps $5-million, perhaps more, to film "Le Mans," and many reviewers panned it. Mike Keyser believes he can produce a superior picture -- a one-hour documentary ready for television this autumn -- for about $150,000 of his own money.

A police helicopter flipped over yesterday while skimming over Jamaica Bay on a rescue mission. Passing patrolmen and a fireman pulled the craft's observer from beneath a pontoon, cut the pilot loose from his submerged bubble seat and pulled an unconscious man -the object of the rescue mission -- from the water.

Mutual of New York -- the nation's 11th largest life insurer -yesterday elevated three executive vice presidents to higher posts following the death last week of Roger Hull, chairman and chief executive officer.

VIENNA, Feb. 15 (Reuters) -The Rumanian Embassy here said that Foreign Minister Corneliu Manescu denied all knowledge today of the reported execution of a Rumanian general, Ion Serb, for having passed defense secrets to the Soviet Union.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market finished mostly higher yesterday in brisk trading.
Roy White was signed to a 1972 contract by the New York Yankees yesterday, together with a pair of newcomers to the team, Bernie Allen and Rich Hinton.

Your editorial on "Pakistan and Bangladesh" (Feb. 5) has finally come to grips with the real situation on the Indian subcontinent. The suggestion for "establishing a new commonwealth on the subcontinent" is a step in the right direction. Let me enlarge my views on this point.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Feb. 15 -- Jean Ratelle, the high-scoring center of the New York Rangers, took just three shots at Dunc Wilson in the Vancouver Canucks goal tonight. Ratelle shot 1,000, scoring three times in carrying the Rangers to a 5-1 victory over the two-year-old expansion club in the Pacific Coliseum.
Textron, Inc., announced yesterday that it had terminated its proposed offer to acquire the Kendall Company and it related agreement with shareholders of the Henry P. Kendall family.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 15 (AP) -- The 110-man caucus of the longshoremen's union voted tonight to recommend that the 13,000 striking members of 29 West Coast locals ratify a contract that would end the 130-day walkout.
SARASOTA, Feb. 15 -- School busing became the overriding issue today in the Florida Presidential primary when the way was cleared for the placement of an antibusing referendum on the March 14 ballot.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 15 (UPI) -Stan Mikita scored two goals tonight to give the Chicago Black Hawks a 3-2 victory over the St. Louis Blues and a 13point lead in the West Division.

NEWARK, Feb. 15 -- Mayor Kenneth Gibson and the City Council publicly ended their feud over the operation of a proposed $7-million Model Cities program today and pledged a new spirit of cooperation that has been missing since the city administration was elected 21 months ago.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- Twelve European countries today signed a convention designed to end the dumping of poisonous waste by ships and planes in the northeast Atlantic Ocean.

Jim Lansing resigned yesterday as head football coach at Fordham University. He will continue as assistant athletic director, intramural director, and coordinator of the National Summer Youth Sports Program.

Bill Bradley, who has apparently taken over as the hometown hot hand for February, leads the New York Knickerbockers against the Houston Rockets in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15 -- High-ranking sources report that the decision to bomb Communist base areas at the border of Laos and South Vietnam was based on intelligence reports showing that more North Vietnamese troops were moving south this month than in any previous month.

The American Public Health Association yesterday cautioned men planning to have their sperm frozen before undergoing a vasectomy that the likelihood of being able to have a child by the sperm if it is stored for a "protracted period of time" is not established.

KARACHI, Pakistan -- in a downtown hotel recently, a woman stepped to a podium and told an audience of other women that those fighting against changes in marriage laws were "a reactionary group of people whose main aim in life seems to be the suppression of women."

Fletcher, dog writer for The New York Times, were honored by the Gaines Dog Research Center at the Statler Hilton yesterday.

MOSCOW, Feb. 15 -- The Soviet Government said today that a United States decision to establish a naval base in Greece tended to aggravate tensions in Europe and might prompt a Russian countermove in the Mediterranean Sea.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas, looking grim and drawn, went on nationwide television tonight to counter persistent charges that he had evaded taxes for four years and had hidden his wealth.
CONCORD, N. H., Feb, 15 -Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that he would amend his revenue-sharing bill so as to remove a clause that would penalize states with no income tax.

LONDON, Feb. 15 -- About 400,000 more workers were laid off today because of power cuts as a court of inquiry opened hearings in an effort to find a settlement for the national coal strike by the end of the week.

Karen Phillips, a young violist who gave her first New York solo recital Monday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, must have been slightly nervous. Although she is an experienced ensemble musician, a solo debut is, after all, a solo debut.

Bronislava Nijinska was one of the great figures of 20thcentury dance, and one of the last survivors of the Diaghilev era, which, during the first three decades of the century, completely changed the course of dance history.

Ronald E. Galella, the freelance photographer who is suing Mrs. Aristotle Onassis, conceded on the witness stand here yesterday that he had once signed a complaint against her for an incident that did not allegedly take place until nine days later.
Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr., the Queens Democratic leader, yesterday applauded Mayor Lindsay's proposed "tax vacation" for harried taxpayers and challenged him to put it into effect in the city.

BRADENTON, Fla., Feb. 22 -For Roberto Clemente, the hero of the World Series, the spoils of victory hang heavy as he prepares for his 18th season with the Pittsburgh Pirates -more tired and more troubled than at any time in recent years.

The New York Telephone Company said yesterday that nearly 1,000 employes refused to go to work when more than 20 union officials were suspended after holding a shop steward meeting during working hours.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -The Treasury urged Congress today to pass speedily and without amendment the legislation formally devaluing the dollar by raising the official price of gold to $38 an ounce.
Anxieties are growing about the durability of the monetary agreement negotiated by the major financial powers of thenon-Communist world at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington two months ago.

TRENTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -The New Jersey Lottery Commission, facing competition from lotteries in New York and Connecticut, announced today that it would double the number of ticket buyers who will qualify for the special millionaire drawings, held about every five weeks.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- For 15 months the Japanese Ambassador to the United States, Nabuhiko Ushiba, has been crisscrossing this country in an intensive crusade for the cause of alliance between Japan and America.

MOSCOW, Feb. 22 -- The Soviet Union announced today that with the successful soft landing yesterday of its unmanned moon craft Luna 20 it had resolved the "important scientific and technical problem'' of delivering an instrumented package safely to sections of the lunar surface with rough terrain.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Mayor Lindsay told the Florida Legislature today that he would continue to favor the busing of schoolchildren to achieve racial integration and was willing "to accept the political consequences" of opposition by many voters on the issue.
ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- State Controller Arthur Levitt went into court today to test the constitutionality of Governor Rockefeller's proposed $7.9-billion budget for the fiscal year beginning April 1.

ALBANY, Feb. 22 -- The Public Service Commission said today that it would hold a public hearing next month in its investigation of complaints about service provided by the Western Union Telegraph Comany in the state.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Bernardo Paez has mad up his mind -- he will play football for Rice University.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide if the New York Legislature violated the Federal Constitution in 1965 when it voted to purchase books and lend them to all school children in the higher grades but allow local school boards to require children in the lower grades to rent their texts.
Bill Bradley was out of the line-up but not out of the spotlight last night as the New York Knicks faced the Portland Trail Blazers in a National Basketball Association game at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the validity of the largest default judgment on record the $145-million judgment imposed against the Hughes Tool Company when its owner, Howard R. Hughes, refused to appear for testimony in a suit brought by Trans World Airlines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 -After five weeks of debate, the Senate broke a Southern filibuster today and passed legislation giving the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission power to move against job discrimination.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company realized a-22.7 per cent increase in earnings in its first fiscal quarter, ended Jan. 31, on a sales gain of'9.4 per cent, the concern's report disclosed yesterday.

NEWARK, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- The United States Supreme Court today refused to hear the appeal of former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and three co-defendants, who were convicted in 1970 of extortion and conspiracy in connection with shakedowns of contractors, the United States Attorney's office here said.

Alex Olmedo started the ball rolling at the Clean Air tennis tournament yesterday by recording a mild upset over Haroun Rahim, 6-2, 2-6, 7-6. Before the evening ended, three seeded players had been ousted in the $30,000 event at the Seventh Regiment Armory at 66th Street and Park Avenue.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22 -- Although William Pena did not live long enough to see his grandson keep his promise to him, George Pena intends to keep it anyway -if the Yankees will give him the chance.

Julius Lipsett, president of the Lipsett International Corporation, said yesterday that his ship-scrapping concern planned to leave the Brooklyn Navy Yard when its lease with the Commerce, Labor and Industry Corporation of Kings County (CLICK) expires on March 31.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Feb. 22 (AP) -- Stewart Gray, a 27-yearold light-heavyweight boxer from Toronto, died late tonight from injuries suffered last night when he was knocked out by the Canadian champion, Al Sparks of Winnipeg.
Paul B. Mott Jr., headmaster of the Collegiate School, the oldest independent school in the United States and one of the most highly rated, has been relieved of his duties by the board of trustees.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) -- In an effort to cut home-buying costs, George Romney said today that the government would put ceilings on settlement charges for purchasing federally insured homes.

The Federal Reserve, for the second time in the last three days the bond market has been open, sold short-term Treasury securities -- a move that seemed designed to keep short-term rates from declining further.

With the proliferation of apologia for Hubert Humphrey's support of the Johnson Vietnam policy during most of the 1968 campaign, one is conditioned to expect large excuses and little fact. Even so, Chester Cooper's Feb. 3 Op-Ed defense of Humphrey's failure publicly to demand a bombing halt in the summer of 1968 evokes comment. For, according to Cooper, Humphrey was intellectually and morally opposed to the Johnson bombing policy.

Alvin Roth of New York and Barbara Rappaport of East Orange, N. J., reigning national life master pair champions, were the winners again in the Greater New York Bridge Association's sectional tournament at the New York Hilton Hotel over the weekend.
The Topper Corporation, a leading toy manufacturer, announced yesterday the signing of an agreement with its creditors' committee regarding the payment of its trade and service debts.

Alan Pifer, president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, called yesterday for reforms that would lighten the "formidable burden the nation has placed on its higher education system."

The Public Broadcasting Service will make two controversial proposals to its board of directors on March 6. One calls for the appointment of an experienced journalist to coordinate public affairs programing on the non-Commercial network.

Alex Webster, coach of the New York Giants, made his first public appearance yesterday since undergoing ear surgery a couple of weeks ago. He attended a get-together luncheon for some of the new Giant players and members of the news media in the wine cellar at Mamma Leone's Restaurant.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22 -- Howard Hughes has accepted the urging of some of his most trusted employes and agreed reluctantly that an authorized biography of him be prepared under their direction, a Hughes Tool Company source said today.

LONDON, Feb. 22 -- It is foggy here and the City of London, as the financial district is called, is jumping or slumping, depending on whether the establishment in question is being run by candle or electricity.

The Philadelphia-BaltimoreWashington Stock Exchange which indicated recently that it would oppose the Securities and Exchange Commission on the thorny issue of institutional membership, received yesterday an informal endorsement of its views from some 30 institutional members.

A group of Greenwich Village community leaders accused Mayor Lindsay yesterday of aggravating their crime problems by initiating a "piece-meal" anticrime drive in the Times Square area and ignoring other neighborhoods.
The Perkin-Elmer Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the Multi-Amp Corporation, which provides equipment for testing electrical protective devices.

Mozart's concert pieces for voice and orchestra do not turn up ordinarily, and for a simple reason: Ordinary singers sometimes are foolish, but they are rarely crazy. Happily, Beverly Sills is neither ordinary nor crazy, and her appearance Monday night at Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra proved to be a joyful event for Mozarteans.

PEKING, Wednesday, Feb. 23 (UPI) -- Warmly dressed in a fur-lined coat, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon strolled through a light snow today on a tour of a Chinese farm commune. She saw a demonstration of acupuncture medical treatment and heard children sing the praises of Chairman Mao Tse-tung.
The stock market opened with a burst of strength yesterday, but failed to sustain most of its early gains and closed on the fence after meandering through the balance of a lackluster session.

A blistering fast break during a 45-point fourth quarter gave the New York Knicks a 122-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers at Madison Square Garden last night before a crowd of 18,211, the first lessthan-capacity Knick crowd since New Year's Day.
