Federal charges of conspiracy, fraud and transporting stolen securities were filed here yesterday against a former official of the state's Democratic party, a rabbi, a convict and three former brokerage company employes.

TRENTON, Feb. 24 -- Richard W. DeKorfte, the Republican Assembly majority leader from Bergen County, announced today that he would attempt to have a special legislative session in June approve a $1.5-billion tax-reform package for New Jersey.

ATLANTA, Feb. 24 -- Gov. Jimmy Carter said today that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey told a group of Governors in Washington this week that Gov. George C. Wallace was forcing him into positions on busing and tax reform that he regreted not having taken earlier.

The Times correctly characterizes the language of Rabbi William Berkowitz as "intemperate and unfortunate." It goes on to conclude [editorial Feb. 11], also correctly, that the talk of the "preservation of 'ethnic entities' in terms of real estate, either in Forest Hills or anywhere else" is but exacerbating the racial aspects of the Forest Hills dispute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -The Supreme Court declared unanimously today that it was unconstitutional to punish persons as vagrants under vague laws that outlawed such conduct as loafing, "nightwalking" and avoiding work.

The Forbidden City -- a complex of palaces and temples set on 250 acres in the heart of Peking -- was the dwelling place of 24 Ming and Ching dynasty emperors from the early 15th century until 1912, when the Ching dynasty was overthrown.
Dr. Wei-Ping Chen, who had had a long and distinguished career as a churchman and as a diplomat in Nationalist China, died on Wednesday in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 96 years old.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 24 -Angela Davis said today her release on $102,500 bail after 16 months in prison was a "victory for the people" and vowed to work for the release of "all political prisoners."
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

Four men who operated an unlicensed real estate company were arrested yesterday and accused of swindling more than 200 apartment seekers out of $60,000 in cash deposits on premises with which they had connection.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 24 -- If Rich McKinney ever joins Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Joe DiMaggio, Mickey Mantle and Casey Stengel in having his number retired by the Yankees, the number will be 27, not 11.

State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist yesterday invited applications for two "external" college degrees that can be earned by persons who have never taken a college course or even acquired a high school diploma.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 24 -- Exploration of the distant outer planets by spacecraft is scheduled to begin Sunday night with the launching here of an unmanned Pioneer 10 on a 22-month, half-billion-mile journey to Jupiter.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its revised commission schedule -- the first basic overhaul of Big Board fees in 14 years -- would go into effect with trades executed on March 24.

DANBURY, Conn., Feb. 24 -In the bitter cold this morning, with about 200 supporters waiting ankle deep in snow at the gate, the Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, a major symbol in the antiwar movement, walked out of Federal prison on parole.

Four counts of perjury have been added to the stolen-securities charges against Seymour R. Thaler, the former State Senator and recently elected State Supreme Court justice, who goes on trial next week in Federal Court here.
State Supreme Court Justice Irving H. Saypol signed a formal order yesterday embodying his decision directing the halting of construction on the controversial Forest Hills low-income housing project.

A newspaper in Richmond, Va., ignoring the facts and deliberately distorting the record, has charged The Times with "hypocrisy" in our editorial position on school-desegregation busing. Central to the charge is the allegation that The Times applies a double standard to integration South and North.

Clifford Irving and his wife, Edith, failed to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday for questioning on pending lawsuits involving both Mr. Irving's book "Fake" and his compilation of the purported autobiography of Howard R. Hughes.

The Internal Revenue Service, disturbed because too much money is being withheld from many income-tax payers, called attention yesterday to a device to bring the withholding down to where it should be.

FLINT, Mich., Feb. 24 (AP) -- The Genesee County grand jury handed up indictments today against nine officers of a Flint-area cemetery in an alleged $3-million scheme to defraud veterans by selling them ostensibly free cemetery lots that turned out to be expensive.

WINTERHAVEN, Fla., Feb. 24 (UPI) -- Luis Aparicio has been delayed in reporting to spring training with the Boston Red Sox because of problems in obtaining a visa to leave his home in Maracaibo, Venezuela.
TOKYO, Feb. 24 (AP) -- China has named 86-year-old Tung Pi-wu acting chief of state, filling the vacancy created by the ouster of Liu Shao-chi, a Peking broadcast disclosed today.

International Longshoremen's Association locals from South Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports went into another bargaining round with management representatives yesterday on two issues -- the guaranteed annual income and welfare-fund financing -that may not be entirely re solved before the union votes on a new contract March 8. The I. L. A. has tentatively agreed on such basic master contract items as pay and hours.

FRANKFURT, Feb. 24 -- West Germany today slashed its discount rate from 4 per cent to 3 per cent and prepared to put into effect its first exchange controls of the postwar era to check an influx of dollars and defend the monetary accord of last Dec. 18.

In a Feb. 11 editorial "Dubious Integration Plan. . ." The Times found it "unfortunate" that the Fleischmann Commission has "proposed actions likely to create a maximum of conflict and in any case are quite unrealistic." Election year attitudes and politics aside, the commission's recommendations are not as unrealistic as The Times chose to characterize them.
HONG KONG, Feb. 24 (AP) -North Vietnam made its first comment on President Nixon's visit to China today and it was an adverse one that did not mention China by name.

William R. Phillips, the suspended city patrolman who became an undercover agent and key witness last year for the Knapp Commission investigation of police corruption, has been questioned in the murder of two persons in an East Side bordello three years ago.

OAKLAND, Calif. Feb. 24 (AP) -- Cazzie Russell scored 20 points in the third quarter tonight as he helped rally the Golden State Warriors to a 116106 victory over the Detroit Pistons. Russell finished with 26 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- A small group of black executives met today in a downtown hotel in an effort to form a multimilliondollar communications conglomerate based on what they see as an impending "revolution" in the broadcast media.
The stock market continued churning indecisively yesterday and closed with generally small gains.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24--Japan was reported today to have refused an American request that she refrain from sending her first official mission to North Vietnam this month. The American objection was said to be that it might embarrass President Nixon during his visit to China.

Chicago had just burned down when F. W. Rueckheim, a German immigrant, came to the Windy City from a nearby farm with his life savings of $200. He intended to make an honest buck cleaning up the debris from the 1871 holocaust, but instead opened a popcorn stand.

Federal Judge Irving Ben Cooper said yesterday afternoon that there was a clear-cut conflict between the testimony and pretrial depositions of Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer who is suing Mrs. Aristotle Onassis for $1.3-million for allegedly interfering with his livelihood.

Poking around in the annals of some less than eminent Victorians, the English biographer and novelist Elizabeth Jenkins has come across a sensation-making scandal of the late 1870's -- sensation-making even by newsworthy standards of today. The incidents as the author details them for us prove once again that though the age was Victorian, a large number of people were not.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 24 (AP) -- Big Ten athletic directors completed a session of more than eight hours gathering testimony today in the suspension cases of Ron Behagen and Corky Taylor and prepared tonight to go into an executive session.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -John Cassese, former president of the New York Policemen's Benevolent Association, and George Hardy, president of the Service Employes International Union, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. affiliate, announced today that a national police union would be formed as an autonomous division within the Service Employes Union.

Senator Philip A. Hart, Democrat of Michigan, yesterday repudiated the use of his name in a full-page advertisement in The New York Times attacking United States aid to Israel.

PEKING, Friday, Feb. 25 -President Nixon continued to react with public enthusiasm today toward his Peking visit while his Chinese hosts, although not matching the President's rhetorical buoyancy, continued to give widespread publicity to their extensive dealings with him.

A concert appearance by Joni Mitchell is not only rare, it is a rare delight. Her performance at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night was her first New York appearance in nearly two years; for anyone who values popular music in its finest form, the interval has been far too long.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its consolidated net income in 1971 declined to $9,452,000, or 80 cents a share, from $13,722,000, or $1.16 a share, in 1970. Revenue rose to $290,922,000 from $282,537,000 a year earlier.

Some questions may never be answered, such as "What defines the border between conventional theater and dance?", but the asking of them is so beneficial that it scarcely matters. WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A high-ranking Pentagon official disclosed today that the code SPN384 is stamped on the discharge papers and the per-permanent records of soldiers, sailors and airmen who are discharged for drug abuse.

A "profile" of Samuel Melville, who was sent to Attica prison for his role in a series of 1969 bombings in New York City and killed during last September's uprising at the prison, has been written from underground by Jane Alpert, herself a fugitive from justice for her role in the bombings.

The early announcement of New York City's proposed expense budget for the next fiscal year comes as a grim storm warning. Details are to be revealed in their full tabular form later this week, but the public has already been told that this budget will total about $10 billion, a rise from $8.6 billion for the current fiscal year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 29 -- Although Swift Co. earnings for the first quarter of the fiscal year were down 10 per cent from the record of a year earlier, sales and profits should increase in the full year, Robert W. Reneker, president, said at the annual meeting today.
ROME, Feb. 29 -- Italy's Roman Catholic hierarchy indicated today that it would strongly back the Christian Democratic party in the campaign for the general elections in May.

Beset by a pressing need for endowment funds, Cranbrook Academy, one of the country's leading art schools, will auction off a major part of its art collection at Parke-Bernet Galleries, beginning tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 (UPI) -- The nation's largest consumer finance company has agreed to a court order requiring it to provide equal borrowing opportunities to members of minority groups and to hire more women and nonwhites, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.
A desk sergeant with the Carmel town police in Putnam County was gunned down at police headquarters last night by a shotgun blast firsed from an automobile.

Legislation to dismantle the City Housing and Development Administration and curb Mayor Lindsay's power to authorize funds for municipal loans for the rehabilitation of slum housing was introduced in the City Council yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 29 -- Mexico proposed today that the United States and the Soviet Union give up their co-chairmanship of the Geneva disarmament conference as a means of encouraging China and France to participate.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee added its approval today to the legislation, already unanimously approved by the Banking Committee, formally devaluing the dollar by raising the price of gold from $35 to $38 an ounce.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, sent the Government a 28-page compendium today of what he called "flagrant deficiencies" in Federal auto safety standards. He urged "drastic" improvements.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 29 -Slates of delegates for four Democratic Presidential candidates and three Republicans have been filed for the Rhode Island primary election May 23.

TOKYO, Feb. 29 (Reuters) -Japan's balance of payments in January produced a surplus of $196-million, the Finance Ministry announced today. The revised figure was in contrast to a deficit of $309-million a year before.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb. 29 (UPI) -- Judge Richard Arnason ruled today that a prospective juror in the Angela Davis murder-kidnapping trial could not be removed solely because he did not like Communism.

PARIS, Feb. 29 -- A Chicago banker is drumming up support for a novel way to deal with the problem of inconvertibility of the dollar. He would have the United States Treasury buy up packages of American corporate securities and offer them at a discount to foreign central banks.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 1 -- Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green predicted to Japanese officials yesterday that United States corporations would be represented at the Canton trade fair for the first time this April.
Counsel for Ronald E. Galella rested their case yesterday afternoon in the photographer's suit against Mrs. Aristotle Onassis for $1.3-million for alleged interference with his livelihood.

ALBANY, Feb. 29 -- The State's Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, Henry L. Diamond, ordered Consolidated Edison today to cease testing its pump and water-intake equipment at its new nuclear plant at Indian Point.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- A memorandum purportedly written last June by the chief lobbyist for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and disclosed here today linked the settlement of an antitrust action against the company with a subsidiary's pledge to help finance the Republican National Convention this year.

The two giant pandas promised to the United States by China in exchange for two musk oxen, as a token of goodwill, have stirred up polite warfare among the nation's zoos.
The 60th annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with contributions totaling $1,020,763.85 from 13,155 donors.

Edwin C. Fox has been elected president of James Talcott Factors and executive vice president, a member of the board and of the executive committee of James Talcott, Inc., the parent company. He succeeds Thomas J. McGann, who as executive vice president of James Talcott, Inc., will head internanational factoring operations.

The Scott Commission ended its borough public hearings yesterday with a meeting in Manhattan and added a dozen more suggestions, complaints and warnings to its long list of decentralization plans for New York City.

The last of the Long Island Rail Road's 63 double-decker commuter cars was sent to the scrap heap yesterday after it had completed its trip to Penn Station. On the return route, the cars were made up of the first group of 150 new Metropolitan cars, of which the railroad already had 620.

ATLANTA, Feb. 29 -- Venereal disease specialists at the Center for Disease Control here expressed confidence today that within a year they would have a "reasonably helpful" blood test to detect gonorrhea, the most commonly reported communicable disease in the country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 29 -- Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's assistant for national security, came under severe criticism today from members of Congress who accused him of pre-empting the State Department's traditional role in formulating United States foreign policy.

No Scotch whisky will be unloaded today on East and Gulf Coast and Great Lakes docks, if a directive sent out yesterday by Thomas W. Gleason, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, is carried out.

Prices of wheat futures closed 5/8 cent to 2 cents lower a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday. They reflected liquidation with the beginning of deliveries agianst the March contract and speculative profit taking following the gains of 1 cent to 2 cents a bushel Monday with the news of the sale by Canada of 185 million tons of wheat, valued at $330-million, to the Soviet Union.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market rose briskly yesterday in stepped-up trading.

RABAT, Morocco, Thursday, March 2 (AP) -- Moroccans voted overwhelmingly yesterday for a new constitution proposed by King Hassan II that he said would gradually transform him from absolute ruler to an arbiter.

Henry Moore's sculpture "Reclining Figure" was sold last night by Cranbrook Academy for $260,000, a record auction price for a sculpture by a living artist.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that its $250million atom smasher in Batavia, Ill., had boosted a stream of protons to the highest energy level ever achieved by man, 200 billion electron volts, or almost three times as high as produced by the largest Soviet machine.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 1 -- The jury in the bombing-kidnapping conspiracy trial of the Rev. Philip F. DETROIT, March 1 -- With 265,000 registered snowmobiles, Michigan is rivaling Minnesota for the lead in registrations, but the state that put the world on wheels has had only limited success in making a snowmobile to exploit the country's fastestgrowing recreational market.

Walter D. Dance and Reginald H. Jones were elected yesterday vice chairmen and executive officers of the General Electric Company. Dennler will retire after more than 38 years with the company.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 1 -- Juan Maria Bordaberry, a 43-year-old conservative, today assumed the presidency of Uruguay with a notable lack of public enthusiasm and maximum security.

PARIS, March 1 -- Robert Aries, whose profitable hobby is to pick up any valuable patents and trademarks that aren't nailed down, has a "mexxage" for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey).

CHICAGO, March 1 -- Japan is willing to reduce its balanceof-trade deficit and help American companies achieve greater penetration of Japanese markets, Nobuhiko Ushiba, Japan's Ambassador to the United States said today.

Queen Frederika, the self-exiled mother of King Constantine of Greece, is no longer in trouble with the Holy Synod of the Greek Orthodox Church. The synod has dropped charges, brought against her by Bishop Avgoustinos, Metropolitan of Florina, that her autobiography contained anti-Christian doctrines and ideas against Orthodoxy.

The East Coast dock strike "will result in a permanent loss of perhaps as much as 20 per cent of shipping traffic diverted through Canada," Mrs. Helen Delich Bentley, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, said here yesterday.

As almost every Welshman -and almost no one else -- was aware, yesterday was St. David's Day, celebrated here with the singing and daffodils of tradition and the roast beef and trifle of accommodation.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., March 1 -- On a day that saw the temperatures climb and drop within a few hours, a 21-year-old medical student from Poland and a 21-year-old brunette from Turin, Italy, captured gold medals at the World University Winter Games today.

Hartford N. Gunn Jr., president of the Public Broadcasting Service, vigorously defended public television's role in public affairs programing yesterday against critics "in positions of real power" who attempt to influence a public medium "on the basis of their own personal biases."
About 500 East Side residents, angry about rising crime -- reported to be up 172 per cent since 1967 -- confronted public officials and police commanders last night with demands for action.

The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center has turned down Ed Bullins's request that it refrain from using his name or the title of his play, "The Duplex," which is scheduled to open next Thursday in The Forum, the experimental playhouse beneath the Vivian Beaumont Theater building.

A magazine editor testified in Federal Court here yesterday that Ronald E. Galella, the photographer, had urged her to destroy all his photographs of Mrs. Aristotle Onasis that the magazine had in its files.

Hartz Mountain Pet Foods, Inc., filed a registration statement yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the sale of 1,750,000 shares of common stock, marking its first public offering.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association filled its 25team basketball championship field by selecting nine independent teams yesterday, including Villanova, which had to forfeit its runner-up finish in last year's N.C.A.A tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Government asked the Supreme Court today to expedite hearings on Senator Mike Gravel's legal effort to stop a Federal grand jury in Boston from investigating efforts he made to publish the Pentagon papers last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 1 -- China has made a $3-million first installment on her United Nations dues but, like the Soviet Union, is refusing to pay for some peace-keeping expenses and other budget items.

A 45-year-old man was killed in a smoky fire in an apartment house in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn last night, the Fire Department said. His two young nieces were rescued and hospitalized for smoke inhalation.

The "Life of Will Hare, Illusions and Reality," should be a nonelective course for any young man moving toward a career in the theater. It is a harrowing account and the fact that Mr. Hare has survived it, with grace, suggests the indestructibility of a certain kind of purpose.

PARIS, March 1 -- Today, as they do every Wednesday, several hundred thousand Frenchmen, including those in high places, picked up Le Canard Enchaine to see who was being subjected to the ferocious humor of one of Europe's most famous satirical weeklies.

MILFORD, N. H., March 1 (AP) -- Mayor Sam Yorty of Los Angeles, back in New Hampshire to campaign for next Tuesday's Presidential primary, suggested today that unemployed aerospace scientists be given the job of developing a nationwide antidrug program.

The New York State Banking Board yesterday approved the application of the giant First National City Corporation, the largest banking concern in the state, to acquire the tiny Silver Creek National Bank, just outside Buffalo.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The recent announcement by Mercedes University that it will offer an experimental course in bank robbery during the spring semester has created quite a stir on campus, not all of it favorable.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -Deputy Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst will appear before a special session of the Senate Judiciary Committee to morrow to answer under oath allegations of improprieties growing out of the Justice Department's settlement of an antitrust action against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

Three cheers for President Nixon. His amazing success in China so far is already worthy of praise. He evidently succeeded in the principal thing: breaking through the venomous approach to all things concerning our U.S. Government.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The Senate, after rejecting a series of amendments designed to prevent the use of busing as a means of desegregating schools, passed today a broad education bill that would aid schools and students at every level.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -The probability of a court challenge to New York's Congressional redistricting plan began to develop here today even as incumbent Democrats anxiously awaited their new district lines being drawn by the Republicancontrolled Legislature in Albany.

TRENTON, March 1 -- A three-judge Federal court has struck down New Jersey's 122year-old abortion law, declaring it unconstitutional on two grounds -- vagueness and invasion of privacy. The vote was 2 to 1.
MONTREAL, March 1 (UPI) -- Yvan Cournoyer and Marc Tardif each scored two goals and added an assist tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 4-1 victory over the Buffalo Sabres.

Nearly 100 works of folk art will be auctioned tomorrow evening at a benefit preview for the Museum of American Folk Art at the annual antiques fair at the Coliseum. About two-thirds of the items are from the museum's collection; the rest are donations.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 1 -- For the third time this week, the launching of Pioneer 10, the spacecraft designed to explore the environs of Jupiter, was postponed tonight.

ALBANY, March 1 -- A maverick Republican Assemblyman, aided by the minority Democrats, tried unsuccessfully today to pry a bill out of committee that would repeal the socalled "hot dog tax" enacted last year and got into an angry shouting match with the chairman of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.
Major efforts to regulate home-mortgage closing costs are under way on a Federal level.

WASHINGTON, Pa., March 1 -- Paul E. Gilly of Cleveland the second defendant to go on trial for the 1969 murders of Joseph A. Yablonski, the unsuccessful candidate for president of the United Mine Workers; his wife and daughter, was found guilty tonight of first-degree murder.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday approved, by a vote of 852 to 109, a broad plan to reorganize the governing structure of the Big Board.

ALBANY, March 1 -- A long, complicated and occasionally contentious hearing on "nofault" auto insurance opened today with some sharp remarks by Governor Rockefeller about the role of lawyers -- legislatorlawyers in particular -- who are opposed to the idea.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which pumped nearly $2.4-billion into the economy in long-term investments last year, disclosed here yesterday that it has more of the same in mind for 1972.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- State and Defense Department sources say that the Soviet Union, after years of keeping old nuclear weapons deployed even as it continued to install large numbers of newer weapons, now appears to be engaged in a significant program of retiring medium- and intermediate-range missiles.

ALBANY, March 2 -- A change in teachers' pensions that would end a $2,800-a-year advantage that the retired male has over the retired female teacher was proposed today before a legislative hearing on discrimination.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -American consumers may be paying exorbitant overcharges for vitamin-fortified cereals, a food-additive expert told a Senate subcommittee today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 2 -Archbishop Makarios was called upon today by members of the Holy Synod of the Cypriote Orthodox Church to resign as President of Cyprus, a position he has held since the island gained independence from Britain in 1959.

The League's strategy would only guarantee that nothing better than the House measure would finally emerge from conference.

WASHINGTON, Pa., March 2 -- A jury of five women and seven men today sentenced Paul E. Gilly to death in the state's electric chair for the 1969 murders of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers insurgent, and his wife and daughter.
NEWARK, March 2(AP) -Five present or former officials of a New Jersey union were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges that they embezzled $32,000 in union funds.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has come up with a new idea in the growing network practice of amortizing expensive investment in pilot films for each new season through advance airing as prime-time specials or movies.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, March 3 (AP) -- American fighter-bombers struck inside North Vietnam and Laos yesterday in exchanges of fire with enemy antiaircraft defenses, and an Air Force light reconnaissance plane was shot down over southern Laos, United States military spokesmen said.

ATLANTA, March 2 -- Edward Grady Partin, a teamsters' union leader, was found guilty today of Federal antitrust and extortion charges in connection with labor troubles plaguing the Baton Rouge, La., area in the late 1960's.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI) -- The House ethics committee voted 11 to 0 today to look into the bribery conviction of Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, in the first step toward possible House action against him.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 2 -- Senator George McGovern of South Dakota, sensing a surge of support in the New Hampshire Democratic Presidential primary, said again today that he felt voter sentiment in the state was almost evenly divided and indicated that he thought the race might now be neck-and-neck.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- President Nixon announced in a message to Congress today that he had directed the Department of Health, Education and Welfare "to recommend to me as soon as possible a plan for developing a safe, fast and efficient nationwide blood collection and distribution system."

The Hamilton Brothers Exploration Company, a new affiliate of the Hamilton Brothers Petroleum Corporation, made an offering of 1.2 million units of common stock and warrants through a syndicate headed by Morgan Stanley Co.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., March 2 -- An American spacecraft, Pioneer 10, was launched tonight on the first mission to explore the environs of the planet Jupiter.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The first use of nuclear energy to power an artificial heart pump in a living animal was announced today by the National Heart and Lung Institute. The institute is sponsoring a major research effort to make such devices eventually available to man.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -More than 50 Senators joined today in the introduction of a resolution to put pressure on Senator J. W. Fulbright, chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, to drop his opposition to a House measure to finance Radio Liberty and Radio Free Europe and end a deadlock that threatens the future of the two American-controlled stations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 2 -- Syria said today that her air and ground defenses foiled an attempt by Israeli planes to enter Syrian airspace over the Latakia area in the northwestern part of the country.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Senate passed today a major housing bill that includes consolidation of urban grants, a feature that could result in more Federal assistance to large cities and much more flexibility in the use of the money on the local level.
The bond - market recovery that got started Wednesday kept going yesterday.

RABAT, Morocco, March 2 -After the voters' adoption of Morocco's third Constitution in nine years, King Hassan II prepared today to hand over some of his powers to the Government and Parliament and to tackle problems arising since the attempt by army elements last summer to overthrow him.

Hundreds of thousands of New Jersey bus riders used alternative modes of travel without major difficulties again yesterday as the deadlock continued for the second day in the strike against Transport of New Jersey.
Judge Irving Ben Cooper declared in Federal Court here yesterday that it would be normal for photographers to want to take pictures of Mrs. Aristotle Onassis.
BUFFALO, March 2 -- One of these years the Buffalo Sabres may enjoy a night of reckoning against the New York Rangers, but such was not the case tonight.
MADRAS, India -- The ruling party in this southern state of Tamil Nadu has launched a Bangladesh-style autonomy movement, causing a national furor.
PARIS, March 2 -- The Credit Lyonnais offers paradise to the American in France with a bundle who wants his money managed by banks and not brokers.
PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- Gulf Western Industries, Inc., intends to concentrate on consumer-oriented acquisitions in the future, Charles G. Bluhdorn, chairman, said here today.
Leaders of Brooklyn's cultural life, in tones ranging from despair to resignation, told a state commission yesterday that the borough's institutions were being shortchanged on public funds.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 2 (Reuters) -- Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green arrived from Seoul today to brief Chinese Nationalist leaders on President Nixon's visit to mainland China.
In the menus below, the dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges yesterday issued their latet reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of their listed companies. The lists include the following:

Six of the country's largest retail chains reported yesterday substantial gains in sales for the four weeks ended Feb. 26. The period involved represented the first month in the retail industry's new fiscal year, which began Feb. 1.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2 -- Joe Torre, the best hitter in baseball last summer, continued his holdout as the St. Louis Cardinals opened full workouts today, with indications that his bidding had reached $145,000.
LONDON, March 2 -- Britain's official reserves increased by $11-million in February and stood at a record level of $6,991,000,000, at the end of the month, the Treasury said today.

The Great Southwest Corporation, a subsidiary of the Pennsylvania Company, announced yesterday that it had reached agreements with representatives of its major domestic and foreign creditors to extend maturities on its debt in excess of $100-million.

VERSAILLES, France, March 2 -- American-based multinational corporations think they have the muscle to defeat the Burke-Hartke bill in Congress this year and are chiefly worried about the possibility that its tax provisions, which would trim multinational sails, might be appended to other legislation.

The circumstances surrounding settlement of the anti-trust suit against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation last year and the degree of involvement of high Justice Department officials in making that settlement require more extended investigation by the Senate Judiciary Committee. At stake is not only the nomination of Richard G. Kleindienst to be Attorney General but also -- and more important -- the integrity of departmental procedures under the retiring Attorney General, John Mitchell.

A strike authorization was voted last night by Local 1707 of the Community and Social Agency Employes after efforts to negotiate a new contract between the management of cityfinanced day-care centers and 2,200 employes were reported deadlocked.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Pay Board unanimously exempted from its pay standards today the money professional athletes earn from playoff and all-star games.
FIRE BASE BALDY, South Vietnam -- "The North Vietnamese are good fighters," the South Vietnamese Army private said as he shouldered his rucksack and headed for an assault helicopter.
SEOUL, South Korea, March 2 -- Assistant Secretary Green assured South Korean leaders today that President NLxon did not make any secret deals on Korea during his visit to Peking

PITTSBURGH, March 2 -- Delegates to the convention of the Pennsylvania Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations indicated today an overwhelming preference for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for President in a poll.

HALLANDALE, Fla., March 2 -- Lucien Laurin, one of the most successful trainers on the Continent, let fall the information this afternoon at Gulfstream Park that he thought his horses would finish one, two in the $179,600 Florida Derby. As things turned out, he was exactly right.
A proposal that the real estate industry take over the Municipal Loan Program was made yesterday to Mayor Lindsay and the City Council, which has been investigating the program.
Igor Stravinsky's personal representative during the final decade of his life has written a book that casts controversial new light on the composer's last years.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., March 2 -- Mrs. Elizabeth Rodgers Boger of Southport, Conn., widow of Robert Forrester Boger, was married here this afternoon to Sidney Frederick Heckert Jr., a widower of Santa Barbara.

Senate approval of the higher education aid bill unfortunately means less than the $20 billion that meets the eye. The amount of money dangled before the hard-pressed universities stands in marked contrast to the depressing estimates of the actual allocations -- somewhere around $200 million -- that the Administration is believed ready to earmark for direct institutional aid, if the bill survives.
NORTH CONWAY, N. H., March 1 -- The New Hampshire Presidential primary next Tuesday may not be the walkover for Senator Edmund S. Muskie that many people expect.
Two gunmen wearing cashmere overcoats "rubbed out" a Brooklyn gambling figure in a crowded Bushwick pool hall early yesterday the police said.

NEWARK, March 2 -- Daniel M. Gaby, chairman of the New Jersey Democratic Policy Council, stood in the ruins that were once the ballroom of the Essex House Hotel today and announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

Harold C. Passer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, said yesterday the United States needs more concessions from the Japanese because of the continuing American trade deficit. He spoke at a luncheon meeting of the Japan Society here.
WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Manufacturers' inventories rose $200-million in January after remaining essentially flat in 1971, the Commerce Department reported today.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 2 -- A funny thing almost happened to the Wilbur Mills New Hampshire Presidential primary campaign tonight: The candidate came close to making a personal appearance in the state.
ALBANY, March 2 -- Representatives of the insurance industry differed today on whether there would be savings in premiums under the "no fault" auto insurance plan being discussed here.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -High-ranking figures in government, diplomacy, business, the military and the academic world gathered here today to ponder the implications of a controversial computer study that says the world must put a quick end to economic and population growth or face total collapse of human society.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Acting Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that he had played a role in events that led the Justice Department to drop three antitrust suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
PHILADELPHIA, March 2 -- Joe McGinniss, author of "The Selling of the President," is far from sold on the musical version of the book, now trying out here and scheduled to open March 28 on Broadway.
Plans to invest approximately $900-million in the stock market this year were disclosed here yesterday by the Prudential Insurance Company, the world's largest insurer.
PRINCETON, N. J., March 2 -- Last spring, during a freshman English class, Joe Savage came to grips with "Waiting for Godot," the Samuel Beckett classic.

TOKYO, March 2 -- Japanese textile companies, unsuccessful opponents of last year's mandatory Government restrictions on exports to the United States, are complaining about competition from inexpensive imports here and asking the Government for countermeasures.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- The Republicans are very much up and the Democrats very far down these days, but that's the way it usually is for the "outs" just before the first Presidential primary election, and the present mood is likely to change dramatically in the nine months before the vote.

The political and emotional whirlwind that has buffeted the school busing issue threatens destruction to any legislation associated with it. This is as true of the proposed $1.5 billion assistance to school districts which are in the process of desegregation as of the entirely unrelated higher education aid bill.

Our specialized society has evolved a new kind of book: one that "translates" our behavior into the modalities and the terminology of a particular discipline and in so doing provokes in us a sudden and often deceptive "shock of recognition." Finding ourselves described in new terms, we assume that we are being seen and understood in new ways.

While a trainman called out, "The 1:04 to Port Washington now boarding," Byong Yu brought tub-thumping to a new height yesterday as he broke four bricks with his forehead in the Long Island Rail Road waiting area at Penn Station.

BOSTON, March 2 (UPI) -Phil Esposito scored three goals and Bobby Orr became the first player in National Hockey League history to score 100 points in three straight seasons as the Boston Bruins defeated the Vancouver Canucks, 7-3, tonight.
PARIS, March 2 -- French customs agents in Marseilles found almost half a ton of pure heroin aboard a shrimp boat early today.
Consumer Affairs Commissioner Bess Myerson proposed a new city regulation yesterday that would force merchants to list the corporate or partnership name on their sales slips.
MIAMI, March 2 -- Florida's 1.1 million Negroes, angered by proposals to abolish school busing in the state, may be turning their anger on the leading candidates in the state's Presidential primary.

PARIS -- In a country largely content to live with traditional furniture, often inherited from one's parents and grandparents, President and Mrs. Georges Pompidou have just given a powerful boost to contemporary design by having four rooms of the Elysee Palace redecorated.
COLERAINE, Northern Ireland, March 2 -- A Northern Ireland medical officer testified today that six of the 13 men killed by British paratroopers in Londonderry on Jan. 30 had been carrying weapons.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP) -- The Financial Analysts Federation recommends that more detailed, improved disclosures be required in prospectuses of companies that want to go public.

Badfinger, a fine English rock group, was very nearly ruined by its technical assistance at Carnegie Hall Wednesday night. First it was the spotlights, aimlessly wandering around the stage, never quite catching up with the soloists, occasionally leaving the entire auditorium in darkness.
The stock market made a valiant effort yesterday to sustain its uptrend but failed to retain some early gains and closed with modest price changes in heavy trading.

DOVER, N. H., March 2 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, appealed to the voters of neighboring New Hampshire today to disregard the "overtones" of the Presidential primary campaign and give his candidacy a vote of confidence on Tuesday.
NEWARK, March 2 -- A black City Councilman slapped the white Council president across the face today as the Council, split along racial lines, debated salary increases for city officials.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 2 -- Jerry Kenney finally signed his contract today, giving the Yankees a complete roster of signed players. That may be the only area in which the New Yorkers beat Baltimore this year.

The appearance of a Black Liberation Army should not be unexpected. The history of Western civilization is full of instances in which man has used various forms of violence to destroy those whom he considers to be his enemies. The tactic of assassination could have been borrowed from Zionist terrorists or the I.R.A.
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 2 -- For the first time, the jury box was full today in the courtroom here where Angela Davis is being tried on charges of murder, kidnapping and criminal conspiracy.
ISLIP, L. I., March 2 -- Republican control of the next State Assembly was threatened today by a controversy brewing in a remote Long Island Assembly district.

Bob Gregory left the bench last night and led Manhattan College to a 98-95 victory over St. Peter's in the second game of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. Gregory, a 6-foot-6-inch, 210-pound strongman, entered the game with St. Peter's ahead, 13-0, and scored 23 points and added 15 rebounds.
Following are excerpts from the Mayor's budget message to the City Council and Board of Estimate:

BRUSSELS, March 2 -- The Common Market Commission today put forward new proposals to revive the European community's plans for creating economic and monetary union. Those plans were stalled last year by the world monetary crisis.

Bob McAdoo, a 6-foot-9-inch junior forward from the University of North Carolina, was the first player chosen in the "secret' American Basketball Association college draft yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

MONTREAL, March 2 (UPI) -- Vic Hadfield of the New York Rangers has been absolved from further penalties in the incident in which a linesman, Alan Glaspell, was struck in the face during the Rangers - California Golden Seals game last night in New York, the National Hockey League president, Clarence Campbell, announced today.
MIAMI, March 2 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson called today for increased Federal spending in educating and training retarded children and urged expanded efforts in medical research to assist them.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Justice Department disclosed tonight that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had traced Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the missing lobbyist for International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, to the Denver area.

The longest interplanetary voyage of the space age was begun this week when Pioneer 10 was launched from Cape Kennedy, targeted to explore the environs of Jupiter some 21 months from now. The vehicle is designed to scan the planet's atmosphere and radiation belt, after which it is to shoot out and escape the solar system to plumb the dark reaches of space.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- House Democratic leaders have renewed their drive to pry from the Rules Committee a bill that could provide pay increases for millions of America's lowest-paid workers.

PARIS, March 3 -- The United States has obtained clearance from nine of its allies for the sale of a satellite ground station to China. But Japan and other allies have interpreted the sale as a political act and have made it clear that they intend to use the same criterion.

BUFFALO, March 3 -- It had to happen, and tonight it did. The Buffalo Braves, who were beaten by the New York Knickerbockers in four previous games this season, turned on the visitors this time and recorded a 105-97 victory.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he was taking action to cancel a mobile heating contract held by a company in which a powerful Lower East Side political figure was a major stockholder.

ATLANTA, March 3 -- The fact that handwriting experts incorrectly identified letters and check endorsements as having been written by Howard R. Hughes, the billionaire, has aroused considerable concern at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Forensic Scientists here.
MIAMI, March 3 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey charged today that the Nixon Administration had failed to recognize a Soviet naval build-up in the Caribbean Sea.

Edwin A. Goodman, general manager of radio station WBAI, was sentenced to 30 days in jail yesterday for contempt of court for refusing to turn over to the Manhattan District Attorney's office the tapes of its broadcast of the uprisings in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men in October, 1970.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- There is a French children's riddle about a pond with a water lily in it. The lily doubles in size every day. In thirty days it will cover the entire pond, killing the other creatures in it. The owner wants to avoid that, but he sees no hurry: He will cut the plant back when it covers half the pond.
BUENOS AIRES, March 3 -- Argentina's 12 Cabinet Ministers and the president of the Central Bank resigned today, leaving President Alejandro A. Lanusse free to form a new government.

Vera Stravinsky, widow of the composer, yesterday denied charges that Robert Craft had misrepresented or distorted the ideas of her husband. These charges are being made in a book by Lillian Libman that will be published in the fall.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 3 (UPI) -- Evelle Younger, California's Attorney General, asked the State Supreme Court today to reconsider its decision outlawing the death penalty. He accused the court of usurping legislative functions and eroding the constitutional separation of powers.

PEKING, March 3 (Reuters) -- China strongly attacked Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan today and accused him of planning to antagonize Peking and make aggressive moves toward Taiwan -- plans the Chinese said were doomed to failure.
With a wild swing of its rhetorical nightstick, the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association (P.B.A.) has underscored some of the basic reasons for New York City's desperate budget crisis.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Two doctors writing in an important scientific journal have called for a moratorium on attempts at human genetics engineering, saying no one knows enough yet to try such manipulations safely.

VERSAILLES, France, March 3 -- France's Finance Minister, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, warned a blue-ribbon European-American businessmen's group today that "indifference" by the United States Government to short-term capital outflows and the dollar's inconvertibility posed a threat to monetary truce in the West.
With a mixture of amusement and exasperation, the city's Budget Director yesterday deplored the annual histrionics involved in fashioning a city budget.

A State Supreme Court Justice refused yesterday to set aside a unanimous decision of the city's Board of Standards and Appeals that blocked construction of a 400-unit high-rise Lefrak project in Forest Hills-Kew Gardens, Queens.

The 19th-century etagere just installed in the entrance hall of the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has elegantly carved ornamentation that suggests that its maker, Alexander Roux, was one of the best cabinetmakers of his day.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The "no fault" automobile insurance plan currently before the Legislature will be amended to meet some of the objections raised during three days of public hearings on the measure, the bill's sponsor said today.
When a 23-year-old United Air Lines stewardess arrived at Newark Airport recently to make a flight to Chicago, a United official took one look at her and ordered that she be weighed.
Martin Sweig, top aide to John W. McCormack when Mr. McCormack was Speaker of the House, was sentenced to three years in prison for bribery and conspiracy.

Miss Constance Randolph Wise, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph E. Wise of Philadelphia, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. Kenneth M. Klein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Klein of the Bronx.

ATLANTA, March 3 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, outlined today plans for a national health insurance project that he said would assure "adequate protection for those who need help while avoiding spending public funds for those who do not need it."
NEW HAVEN, March 3 -- Leading all the way, the Pennsylvania basketball team scored an 86-65 victory over Yale tonight and clinched at least a tie for the Ivy League title.
Riders on the Long Island Rail Road may no longer use 10-trip tickets, the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ruled unanimously in Brooklyn yesterday.
NASSAU, Bahamas, March 3 -- Condor, a Class D yacht owned by Hill Blackett of Winnetka, Ill., captured the overall title of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference sailing series today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Senate, by a vote of 50 to 6, approved today a resolution calling upon the executive branch to submit as treaties, requiring the consent of the Senate, recent agreements with Portugal and Bahrain concerning military bases.

Two sides of the art of Pierre Boulez were demonstrated at the Thursday night Philharmonic concert. One was familiar: Boulez as an exponent of the Second Viennese School, conducting the Chamber Concerto by Alban Berg.

We have duly noted Governor Rockefeller's declared goal of channeling at least $33 million of public tax money to the Catholic Church for its parochial schools, despite the fact that a three-man Federal Court has just declared such use of public tax funds unconstitutional.

LONDON, March 3 -- The London Stock Exchange announced today that its members had approved by a vote of 2,152 to 442 a plan to amalgamate with the six provincial exchanges now operating in Britain and Ireland.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 3 -- The British Army commander in Northern Ireland, Maj. Gen. Robert Ford, said today that there had been no plan to force a confrontation with the Irish Republican Army at the time of the Londonderry killings.
The McLaren School, in Esopus, N. Y., for children with special learning problems closed down suddenly yesterday and nobody knew precisely why.

NEW HAVEN -- The Site selection Board of New York City is scheduled to decide whether to authorize the purchase for $1.5 million of a single block in Manhattan, across from the overcrowded Tombs, for a second men's house of detention. From this small beginning, an error of historic dimensions may evolve.

MIAMI, March 3 -- A track-record, front-running performance by Mrs. Wallace Gilroy's New Prospect marked the opening day's card at Hialeah race track today. With Mike Manganello riding, New Prospect beat a strong field, including the Rokeby Stables' favored entry of Key to the Mint and Head of the River, in the $34,240 Bahamas Stakes for 3-year-olds.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 3 -- A Sydney gynecologist who was one of the first to expose the dangers of Thalidomide said today that another widely prescribed tranquilizer may also produce deformed births.

The dancers in the City Center Joffrey Ballet are not usually presented as innocents. Their image, particularly in the rock ballets, is hip. Catastrophes that engulf them, such as war in "The Green Table," are universal and would destroy even the most sophisticated.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 3 (UPI) -- The Susquehanna Corporation named along with four major banks for alleged violations of securities laws, denied today charges brought against it by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 3 -- Old Man Winter, who yesterday seemed in peril of being washed out of existence along with the World Student (F.I.S.U.) Winter Games, received the equivalent of a transfusion today as the international sports jamboree got into full swing.

It was good to see and hear the Kinks back at Carnegie Hall Thursday night. Their last appearance there was a musical and personal fiasco of such dimensions that it was easy to question whether they would survive as a group.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Western economists believe the setback dealt to the winter grain crop by an unusual cold wave across the Soviet south has increased prospects for a new Soviet purchase of American grain, possibly when President Nixon visits Moscow late in May.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered sharp gains yesterday in active trading.
Feminist movements that were shrugged off by New York politicians only a year ago are this year exerting substantial political pressure comparable to that of civil rights organizations in the state.

It is only a small exaggeration to say that the Kinsey Report -- or, more accurately, "Sexual Behavior in the Human Male" -- was, when it appeared in 1948, the most controversial book since "Uncle Tom's Cabin." Both struck at different kinds of hypocricy; in Kinsey's case it was America's official sex code.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The State Department announced today that the United States would sell approximately $70-million worth of arms to Greece before June 30.

DANBURY, Conn., March 3 -- The warden of the Federal Correctional Institution here and the deputy director of the Bureau of Prisons met today with a committee of inmates and asked them to halt their work stoppage pending negotiation of grievances.

The Better Business Bureau held a seminar yesterday on the problems consumers are having with furniture dealers, but almost everyone agreed that the real culprits were far removed from the meeting room on Vesey Street.
ALBANY, March 3 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller's office confirmed today that "serious consideration" was being given to a moratorium on approving offtrack betting plans upstate.

MIAMI, March 3 -- Lee Trevino, profiting by overtime practice in putting, led with a 36-hole aggregate of 138 in the $150,000 Doral Eastern open today. The ad libbing United States, Canadian and British Open champion said he had hit 400 practice putts yesterday and 600 the day before.

The great popularity of Swiss team contests is attested not only by the size of the fields but also by the decision of the Greater New York Bridge Association to devote three weekends annually to this form of competition.

A lawyer testified yesterday that former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler signed an agreement in 1970 to sell $800,000 in United States Treasury bills that were being offered for only 25 per cent of their true value.

PATERSON, N. J., March 3 -- This city contends that inefficiency by the Federal Government during the 1970 census taking led to an underestimate of its population, which, if not corrected, could mean the loss of $1.5-million to $2-million under Federal and state aid programs based on population.
DETROIT, March 3 -- Car makers reported retail deliveries of 697,724 United States type cars in February, up from 636,041 sales a year ago and more February deliveries than ever before.
Prices of copper futures here yesterday continued to reflect improved industrial demand for refined copper. They rose 3/8 cent a pound to contract highs before profit taking trimmed the gain.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- The new Texas Rangers got off to a bad start with the Yankees' Ron Blomberg today. The public address announcer didn't know how to pronounce his name and pitchers didn't know how to pitch to him.
NORFOLK, Va., March 3 (AP) -- Former Mayor W. Fred Duckworth, 72 years old, was shot and killed on a Norfolk street tonight.

Oscar Wilde -- even the ghost of Oscar Wilde --deserved better of life than Joe Layton, whose ballet "Double Exposure" had its New York debut at the City Center last night. It is said that the ballet is "inspired by Oscar Wilde's "The Picture of Dorian Gray." Perhaps -- but not sufficiently.
Ten of Newburgh's 70 policemen were charged yesterday with burglaries and larcenies involving seven different concerns in their riverside city, which has been called a "cesspool" of crime.
Three retail chains reported yesterday higher sales in February compared with the year-ago month.

There is a potentially irreconcilable conflict between the Judaeo-Christian image of the Biblical God as the just Lord of history and the terrible events of the twentieth century. The problem is especially urgent within Judaism. The traditional Jewish doctrine of the chosen people, no matter how interpreted, is difficult to maintain in the face of Auschwitz.

ALBANY, March 3 -- Senate Majority Leader Earl W. Brydges introduced a bill today to expand the state's tuition-loan program for college and university students and provide loans for students currently excluded from the program because of their family's relatively high income.
SHIRLEY, L. I., March 3 -- More than 15 miles of beaches on Fire Island were covered today with patches of a heavy grade fuel oil that apparently washed up from the ocean early yesterday morning.

Prodded by Congress and by fresh Soviet moves to exploit Moscow's new diplomatic advantages on the Indian subcontinent, the Nixon Administration has disclosed that it is preparing to recognize Bangladesh. This overdue action -- already 47 nations, including all the other major powers, have granted recognition to the breakaway Bengali nation -- would initiate a welcome change in policies that have undermined American influence on the subcontinent.
A major storm is gathering over the Administration's request for $942-million in the 1973 defense budget to develop a new Undersea Long-Range Missile System.
" It's my life, I can mess it up if I want to."

Saigon, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 4 (AP) -- Enemy antiaircraft defense opened fire on two American reconnaissance planes, prompting a new round of United States air strikes in North Vietnam yesterday, the United States command said today.

When Transport of New Jersey -- or Public Service Coordinated Transport, as it was then known -- named a new president last year, many Jerseyans repeated, in-advertently, the slogan of the 1961 mayoral campaign here "Who's Gilhooley?"

MOSCOW, March 3 -- An unusual report on Soviet gold-nining operations in northeast Siberia, opposite Alaska, discloses that the gold content of placer mines is steadily declining, requiring increasing volumes of excavation to keep gold output at present levels.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., March 3 -- China charged the United States today with "forcibly occupying" Taiwan and conspiring with Japan to give her control of a number of islands in the East China Sea claimed by China.
Five works owned by the Cranbrook Academy of Art, bought in the 1940's and early 1950's for $15,368, grossed $445,000 in an auction sale at the Parke-Bernet Galleries Thursday evening.

The first arrest under a new program designed to plug loop-holes that have allowed drivers to ignore summonses for moving violations was announced yesterday by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- In defiance of its premature death notices, the foreign aid program has risen to live at least until July, largely because Congress, for all its criticism, finds the program politically convenient.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., March 3 -- When David Blunschi and Fred Granitz of Powder Springs, Ga., arrived here last Monday morning with a busload of other young Army recruits, they were not at all sure they would like what they found.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The biggest gathering of Republican party leaders before the national convention ended here today in an atmosphere of ebullience that clearly announced the party's mood for the upcoming campaign.

After the recent upward move in the prices of copper and lead, another commodity, zinc, seems to be heading that way. In Toronto, Cominco, Ltd., announced it would raise its price for prime Western grade zinc by a penny a pound, to 18 cents a pound, beginning Monday.
Attendance at Aqueduct plunged to 14,512 yesterday, increasing the danger of a labor crisis that could jeopardize racing here next week.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association accused Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy yesterday of sabotaging its contract negotiations, broke off the talks and warned of possible job action by the police.

A member of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers clashed yesterday with a leading Democratic Congressman over the report of the Presidential Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 3 -- A proposal to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, an adviser to President Nixon, "opens the door to murder," the Rev. Philip F. Berrigan warned a New York nun, according to letters introduced by the Government today at the antiwar conspiracy trial of the priest and six other defendants.
LONDON, March 3 -- The British Government announced a renewed "war against the polluter" today and promised stiff penalties against anyone dumping dangerous wastes on land.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, March 3 (AP) -- Thousands of Greek Cypriotes shouted their support today for Archbishop Makarios as President and religious leader of Cyprus.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) Alger Hiss, a central figure in the Congressional investigation of the State Department in 1948, won a court decision today ordering the Government to pay him pension benefits.

HONG KONG, March 3 -- In its first official reaction to President Nixon's China trip, North Vietnam today denounced the American side of the joint Peking communique and accused the United States of "sowing discord" among Communist countries.

MIAMI, March 3 -- Mayor Lindsay began a four-day Florida campaign swing today by linking three of his liberal opponents for the Democratic Presidential nomination to Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.

Lawyers for Mrs. Aristotle Onassis charged in Federal Court here yesterday that Ronald E. Galella, a freelance photographer, brought suit against their client to gain publicity and the business he knew a lawsuit would spark.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 3 -- The leadership of the Palestinian guerrilla movement has reportedly decided to take steps to avoid confrontations with the Lebanese Army, which has moved into areas on the border with Israel that had been under commando control.
MOSCOW, March 3 -- A public lecture titled "Will the Leaning Tower of Pisa Fall?" drew about 70 people here the other day.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 3 -- Chinese Nationalist resentments growing out of President Nixon's visit to China appeared somewhat softened here today after a 24-hour visit by Marshall Green, United States Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian Affairs. But Taipei's attitude toward Washington remained visibly cool.
NEWARK, March 3 -- The closing of the P. Ballantine Sons Brewery, one of the major employers here, was announced today by the brewery's parent company, the Investors Funding Corporation.

The increasing entry of huge corporate conglomerates into farming has had one unintended but predictable effect -- a spur to the unionization of farm labor, most exploited segment of the American work force.

President Nixon's "journey for peace" has ended but American bombs are still falling throughout Indochina and Communist troops are still massing and maneuvering in South Vietnam for an expected offensive that could pose a formidable challenge to the Vietnamization program.

PASADENA, Calif., March 3 (UPI) -- Pioneer 10 cruised on a near-perfect course today in the beginning of a long-range picture-taking mission to Jupiter and responded flawlessly to radioed commands from earth.
The Kroehler Manufacturing Company has promoted Elmer A. Dagenais to executive vice president-manufacturing and Terrence L. Henderson to executive vice president-merchandising.

ROME, March 3 -- The neo-Fascist party, confident of achieving further advances in the general elections for the Senate and Chamber of Deputies on May 7 and 8, said today that it was considering participation in a right-wing alliance "on the government level."

It is generally agreed that neo-plasticism, the art style that sought a universal esthetic through simple, clear geometric abstraction and pure primary colors, was originated in 1917 under the impetus of the great painter Mondrian and came to an end as a consolidated movement in 1931.

With the U.N. Conference on the Human Environment scarcely fifteen weeks away, it is extremely distressing to learn (news story Feb. 8) that because East Germany is not invited to the conference, the Soviet Union and its eastern European allies are refusing to help prepare the draft documents and may refuse to participate at Stockholm.

ATHENS, March 3 -- One of three former members of Parliament invited to testify before United States Congressional subcommittees on making Pirteus a home port for the sixth fleet was informed today that he would not be allowed to leave Greece because he has a prison sentence pending.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 3 -- President Nixon today issued an Executive order establishing machinery to oversee and carry out all cotton agreements with some 20 nations, as well as an agreement last Oct. 15 setting over-all ceilings on textile imports from Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong.
MAN, W. V., March 3 (AP) -- Hope began to wane tody that many of the 94 persons still missing since the Buffalo Creek hollow flood would be found alive.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 3 -- President Zulfiker Ali Bhutto today dismissed the two military officers most responsible for putting him in power last December. He accused them of "Bonaparte" actions.

Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello lifted yesterday his order barring two major drug companies from doing business with the city because they had failed to comply with the city's antidiscrimination employment policy.

PARIS, March 31 -- In European investing circles -- far from the madding crowd at Broad and Wall -- there is an insistent refrain about our market that may be helpful to the small investor back in the United States.

ATLANTA, March 3 (AP) -- Representative Shirley Chisholm, campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination, urged members of a Spelman College audience today to run as delegates committed to her in state party delegate caucuses.

MOSCOW, March 3 -- Sheik Mujibur Rahman, Prime Minister of Bangladesh, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin of the Soviet Union signed a joint policy declaration here today, then traveled by air to Leningrad on the final stage of the Bengali leader's visit to the Soviet Union.

WEST POINT, N. Y., March 3 -- Harvard grabbed the early lead in the 39th annual national intercollegiate squash racquet championships today by advancing all six players in the three divisions into tomorrow's quarter-final round. Harvard had 24 points after three rounds.

WASHINGTON, March 2 -- Harry S. Truman's white frame house in Independence, Mo., has been the goal of pilgrimages by Democratic politicians who aspire to the Presidency ever since Mr. Truman left the White House in 1953.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The nation's unemployment rate declined in February for the second consecutive month and reached the lowest level since October, 1970, the Labor Department reported today.

Winter, banished by three days of sunny springlike weather, reasserted itself here yesterday in the form of rain, sleet, lightning, thunder and temperatures that plummeted to sub-freezing levels more than 40 degrees below the record-setting 70-degree temperatures of earlier in the week.

RABAT, Morocco, March 3 -- King Hassan II today accepted the resignation of the Cabinet led by Premier Mohammed Karim Lamrani and began consultations to form a "transitional" Cabinet that will hold legislative elections, due this summer.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The independent analyst hired by the Justice Department to write a report on the financial consequences of an antitrust action against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that he had dealt entirely with a key White House aide.

LONDON, March 3 -- Sir John Partridge, president of the British Confederation of Industry, today predicted a period of rapid expansion for the British economy, accompanied by a rise in living standards and a reduction in unemployment.

ROME, March 5 -- Roman Catholic laymen prayed and demonstrated today in support of a liberal Benedictine abbot whom the Vatican reportedly is seeking to remove from one of Rome's oldest basilicas.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- Mrs. Dita Davis Beard, the purported author of a memorandum linking the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's reported contribution to the 1972 Republican convention with settlement of three antitrust suits against the company, is one of the capital's thousands of lobbyists who work behind the scenes and make every effort to stay out of the public limelight.

Representative Bella S. Abzug showed up at Philharmonic Hall Saturday afternoon to tell the audience of the Cosmopolitan Young Peoples Symphony Orchestra that she thought there should be more events of the sort they were experiencing.

Alfred Brendel's performance of the great B flat Piano Sonata of Schubert yesterday afternoon at Hunter College Assembly Hall was extraordinary in every way. The Viennese artist gave it the musical density of a Beethoven work, which the Schubert is able to support.

Ignoring prognostications that they were supposed to lose, the German-Hungarians defeated New York Hota, the 1971 national soccer champion, 4-2, in the New York final of the United States Challenge Cup yesterday.

PASADENA, Calif. March 5 (UPI) -- Pioneer 10, the Jupiter-bound spacecraft, completed two critical maneuvers -- testing thrusters and turning on its "earth pointing system" -- early today, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced.

WASHINGTON -- Mother Nature on the Run, caterer of organic foods, has no illusions about the motive of most of its customers, establishment Washingtonians who occasionally turn from escargots and crepes to an evening of lentil soup and yogurt fruit salad.

MILWAUKEE -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey is on the move in Wisconsin, a state whose April 4 primary could demolish some of the dreams born of the balloting in New Hampshire and Florida this month.

Dean Dixon led the Washington National Symphony through its athletic hurdles yesterday afternoon in Philharmonic Hall; the assured performance proved that Mr. Dixon is a superior technician and that the National Symphony is becoming a major orchestra.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 5 -- Secretary General Waldheim has conveyed to member countries a proposal for the creation of a United Nations agency that would coordinate all elements of a worldwide attack on the causes of pollution of the environment.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- In 1895 an island 120 miles off the coast of China was ceded from a dying Chinese empire to what soon would be a swiftly expanding Japanese empire.

Decisions on many of the great issues facing the nation in the 1970's will be determined in this Presidential year by the debate of the candidates and the November vote. Nearly 400 Roman Catholics participated yesterday in a Melkite mass, the normal form of worship for millions of Eastern rite Catholics, but little more than a name to Western church-goers accustomed to the Latin rite.

MOSCOW, March 5 -- Private homeowners, sometimes overlooked and more often maligned despite their numbers in the Soviet Union, have won support from an unexpected quarter -- the Government newspaper Izvestia.

TRENTON, March 5 (AP) -- New Jersey has set up a "hot line" telephone number for any citizen to report a case of child abuse. The emergency, toll-free number is 800-452-9150.
WASHINGTON, March 5 -- For the nations of Southeast Asia, other than Vietnam, the communique issued at the end of President Nixon's trip to China contained both good and bad news.

Murray Perahia is scheduled to make his debut with the New York Philharmonic Friday, and if he plays Mozart's Piano concerto No. 17 as beautifully then as he did No. 21 Saturday night, it will be a debut to remember.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Census Bureau reported today a precipitious drop in the number of students attending private grade and high schools. Enrollment has plunged 23 per cent since 1965, the peak year.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The Construction Industry Stabilization Committee is withholding "hundreds" of deferred construction wage increases in order to impose noninflationary wage patterns on a city-by-city basis across the country, according to John Dunlop, chairman of the committee.

The uncommonly frank "Report to the People" issued recently by the City Health and Hospitals Corporation provides a dismaying insight into the magnitude of the problems the corporation inherited when it assumed responsibility for operating the municipal hospital system twenty months ago.

The night began slowly at the 24th Precinct. Surprising, for a Saturday. A teen-age boy came to retrieve his stolen motorcycle, an angry woman asked help in getting her TV set back from a repairman who had kept it 11 months, an elderly man forgot where his nursing home was.
HARTFORD, March 5 (UPI) -- Barbara Dunn, Connecticut Consumer Protection Commissioner, issued a warning today not to eat a Hormel brand of Genoa salami.
Pari-mutuel clerks protesting job cutbacks by the New York Racing Association have called a strike for today that will shut down Aqueduct Race Track.
Four teen-agers who allegedly beat and robbed four persons yesterday afternoon in Riverside Park were arrested after a chase in which policemen commandeered a Penn Central diesel locomotive.

LONDON, March 5 -- Prime Minister Dom Mintoff of Malta and Lord Carrington, Britain's Defense Secretary, resumed negotiations on allied use of bases on Malta here today. There was no major progress reported after six hours, and the talks are to continue tomorrow.

LONDON, March 5 -- A starkly modern rectangular edifice, clad in bronze and glass and featuring a roof garden and public piazza, has been chosen in a campetition for a new office building for Members of Parliament.

ATLANTA, March 5 -- Internes and resident physicians from hospitals across the country have decided to form a national organization, independent of the American Medical Association and other health groups, to work for sweeping changes in traditional ways of practicing medicine.
LOS ANGELES, March 5 (AP) -- Angela Davis's trial defense fund was $38,000 richer following a benefit here last night headlined by entertainers Sammy Davis Jr. and Aretha Franklin.

Despite a late scoring rampage against an unsteady goalie, the Rangers continued to look disorganized because of Jean Ratelle's absence as they gained a 6-1 decision last night over the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, March 5, (Reuters) -- Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said today he would introduce legislation tomorrow giving the Securities and Exchange Commission authority over a national clearing system for securities transactions.

MIAMI, March, 5 -- After interruptions by rain and lightning and a postponement of the fourth round until tomorrow, Jack Nicklaus and Lee Trevino shared the 54-hole lead today in the $150,000 Doral Eastern open with totals of 206.

WASHINGTON, March 5 -- The State Department has opened a diplomatic campaign within its own walls to raise the status of secretaries and to persuade their bosses not to regard them as housekeepers, office wives or "go-fers."

PITTSBURGH, March 5 -- Demand for domestic steel continued to rise last week. On the basis of recent orders, steel analysts were predicting a jump in shipments from 6.8 million tons in February to as high as 8.2 million tons in March.

Nearly 36 hours after running agound at the entrance of Port Jefferson Harbor, the 650-foot tanker Atlantic Endeavor was refloated on the high tide at 2 P.M. yesterday, relieving the immediate danger of an oil spill in that deep-water port on Long Island's North Shore.
More than 30 ballets to music by Igor Stravinsky, including 22 premieres, will be presented in a single week during the New York City Ballet's Stravinsky Festival at the State Theater June 18-25.

New York City students won the three top awards and five of the top 10 prizes yesterday in the 31st annual Westighouse Science Talent Search, a nationwide science-project competition that began last fall with more than 14,000 high school seniors participating.

MIAMI, March 6 -- On a day classified as cloudy but one that was bright and cheerful for him, Jack Nicklaus won the Doral Eastern open today by two strokes and became golf's all-time leading money winner.
