Two Bronx biochemists have found that the antibacterial chemical hexachlorophene interferes with the ability of brain cells to produce the energy they need to function properly.
Net income of the Allstate Insurance Company rose 33 per cent last year, the Sears, Roebuck Co. subsidiary disclosed yesterday.

Alert students of the television commercial may have noticed that one recent major advertising campaign has been revolving around the products of Bumble Bee Sea-foods. As one TV Spokesman puts it, some stations "have Bumble Bee coming out of your ears."
Investigation of the disputed autobiography of Howard Hughes accelerated toward a conclusion yesterday as three of the principal figures testified here before grand juries.
The stock market racked up another big gain yesterday in heavy trading.

The appointment of Charles P. Whitlock as dean of Harvard College was announced by Derek C. Bok, president of Harvard University. Dean Whitlock, who had been serving as acting dean, is a lecturer on social psychology who for more than 20 years has taught a series of Harvard courses dealing with interpersonal relations.
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Supermarkets, bottlers and soft drink manufacturers have combined forces in an effort to eliminate returnable bottles, the Senate Environment Subcommittee was told today.

MADRID, March 6 -- "It will be a magnificent chaos," a Cabinet minister predicted the other day about the wedding next Wednesday of Generalissimo Franco's eldest granddaughter to Don. Alfonso de Borb6n' y' Dampierre, a grandson ..of, Spain's late King, AlfonsO. XIII.
" Stand next to daddy's leg, honey," the photographer shouted.

MILWAUKEE, March 6 (AP) -- Kareem Abdul-Jabbar scored six of his 45 points in overtime tonight as the Milwaukee Bucks, down 16 points in the first period, stormed back for a 132-127 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.
The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a revised urban - renewal plan for the Two Bridges area in Lower Manhattan that will convert a 10 - block section into three superblocks.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate passed today, 62 to 10, the compromise bill giving enforcement powers for the first time to the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to move against job discrimination.

The catastrophe in Logan County, W. Va., was predicted. For the last ten years we have been warning of the dangers of slag piles, which emit sulphur-dioxide fumes and cause illness among women and children of the coal mining communities. We know this to be a cause of chemical bronchitis and pneumonitis, which is almost impossible to treat.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 6 -- A newspaper here quoted reliable Arab diplomatic sources today to the effect that Libya and the Soviet Union had concluded an arms deal under which the Libyans were to buy advanced Soviet offensive weapons for eventual delivery to Egypt.

TEL AVIV, March 6 -- Two secularists with personal stakes in the outcome of the forthcoming Israeli rabbinical election are Hanoch and Miriam Lange, a brother and sister. They have been labeled bastards by a rabbinical court, which makes them ineligible for marriage.

NEWARK, March 6 -- Ex-Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio was led in handcuffs today from the Federal Courthouse, just across the street from his former office in City Hall, to begin serving a 10-year prison term for extorting money from contractors.

ALBANY, March 6 -- Governor Rockefeller and leaders of the Legislature are studying a voluminous bill drafted by the New York Racing Association that would drastically overhaul the state's racing laws by consolidating the state's track and offtrack betting commissions and by absorbing New York City's Offtrack Betting Corporation.

An Eastern District High School student, Nestor Gonzales, said yesterday that a quote attributed to him in a New York Times article last Friday mistakenly implied that students were dissatisfied with the high school principal.
LONDON, March 6 (UPI) -- Moves to develop a strong and unified Common Market currency brought the dollar under renewed pressure in hectic trading on European foreign-currency exchanges today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- As the parliamentary traffic cop of the House of Representatives, William Meyers Colmer of Mississippi, the chairman of the House Rules Committee, has suffered from a split public image.

TAMPA, Fla., March 6 -- While Baltimore Colt football fans nervously wait to see if the other shoe will really drop, Tampa's pushy pigskin promoters unashamedly hope that it will. They even are ready to clutch it in tender embrace, cleats and all, in the event that the Maryland metropolis fails to keep a tight grip on its franchise.
St. Patrick's Day was celebrated 11 days early here yesterday.

With New Hampshire's Democratic primary sputtering out in a desultory questioning of the five candidates by a panel of local newsmen, one is prepared to share the hope of a Muskie staff man that this might be "the end of the debates" -- as these campaign shows are imaginatively called. Fatuous and anti-climactic, Sunday's televised performance recalled the Lincoln-Douglas exchanges only by the vividness of the contrast.
ALBANY, March 6 -- A bill that would have created a continuous learning year with schools open and children attending classes during the entire year, was defeated today in the Assembly, 104 to 29.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 6 -- Every four years since 1960, Presidential candidates have engaged in debate about debates. If only televised confrontations could be arranged, the electorate is assured, the ill-financed little guy could beat the machine; "the real issues" could be set before the public and a serious dialogue could begin.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz was primarily responsible for a January decision to kill a proposed Executive order regulating clear-cutting in Federal forests.

The Interstate Commerce Commission rejected yesterday a request of the railroads to impose general freight-rate increases April 1 on a selective basis averaging about 4.1 percent, which would gave grossed the rails about $500-million if fully applied.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The heart surgeon for Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Washington lobbyist, told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that she was suffering from periodic "distorted and irrational" behavior at the time she wrote a controversial memorandum about the Justice Department's settlement of three antitrust suits against the company.
ROME, March 6 -- A pro-Chinese faction of Italy's Communist party formally registered today its intention to present its own slates of candidates in the forthcoming general elections for Parliament.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 6 -- Dr. Harry Daniel Beery, a British Presbyterian missionary who has lived in Taiwan since 1950, left today for Hong Kong after having been given until tomorrow to leave the country.
Prices of corporate and tax-exempt bonds rose slightly yesterday in light trading activity; Government bonds declined a little.

The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, who was paroled two weeks ago from the Federal Correctional Institution in Danbury, Conn., said yesterday the prisoners there would continue their work stoppage until they won better conditions.
The State Attorney General's office filed a complaint with the State Division of Human Rights yesterday charging the New York Telephone Company with discriminating against women in its employ.

ALBANY, March 6 -- The Republican legislative leadership today disclosed the detailed Congressional redistricting plan that reduces New York City's delegation by two seats, creating dilemmas for some reformers and generally protecting organization incumbents.
WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the scope of the Government's authority to classify documents as secret and keep them from Congress and the public.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- The Senate Health subcommittee was told today that the cost of removing the lead paint hazard from all currently hazardous housing units could be as high as $14-billion and perhaps even higher.
ORLANDO, Fla., March 6 -- Much to Fred Beene's surprise, it didn't rain, the team bus didn't break down and Tinker Field didn't burn down.

LONDON, March 6 (Reuters) -- Britain has decided to refer to the International Court of Justice her dispute with Iceland over a proposal to extend Icelandic fishery limits to 50 nautical miles from 12 on Sept. 1.

Residents of the Chelsea-Clinton area on Manhattan's West Side jeered the chairman of the City Planning Commission, Donald H. Elliott, last night and denounced the city's blueprint for development of the waterfront neighborhood.

In one of the largest retail industry consolidations in some time, the McCrory Corporation and the J. J. Newberry Company announced yesterday that they flare agreed in principle on a merger. The proposed combination, which would require approval by shareholders of both companies, would create a $1.3-billion retail complex.
The Port Security Council said yesterday that cargo container thefts from New York and New Jersey pier areas were cut last year to a total of five with a value of about $250,000.
In recent years the number of advertising agencies that also offer a public-relations capability has been dwindling.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The current case involving the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is only the latest in a long series in which there have been charges that improper influence was exerted to achieve out-of-court settlements of antitrust suits.

The Clorox Company announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the business and assets of the Martin-Brower Corporation of Chicago through an exchange of common shares valued at about $48-million.
BOWIE, Md., March 6 (UPI) -- Frozen Delight ended a long losing streak with a three-quarter length victory in the $7,000-allowance feature race at seven furlongs today at Bowie Race Course.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, indicated to a group of city officials here today that he did not know when or whether the committee would approve revenue-sharing legislation.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that tests of new subway cars found them to be "well engineered and safe by any of the current standards."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (AP) -- Nearly a dozen United States fighter planes and MIG interceptors battled over North Vietnam today. American pilots reported downing one MIG in an exchange of at least eight air-to-air missiles.

TRENTON, March 6 -- A Cahill administration measure that would empower the state to make industries clean up their wastes before emptying them into public sewer systems was overwhelmingly approved today by the State Senate.

MANCHESTER, N. H., March 6 -- Aides of Senator George McGovern and Senator Edmund S. Muskie continued their bitter argument over campaign finance disclosures today as New Hampshire prepared to vote tomorrow in the state's Presidential primary, first in the nation.

MARBURG, West Germany -- The schools and universities in West Germany are in a state of greater chaos than existed at any time since freedom was restored to them at the end of World War II after the Nazis were crushed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, March 7 --Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green said today that he had assured South Vietnamese leaders that American policy toward Vietnam had not been affected by President Nixon's trip to China.

The National Economic Growth and Reconstruction Organization (NEGRO) said yesterday it would begin evacuating students from Public School 186 in West Harlem today because of unsafe conditions in the 71-year-old school.

A loud, clear boo greeted the performance of Mozart's Piano Quartet in E flat in the program of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at Tully Hall late Sunday afternoon. The reason for it was mystifying, since one of the composer's masterpieces had been given a first-class reading.

The Japanese Choreographer Kazuko Hirabayashi, who is giving a season at the Japan House Auditorium, 333 East 47th Street that continues until Friday of this week, has a distinct and distinctive talent. Last night she gave the world premiere of "Suite I," a solo for Lance Westergard, and repeated "Mudai" and "The Stone Garden."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 6 (Reuters) -- The Mayor has ordered all bars in downtown Saigon and Cholon closed on instructions from President Nguyen Van Thieu.

William V. Shannon in his Feb. 28 column "Of Hope and Fear" begins writing an analysis of the chances of the Democratic candidates and winds up with an editorial in favor of Senator Muskie. Senator Jackson he finds too "Hobbesian," Senator McGovern "the candidate of hope" while Senator Muskie is "centrist," which one might assume is just the right mixture of emotion a candidate should have blended into his psyche.

SAN JOSE, Calif., March 6 -- Earl Caldwell, a correspondent of The New York Times, was arrested on a charge of possession of marijuana today by Santa Clara County sheriff's deputies outside the courtroom where Angela Davis is on trial.

Steel production in the week ended March 4 rose by 2 per cent, to 2,487,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This compared with 2,439,000 tons poured the week before.

MOSCOW, March 6 -- Soviet Georgia, hit by a major new scandal involving an illegal private enterprise network run by an underground millionaire, was accused by the Kremlin today of lax ideological and economic ways, signaling a crackdown.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- Representative William M. Colmer of Mississippi, the 82-year-old conservative chairman of the House Rules Committee, announced today that he would not seek another term in Congress.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 6 -- Fifty-two persons, most of them women shoppers and office workers, were injured here today when a bomb exploded in a parking lot behind a movie theater.
Large crowds were attracted yesterday to the start of the going-out-of-business sale at the 17 Broadstreet's and Weber Heilbroner stores in the New York metropolitan area.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 6 -- Prime Minister William McMahon has declared that Australia will seek to broaden relations with mainland China through a new diplomatic mission to be established by this country in Hong Kong.

Price increases covering various paper, metal and chemical products were announced by several companies yesterday.

The value-added tax now under active consideration by the Nixon Administration is, even as taxes go, a bad tax. Although it is to be imposed on business, the tax is expected to be passed on eventually to the consumer. If implemented, it will become in effect a national sales tax with all the regressive features of such a tax.

The Irving Trust Company has elected Anthony Rendino senior vice president.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 -- The New York Mets learned today that Jim Fregosi -- for whom they traded four players this winter -- had broken his right thumb and probably would miss the rest of spring training.
MILWAUKEE, March 6 -- Mrs. Gertrude Raasch, whose decision to refuse an operation was upheld by a county judge six weeks ago, died today.

The late Martin Tananbaum, who was president of Yonkers Raceway and long a powerful figure in Democratic party circles, was named here yesterday as "the big man" behind an Albany businessman who was accused of trying to bribe three Assemblymen to vote for legislation that would greatly benefit harness tracks.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 6 -- Secretary General Waldheim began talks with the Government here today on the question of South Africa's continued control over the disputed territory of South-West Africa.

The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its fourth quarter earnings increased by 15 per cent from the year-earlier period. The company's sales and earnings for all of 1971 were its highest record.

LORDSTOWN, Ohio, March 6 -- The plant where General Motors has placed its hopes of meeting foreign competition was closed today by striking workers who contend that management is forcing them to work too hard and too fast in an effort to cut costs.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- A gloomy picture of a white-controlled communications industry that ignores or distorts the true needs, aspirations, problems and life styles of black Americans was painted for the Congressional Black Caucus today.

MILWAUKEE, March 6 -- Mrs. Gertrude Raasch, whose decision to refuse an operation was upheld by a county judge six weeks ago, died today.

WASHINGTON, March 6 -- The proposed merger of the National and American Basketball Associations was attacked from three directors today by the National Football League Players Association, a former owner of the Boston Celtics and Bill Bradley of the New York Knicks.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 6 -- California's Attorney General, Evelle Younger, has now opened a legal battle to overcome the recent state Supreme Court ruling that the death penalty may no longer be imposed in California. WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty attacked "stamp-happy" bureaucrats and George Reedy questioned the growth of White House staff operations as new hearings began today on Government secrecy policies.

LONDON, March 6 (AP) -- The Manchester United soccer team signed Ian Moore for a reported $520,000 tonight, completing a three-team transfer tangle.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers asserted today that he and the State Department had played "an essential and important role in the formulation and execution" of foreign policy in the Nixon Administration.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- By the end of the Yankees' 14-9 exhibition victory over the Texas Rangers today, so many positive things had happened it was almost easy to forget what had happened to Lindy McDaniel.
Contemporary American music will be the subject of the Brooklyn Philharmonic's third Marathon, which is to be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Saturday from 6 P.M. to 10:30 P.M.
ROME, March 7 -- Some married man use private codes when they call girl friends, Many Italians open their first phone calls of the day with a sarcastic "Good morning, Mr. Spy."

Of course, the Knicks beat the Milwaukee Bucks last night at Madison Square Garden. Almost from a sense of habit -- but with a huge contribution from Jerry Lucas -- the Knicks rode to a 110-101 triumph that so delighted the capacity crowd of 19,588, the fans serenaded the Bucks in the final minute with a few lines of "Good night, Lewis, we hate to see you go."

WASHINGTON, March 7 -The Federal Reserve Board recommended to Congress today that the President be given the authority to vary upward or downward the business-investment tax credit as "the most important single contribution that could be made to easing the plight of the housing industry in recurring periods of credit restriction."
A majority of American corporations pushed ahead to strong profit gains in 1971, a year of economic strain and slow recovery from the recession of 1970.

BASEL, Switzerland, March 7 (AP) -- The Swiss manufacturer of the drug imipramine denied today that there was any hard evidence that its product caused deformities in unborn children but pledged to study questions raised about the drug.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 7 -- Three American journalists who accompanied President Nixon to China arrived here this week, uncertain about their welcome and determined to leave immediately if any attempt was made to confiscate the Communist publications they had picked up.
Mike and Jerry Quarry sparred three rounds in the Felt Forum yesterday as Mike continued preparation for a 10-round light-heavy- weight bout Friday night in Madison Square Garden with Tommy Hicks.
Musical chairs among pro football's assistant coaches continued yesterday when Dick Voris joined the Detroit Lions after having quit the St. Louis Cardinals on Monday "to pursue other opportunities."
PARIS, March 7 -- A Bronx rabbi charged here today that the North Vietnamese had gone back on a promise to allow him to meet and conduct services with Jewish prisoners of war.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 7 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Chow Shu-kai said today that Nationalist China was interested in contacts with Communist nations "if they are not the puppets of Communist China."

La Salle's distance medley team got what it wanted, Kevin McCarey just missed what he wanted and Dave Law wasn't expecting what he got last night at the seventh annual Eastern States schoolboy indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Negotiations focused on pensions as bargaining between Transport of New Jersey and eight locals of the Amalgamated Transit Union resumed yesterday for the first time since 4,500 drivers and other workers went on strike against the private bus company last Wednesday.

TOKYO -- Emperor Hirohito, a mild-mannered, soft-spoken little man with greying hair and mustache and weak eyes shielded by rimless spectacles, is obviously by instinct a retiring, modest intellectual with a keen interest in the countryside and a passion for marine biology and botany.
TOKYO, March 7 -- Emperor Hirohito has said that he would be very pleased if President Nixon paid an official visit to Japan.

State Senator Waldaba Stewart predicted yesterday that the first National Black Convention, which opens Friday in Gary, Ind., would not endorse Representative Shirley Chisholm or any other black Presidential candidate.

" A Celebration of Richard Rodgers," a one-performance, all-star musical tribute to the Broadway composer, will be presented at the Imperial Theater on March 26 under the auspices of the Friends of the Theater and Music Collection of the Museum of the City of New York.

NORFOLK, Va., March 7 (AP) -- The city of Norfolk was told by a Federal appeals court today that it must provide free transportation to pupils who are being bused beyond "a reasonable walking distance" of their homes under a courtordered school desegregation plan.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The House Banking Committee approved a dollar-devaluation bill today in exactly the form requested by President Nixon. The action paved the way for final Congressional action next week.

The City University of New York started in 1847 as the first and only open-admissions university in the United States. At that time the public-spirited citizens of New York City began the tradition of free tuition by voting for it by a margin of more than six to one in a referendum authorized by the State Legislature.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 7 -- Premier Saeb Salam disclosed today that Lebanon had received another warning from Israel and that the Government was thinking of taking the matter to the United Nations Security Council.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that the Civil Service system "constantly needs re-examination" because "it locks people out," and predicted that the city's ethnic survey would shed light on those who were excluded.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The Republican chairmen of the Conservation Committees of both houses of the Legislature plan to propose a $1.2-billion environment bond issue tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., chief of naval operations, warned a Congressional panel today that the nation was extracting "inhuman sacrifices" from seamen and airmen serving aboard the nation's 17 active aircraft carriers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- The New York Mets gained their second straight exhibition-game triumph today with a 9-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers, who proved their point: Detroit needs pitching to overtake the Baltimore Orioles in the American League.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Senate failed today to set a rigid ceiling on the amount of money the Federal Government can spend in the fiscal year 1973 that begins July 1.

GENEVA, March 7 -- Calls by the United States, the European Economic Community and Japan for mounting a major international assault on trade barriers in 1973 won the endorsement today of other industrialized nations.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -John N. Nassikas, chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today that, if necessary, the commission would ask the Supreme Court to review a lower court's decision that the commission was not in compliance with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, March 8 -- Amid reports of continuing heavy American air strikes on North Vietnam, the United States command here said today that it would no longer disclose information on the number of American aircraft involved in the raids.

Clifford Odets, acclaimed in the mid-thirties as "a new dramatist of exciting possibilities" for his plays of social unrest, is enjoying a post-mortem revival as an exciting playwright of the early seventies for his plays of psychological perception.

Wearing the floppy, feathered hat that has become her trademark, Representative Bella S. Abzug yesterday denounced the "maledominated" State Legislature's plans to remap her 19th Congressional District and vowed that "whatever happens, I shall run for reelection."
The stock market, as viewed yesterday by two managers of brokerage branch offices in mid-Manhattan, is getting a bit more bubbly, but signs of customer speculation remain relatively sparse.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- President Nixon said today that he had gone to China because he hoped to promote the proposition that peoples of different views "can live together rather than die together."
FLINT, Mich., March 7 -- To make his voice for racial harmony heard, Paul L. Cabell Jr., frustrated and discouraged, put a shotgun to his head and pulled the trigger.

The tax-exempt securities market, reflecting a current preference either for high longterm yields or for short-term securities, quickly absorbed yesterday a large volume of notes and medium-quality bonds.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 7 -The future of 100 business corporations that are the last reserve of large private enterprise in Chile has become the most serious political issue here since President Salvador Allende Gossens took office 16 months ago.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Former Gov. Louie B. Nunn of Kentucky testified today that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell refused to discuss the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's antitrust problems with Dita D. Beard, a lobbyist, at a Kentucky Derby party.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Health insurance companies have misspent millions of Medicare dollars, Federal auditors report, because of business inefficiencies and excess payments to doctors.

France's chief judicial expert on narcotics smuggling arrived here yesterday to seek information from and about a Frenchman who has pleaded guilty to smuggling $12-million worth of heroin from France to New Jersey.
James C. Lehrer, news director of public television station KERA in Dallas, has been named to the new post of public affairs coordinator for the Public Broadcasting Service.

A key prosecution witness maintained under cross-examination in Federal Court here yesterday that he had helped sell stolen United States Treasury bills under instructions from former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler.

Largely because of faulty enrollment estimates by the decentralized community school districts, the Board of Education will have to reallocate $4.6-million in authorized operating funds among the districts.

The program presented by Janita Byars Monday night in Carnegie Recital Hall, each piece built around Miss Byars's live clarinet and recorded tape, would have been impossible a few years ago. By now, however, there is quite a sizable repertory available for instruments and electronic accompaniment.

A $55-million suit was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court by Mrs. Mary Lake, alleging a conspiracy in the 1968 auction of a painting of hers for $325, a work later authenticated as a valuable lost portrait by Raphael.

Mayor Lindsay attempted yesterday to cool the bitter controversy that has led to clashes in the last few days between Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy and members of the Police and Fire Departments.

UNIONDALE, L. I., March 7 -- Although they displayed an oportunistic defense that kept the Kentucky Colonels off balance most of the time, the Nets were unable to muster a consistent offense and were worn down by the taller visitors, 117-112, in overtime tonight.

An American columnist who accompanied President Nixon to China and is still there reports that Chinese and North Vietnamese leaders recently reached a short-lived agreement that Premier Pham Van Dong of North Vietnam "would go to Paris to push the peace negotiations with the United States."

Many non-bridge-playing wives had the task at Christmas of finding suitable gifts for bridge-playing husbands. RANDOLPH, Vt., March 7 (UPI) -- President Nixon received 407 of the 772 votes cast here today to win what was believed to be the nation's only municipal Presidential primary.

Americans and Britons are close in many ways, but they are worlds apart.

MADRID, March 8 (UPI) -Spanish bishops today gave Vicente Cardinal Enrique y Tarancon, leader of the reform movement, a resounding vote of confidence and then called for the resignation of two highly placed Vatican conservatives who tried to weaken his position.

Arthur Thompson, a baritone who was presented in his New York debut in 1967 by Young Concert Artists, returned for another appearance under that organization's sponsorship on Monday night. In a recital at Town Hall, Mr. Thompson was assisted by Elizabeth Wright, pianist, and a string quartet headed by Rolf Schulte.

GORDON, Neb., March 7 (AP)--A band of Indians established at 12-member "grand jury" today to investigate the death of Raymond Yellow Thunder and vowed to remain in this Nebraska Sand Hills community of 2,106 persons pending the outcome of a new autopsy.

GENEVA, March 7 -- Italy urged other members of the Geneva disarmament conference today to join in issuing a unanimous invitation to China and France to participate in the negotiations as soon as possible."

The city of Aachen, West Germany, annually gives its Charlemagne Prize, worth $1,560, to a person who has furthered European unity. In this area, up until the last two weeks or so, excellent dining has been easier to find than excellent snow conditions.
The Police Department issued yesterday an artist's composite sketch of a man wanted for the rape-slaying of a young receptionist.

QUITO, Ecuador, March 8 -The new military Government of Ecuador has spent most of its first 22 days in office drafting plans for economic and social change that imply an indefinite stay in power.

The West Coast's most active bridge expert, who plays, writes and teaches with equal enthusiasm and ability, has recently completed two books of importance to all serious students of the game. One is "Bridge Conventions" (106 pages, $4) and the other is "Bridge Bidding Made Easy" (256 pages, $5).

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation asserted yesterday that Mrs. Dita D. Beard, the lobbyist who wrote a memorandum involving an antitrust settlement and a contribution to the Republican National Convention, was summoned to the company's New York headquarters the day the memorandum was made public.
Three large retail chains reported yesterday higher sales in February compared with the year-earlier month.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 8 -- Attorney General Evelle Younger is convinced that the California Supreme Court's decision to abolish the death penalty was an effort to "lobby" the Federal Supreme Court, which is considering the same issue. Therefore, Mr. Younger is asking visitors these days, why shouldn't nine million California voters try to "lobby" the high court in the other direction, by a referendum vote?

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Soviet Union has politely turned down offers of assistance from the Secretary of State and the Chief of Naval Operations for a nuclear-powered missile submarine that is in mechanical trouble off Newfoundland, official sources say.

Griswold told the Senate Judiciary Committee today that if the Government had not settled its three anti-merger suits against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, it would, he believed, have lost all three of them in the Supreme Court.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 9 -- Boyd F. Douglas Jr. admitted under cross-examination today that he posed as a "popitical prisoner" while gathering information about an alleged conspiracy by priests and nuns to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, the Presidential aide.
CHICAGO, March 9 -- A permanent exposition facility to display and demonstrate materials for the $70-billion-a-year education industry was formally opened here today.

Harold Sydney Geneen, a 62-year-old British-born naturalized citizen, has built a reputation as one of the toughest corporate chiefs in American industry and has been periodically under fire for his business tactics since he took command as president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation 12 years ago.

Governor Rockefeller is reported to be hesitant about urging a projected $1.2-billion environmental bond issue so soon after the voters rejected his transportation bond issue last fall. Essentially sympathetic to the plan, he should take courage; there is a world of difference between the two proposals.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Legislation that would almost double Federal spending on heart, lung and blood diseases was introduced today by Congressional leaders in the health field.
TOKYO, March 8 -- Premier Eisaku Sato of Japan predicted today that China would voluntarily limit her support of the Vietnamese Communists as a result of President Nixon's discussions in Peking.

Fordham readied itself for the National Invitation Tournament last night by outlasting Manhattan College, 91-84, in the second game of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden. The game was one of those old-fashioned New York rivalries with a victory and neighborhood pride at stake.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -The Price Commission announced today new regulations providing relief from price controls for companies incurring losses or low profits.

UNIONDALE, L. I., March 9 -- Who needs Rick Barry? Not the New York Nets tonight as they rolled to a 113-99 American Basketball Association victory over the Virginia Squires with Barry watching the game from the bench along with a crowd of 6,873 at the Nassau Coliseum.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP) -- United States fighter-bombers raided antiaircraft positions in North Vietnam yesterday for the eighth successive day, the United States command reported today.

TRENTON, March 10 -- New Jersey insurance officials have drafted a regulation that would require all mail-order health insurance companies doing business in New Jersey to submit their advertising to the State before it could appear in newspapers or other media.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -Dita D. Beard, a Washington lobbyist, was quoted today as having said that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell had told her that President Nixon ordered him to "make a reasonable settlement" of three antitrust cases against the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

The authenticity of a published memoir -- a best-seller here and abroad -- by a man claiming to be a 101-year-old Sioux chief is being seriously questioned by some of the country's leading authorities on American Indians and challenged in a lawsuit charging plagiarism.

DALLAS, March 9 (UPI) -- Top-seeded Evonne Goolagong rallied from a 5-3 deficit in the second set tonight to defeat Helen Gourlay, 6-3, 7-6, and move into the quarterfinals of the $30,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament.

Two restaurants in the Pan Am Building, the Trattoria and the Zum Zum, were among 42 food establishments cited yesterday by the city's Health Services Administration as having serious violations of the city's Health Code.

Complaining that it was being asked to "rubber stamp" $3-million for narcotics programs on the basis of scanty information, a coalition on the Board of Estimate forced the Lindsay administration yesterday to postpone approval of contracts for 14 programs.

WASHINGTON -- In a recent column on this page I provided an assessment of the Army as it is today and mentioned briefly some of the measures we are taking to revitalize it as we enter the post-Vietnam era.
George A. Oberle and Robert J. Pedovano have been elected first vice presidents of Walston Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange.

HONG KONG, Friday, March 10 -Peking today made its first attack on "U.S. imperialism" since President Nixon's visit to China by issuing a strong, for real denunciation of recent American bombings of North Vietnam and reiterating all-out support for Communist-led forces in Indochina.

If there is any doubt about the attitude of former Assistant Attorney General Richard McLaren toward vigorous enforcement of the antitrust laws against I.T.T., there certainly was none in the mind of I.T.T.'s top lawyer Howard J. Aibel.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 9 (AP) -- The United States military command, in a reversal of long-established practice, refused today to permit the daily war briefing to be filmed by television cameras.
Ten letters by Ernest Hemingway, Nobel and Pulitzer Prize novelist, were auctioned last night for $5,875 in a sale of literary and historical material at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

The chairman of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers yesterday rejected suggestions that the United States should raise interest rates to protect the international value of the dollar.
The Legislature was urged yesterday by 66 of its members to undertake a statewide study of whether to do away with public-transit fares because of declining ridership and revenues.

DACCA, Bangladesh March 9 (AP) -- A French-Canadian priest, the Rev. Benjamin Labbe, is here as director of the Christian Organization for Relief and Rehabilitation. Over his desk hangs a sign reading, "God bless this mess."
SAN JOSE, Calif., March 9 -- A jury was nearly seated today for the trial of Angela Davis.

The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the parent company of the nation's third-largest bank, is "actively considering" a "spin-out" of its $12-billion investment management business, Herbert P. Patterson, president of the company, said yesterday.
A new city program to identify New Yorkers with high blood pressure and refer them for treatment was announced yesterday by Health Services Administrator Gordon Chase.
Beginning this month, the International Game Fish Association is establishing a new category for world record marine fish in the six-pound line test class.

The Brooklyn Blue Busters, a blues band formed a year ago in emulation of Chicago's Electric Blues Band, has advanced in that time from playing in what the band then said was the only blues club in Brooklyn, the Night Cap, to what it now says is the only blues club in Manhattan.
When the Morton Greenbergs decided to move to suburbia in 1969, their longtime friends, Jesse and Lola Meyers spent many hours trying to persuade them not to give up the good life of the city.

SAN DIEGO, March 9 -- San Diego Republicans, who helped to arrange International Telephone and Telegraph's $400,000 financing guarantee for next summer's Republican National Convention, are coming under strong pressure from party leaders in Washington to cancel the deal as quickly as possible.
An art dealer testified in Federal Court here yesterday that he had acted for Seymour R. Thaler in cashing $250,000 in United States Treasury bills that were stolen from a Wall Street bank.

The new president of the United Service Organizations is Maj. Gen. Francis L. Sampson, who retired last year as Army chief of chaplains. General Sampson succeeds Gen. Emmett (Rosy) O'Donnell, who died in December.
MIAMI, March 9 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie proposed a comprehensive reform of the Federal tax structure tonight as he campaigned here for support in Florida's Democratic Presidential primary.

New faces appear each year on the University of California, Los Angeles, basketball team to surpass the accomplishments of their predecessors, who were stamped "irreplaceable" by all but their coach, John Wooden. And each year this master director melds the new with the experienced to produce the National Collegiate Athletic Association championship team through discipline, pressure defense and speed that exceed anything seen in college basketball.
DETROIT, March 9 -- A sheriff's deputy was killed and three deputies were wounded early this morning by gunfire when three policemen burst into an apartment where five deputies were playing cards.

The last period of Wednesday night's hockey game at Madison Square Garden was delayed by a 14-minute rhubarb over illegal equipment -- the glove used by Glen Sather of the Rangers and two sticks used by Dennis Hull of the Chicago Black Hawks.
Foreign central banks added at least $196-million to their swollen holdings of United States dollars in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

MIAMI, March 9 -- Senator Vance Hartke of Indiana has all but decided to end his active pursuit of the Democratic Presidential nomination, sources in Washington and in the Senator's home state reported tonight.

WASHINGTON -- I have devoted my life to public service as mayor of a great city, as a leader in the United States Senate, as Vice President of the United States. I have come to know this nation, its problems and its people as few candidates have.

SHANGHAI, China, March 9 -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Chief of State of Cambodia, said today that Premier Chou En-lai of China had met North Vietnamese leaders since President Nixon's visit and assured them of China's full support "until total victory."
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Friday, March 10 (UPI) -- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek accepted nomination today for a fifth six-year term as President of the Government of Nationalist China.
BOSTON, March 9 -- Barring a legal or financial miracle, a venerable but tarnished journalistic institution known as The Boston Herald Traveler appears to be heading for extinction.
The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation, one of the biggest names in direct mail, has added something to its envelope of tricks.
The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday it may need to raise funds overseas this year.
The American Press Institute plans to break ground this year for its home in Reston, Va., outside Washington.
TEL AVIV, March 9 -- Israeli jets renewed their raids across the Lebanese border today after an eight-day interlude, an Israeli spokesman said.
SEATTLE, March 9 (AP) -- Spencer Haywood of the Seattle SuperSonics will be out for the rest of the season with a knee injury, the National Basketball Association club said today.
The White House announced yesterday that President Nixon had signed a proclamation that would have the effect of raising the United States meat-import quota for 1972 by 7 per cent.

Clifford Irving's notorious "autobiography" of Howard R. Hughes was officially discredited yesterday as the expatriate author, his wife, Edith, and his researcher, Richard Suskind, were indicted here on criminal charges.

" Luminous Procuress," which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum, is the work of a young West Coast filmmaker named Steven Arnold.

The city's Human Resources Administrator, Jule M. Sugarman, announced yesterday that the Department of Social Services had begun the recovery of more than $3.6-million lost last year through fraudulent cashing of duplicate welfare checks.

BONN, March 9 -- Chancellor Willy Brandt expressed confidence today through a spokesman that his 1970 treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland would attain the necessary majority of the membership of the 496-member lower house of Parliament.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -- Joseph H. Hirshhorn has given 326 additional works of art to the museum here that will bear his name.

Walter Hopps, director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington, has been named by the Smithsonian Institution to organize the United States exhibition at this year's Venice Biennale, opening June 11.
WASHINGTON, March 9 -President Nixon ordered all airlines today to adopt new and tighter security measures immediately to prevent the sabotage of American commercial aircraft.

TOKYO, March 9 (AP) -Kohei Matsuda, president of the Toyo Kogyo Company, Japan's third largest auto maker, said today that his company and the Ford Motor Company had agreed to terminate their three-year-old negotiations on a capital tie-up.

WASHINGTON, March 9 -- The Peace Corps, which has been threatened with Congressional cuts in its budget, was assured by the White House today that it would receive the funds it needs to continue operating at its present level.

TOKYO -- As a consequence of the implied shift in Asian relationships featured by President Nixon's Peking visit, Japan now finds itself in the delightful position of being simultaneously courted by all three superpowers, the United States, Russia and China.

A furor is brewing over the closing of private animal shelter in Woodhave, Queens, from which 81 dogs were carted away Tuesday by the Board of Health and the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

The strike of the Independent Association of Mutuel Clerks against the New York Racing Association continues and there will be no racing again today at Aqueduct.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation announced three related price moves yesterday that the company said will affect products accounting for more than 50 per cent of the aluminum sheet markets.
In France, the banks not only handle investment portfolios for wealthy clients but also operate mutual funds -- something that the banks in this nation would like to do.
The Federal Communications Commission approved yesterday, by a 4-to-2 vote, the sale of five television stations by Time-Life Broadcast, Inc. to McGraw-Hill, Inc., for $69.3-million.

The tally on how dockworkers from Maine to Texas voted on a new contract Wednesday continued to trickle into International Longshoremen's Association headquarters here yesterday. In general, they showed that union members on the South Atlantic and Gulf Coasts were heavily in favor of the agreement. Philadelphia, however, joined Baltimore in rejecting the contract. In terms of cash increases, the agreement is the best the union has ever negotiated.
Many of the statements that have been made regarding the I.T.T. consent judgment show how few Americans understand the entire situation. Consent judgments are not "sellouts."
PARIS, March 9 -- Art is being brought to the strap-hanging masses this month with 14 sculptors exhibitng their avant-garde work in a subway station.
Before a large group of well-wishers, many of them skiing personalities, Lowell Thomas received the Coronet Skiing Award at a luncheon yesterday at Gallaghers on West 52d Street.

BERLIN, March 9 -- The East German Parliament passed a bill today allowing free abortion on demand within the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.

DALLAS, March 10 (AP) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King shattered hopes of a dream match between the Wimbledon champion, Evonne Goolagong, and Chris Evert of the United States tonight by defeating the 17-year-old Miss Evert in the Maureen Connolly Brinker international tennis tournament.

MADRID, March 10 -- The alliance of liberals and moderates that has swept to power among Spain's bishops this week received a rare public endorsement today from the Papal Nuncio, Msgr. Luigi Dadaglio.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- The Selective Service told local draft boards today that they could resume hearing the appeals of thousands of young men seeking deferments or exemptions.

Scripts, photographs, scrapbooks, posters and other papers belonging to Bert Lahr, who died in 1967 at the age of 72, were given yesterday to the Research Library of the Performing Arts, the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center.

WHITE PLAINS, March 10 -- To people who do not live in Westchester County, the title "Sheriff of Westchester" may conjure up an image that is quaint or even amusing. The county's residents know better.

The University of Michigan students who are engaged in a scholarly experiment to determine whether "cohabitation" can break down the sociological and psychological barriers between the sexes have expressed surprise that their devotion to research is considered newsworthy. A rise in the price of frozen boneless beef futures yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange was attributed by traders to Thursday's Presidential proclamation that would raise the United States meat-import quota by 7 per cent. Most of the increased imports would be frozen boneless beef.

GARY, Ind., March 10 -- The First National Black Political Convention, opening here today, was likened to "the rounding of both the Republican and the Democratic parties" by Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan.
The Dow Chemical Company announced yesterday that it was raising the price of liquid caustic soda by $5 a ton for customers buying the product at rates below published list prices.

At heart in the pending controversy over the rights of Congress vs. the courts to define the required extent of school busing for racial balance is a definition of the powers of Congress vs. the powers of the judiciary. In recent years, particularly among intellectuals, fundamental changes in attitude toward the judiciary have occurred.

Somehow, as one follows the debate on whether to bus or not bus children to achieve a racial mix (for whatever reason), there emerges a nightmarish quality to this volatile issue. Columnists, editorial writers, educators, legislators and jurists batter opponents of busing with the necessity -- nay, the unswerving duty of the Republic -- of establishing a virtual racial quota for each component of the public school system.

Out of the western migrations of the 1840's with their body killing experiences, George Keithley has made a lean, taut, narrative poem that moves with the speed and terseness of a killer shark, and William Mulvihill a tidy novella that combines bloody adventure and overt symbolism in a neat mixture of its own.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz announced yesterday what he called a "broad and comprehensive" investigation into the infiltration of the securities industry by organized crime.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The chairmen of two Congressional economic committees urged President Nixon today to reform his economic stabilization program and enforce it more effectively.

DETROIT, March 10 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered the Ford Motor Company to consider two resolutions submitted by the Project on Corporate Responsibility at its May 11 stockholders' meeting.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 10 (UPI) -- North Carolina and Maryland scored semifinal victories in the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament tonight to set up a championship showdown tomorrow night.

For many readers, rhetoric is always dishonest or specious, innocuous at best, always the decoration of falsehood for its acceptance as truth. By "rhetoric" we often mean "bad rhetoric," confusing the proper and the pejorated meanings, the art and the perversion of itself.

After playing the life out of the Brahms D minor Piano Concerto Thursday night in Philharmonic Hall, Rudolf Serkin found his evening was not yet over. A microphone was set up, and out came Amyas Ames, chairman of the board of the New York Philharmonic.

BERLIN, March 10 -- East and West Gemany reported progress today in their talks toward achieving a general traffic agreement between the two countries.

Two teen-agers who allegedly stole one car, banged into five others and almost ran over two policemen in a 70-mile-an-hour chase yesterday in Brooklyn proved no match for a police helicopter that followed them until they were captured.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 10 (UPI) -- Chris Blocker, a suntanned Texan with a sizzling putter, virtually ran away from the rest of the Citrus open golf field today. He carded a six-under-par 66 and gained a four-stroke lead in the second round of the $150,000 tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The nation's airlines began tightening airport security today to comply with an emergency order from President Nixon as Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe met with airline representatives to explain the new rules.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 10 -- A paratrooper who said he fired 19 shots through a frosted glass window at a silhouette of a gunman standing behind the window was challenged today by a lawyer who said there were no bullet holes in the building.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 10 -- Ben Chaney Jr., a brother of James E. Chaney, the slain civil rights worker, was found guilty today of first-degree murder in connection with the death of two Florida Atlantic University students.

A Federal judge rejected yesterday so-called "class action" status for a suit against the Chemical Bank involving charges that it engaged in illegal reciprocal business practices in its trust department.

The New York State Banking Department, in a move designed to open a loophole in the Federal Bank Holding Company Act, has introduced legislation in Albany designed to allow bank holding companies headquartered in other states to acquire banks here -- provided those states grant reciprocal privileges to New York companies.

McGraw-Hill, Inc., has agreed to pay damages to the estate of a former superintendent of the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, portions of whose book on the Wounded Knee massacre were used in "The Memoirs of Chief Red Fox," a best seller published by the company last March.

SPOLETO, Italy, March 7 -- Tradition here has it that before the pagans cut off St. Ponziano's head in A.D. 175 he declared: "Spoleto tremera ma non cadra" ("Spoleto will shake but not fall").

James P. Garvey has been elected a corporate vice president of Burlington Industries, Inc., and named president of Burlington Factoring. He succeeds Charles A. Kelly, who will serve in a consultant and advisory capacity until his retirement at the end of the company's fiscal year in September.

Mike Quarry of Anaheim, Calif., the second-ranked light-heavyweight contender, easily won a unanimous 10-round decision over Tommy Hicks, 10th-ranked, before a paying crowd of 5,000 at Madison Square Garden last night.

VIENNA, March 10 -- Walter Dejaco, the former Nazi architect who designed and built the Auschwitz gas chambers and cremation furnaces in which three million Jews died, was acquitted of murder and released from custody here today.

MIAMI, March 10 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, who has been energetically stumping the cities and backwaters of Florida for the last three weeks, expressed confidence today that he would be among the top finishers in Tuesday's Democratic primary election.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Representative William S. Moorhead, chairman of a House subcommittee on Government information, criticized today President Nixon's new Executive order on secrecy in national security papers, calling it "a very restrictive document."

W. R. Grace Co. realized a 30.5 per cent increase in 1971 net income, but earnings before extraordinary charges were off 8.6 per cent from the year before, the international industrial concern reported yesterday.
TEL AVIV., March 10 -- Two jet fighters, identified as MIG-23's flew over Israeli positions in the occupied Sinai Peninsula today, military headquarters here reported.
POMPANO BEACH, Fla. March 10 -- Spring training is the time when baseball players practice for the season. Managers have to get ready, too, and today Ralph Houk practiced protesting a game.

DETROIT, March 10 -- An organization of black policemen today began a campaign to disband a special police unit, three of whose members were involved in the shooting here yesterday that led to the death of a deputy sheriff and the wounding of three others.

A Brooklyn assistant district attorney charged with falling to prosecute the case of a city correction officer arrested for the possession of more than $200,000 of cocaine submitted his resignation yesterday.

Murray Perahia has been a busy pianist recently. A week ago he played concertos by Chopin and Mozart with the Musica Aeterna Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, and yesterday afternoon, at Philharmonic Hall, he made his New York Philharmonic debut playing Mozart's Concerto in G (K. 453).

The most frequently reported crime of violence in the city -- robbery -- showed a sharp decline in January over the same period a year ago, while the number of murder, rape and assault cases rose sharply, Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy reported yeterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, March 11 (AP) -- A South Vietnamese armored force of about 5,000 troops and 100 vehicles swept into eastern Cambodia yesterday in an attempt to prevent enemy attacks on the approaches to Saigon. It was the first major drive into eastern Cambodia since Nov. 22.
Three Bengali sailors who had been denied shore leave from a Pakistani ship berthed in Brooklyn were granted temporary asylum here yesterday prior to their return to Bangladesh.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (AP) -- Thousands of striking Southern Pacific Company railroad employes started reporting back to work tonight when a Federal judge ordered their strike to end less than eight hours after it had begun.

The surplus toll revenues of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority that help to make the 35-cent transit fare possible may have to be cut off, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday. The Triborough Authority is an arm of the M.T.A.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association opens its 34th annual basketball championship tournament today while expressing concern that some players involved may have signed professional contracts. Villanova and Western Kentucky were forced to forfeit their second and third-place finishes of 1971 when it was learned that Howard Porter and Jim McDaniels were under contract before playing last year's N.C.A.A. tourney.

A slender, boyish-looking policeman who spent three months mingling with high-school students while posing as a confidence man arrested a stockroom employe of a Queens high school yesterday on charges of selling heroin in the school.
Stocks on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter trading cased yesterday in slower trading.

MIAMI, March 10 -- They are waitresses and gas station attendants, machinists and sales clerks and housewives. Some of them go to school part time. Many of them are unemployed. They probably know more about Elizabeth Taylor than Henry Kissinger, and might identify Che Guevara as an outfielder for the Chicago Cubs.

HARTFORD, March 10 -- Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's Strike Force for Full Employment announced a series of wide-ranging proposals today for commercial and industrial expansion and increased employment in Connecticut.
There will be 11 Democrats and three Republicans on the Presidential primary ballot in Nebraska on May 9, and five Democrats and two Republicans on the North Carolina ballot five days earlier.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 10 (UPI) -- Iowa State, getting strong performances from Phil Parker and Ben Peterson, brushed aside a mild challenge by Michigan State tonight and virtually clinched the national collegiate wrestling championship.

Eight years ago the election to Congress of two outstanding Reform Democrats -- Jonathan B. Bingham and James H. Scheuer -- delivered a death blow to the sleazy political machine headed by former Bronx boss Charles Buckley. Ever since, these two legislators have been refreshing exceptions in a New York delegation on Capitol Hill that abounds in mediocrity.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 10 -- Brown University announced today its decision to establish a full medical school program, leaving Princeton as the only Ivy League university without one.
MADRID, March 10 -- Two shipyard workers were killed and three injured today when police fired on strikers in the northwestern port of El Ferrol.

CALGARY, Alberta, March 10 -- Ondrej Nepela, a two-time world figure skating champion, has been thinking about being a spectator at next year's title competition in his home town of Bratislava, Czechoslovakia. His national skating association, however, has other thoughts that have him as a competitor.

NEW HAVEN, March 10 -- Curtis Hayden and Charlie Campbell of Princeton each set records tonight as the Tigers maintained their lead over Yale after the second day of the 32d annual Eastern Seaboard swimming championships.
PARIS, March 10 -- The dollar recovered today in the major European centers after a week of some of the heaviest pounding since its devaluation last December.

NEWARK, March 10 -- France's chief examining magistrate is reported to have denied that French intelligence agencies were involved in international narcotics smuggling, during a judicial inquiry that was held this week in tight secrecy and completed here today.

Starting at the top of the ramp and spiraling downward -- standard procedure at the Guggenheim Museum for an exhibition with a story line -- you may now follow the development of a great sculptor's drawings from earliest examples that have closer alliances to the 18th century than the 19th, to late examples that revolutionized the 20th's idea of what drawing is all about.
ELGIN, Ariz. -- For more than a century, the mile-high meadows south of this hamlet reverberated to the thunder of hooves, the whoops of cowboys and the clangor of westbound immigrant parties.

MIAMI, March 10 -- Upper Caso and Spanish Riddle, colts trained by Lucien Laurin that collected $143,680 by running first and second in the Florida Derby last week, will endeavor to pick up another $112,710 in the same way tomorrow in the Flamingo States of Hialeah Park.

When City Council President Garelik refused to approve a group of drug program proposals before the Board of Estimate this week, demanding instead reasonable assurances that tax funds previously spent for this purpose had achieved some demonstrable results, he was doing something that members of the Board could well do more often: demand accountability, insist on performance.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- Somehow the word had spread that a crazy American was on a safari to the Netherlands in search of a vanishing species of homo sapiens known in the United States as a Dutch Uncle.
WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Even before the ink dried in Albany this week on the maps of the state's new Congressional districts, a number of House members were already off and running.
A law went into effect here yesterday requiring that dairy products, eggs and baked goods be stamped with either the last day the item should be eaten or the last day it should be sold.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, March 10 (Reuters) -- Uruguay today repealed most of the extensive curbs on civil liberties she had imposed to fight Tupamaro urban guerrillas, ending nearly three years of what one Congressman called "paraconstitutional rule."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 10 -- Taiwan's Ambassador to Washington, James Shen, said here today that while relations between his Government and Washington were at an "all-time low," American officials had assured him that President Nixon had made no secret deals during his talks with Chinese Communist leaders in Peking.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 10 -- The University of Pennsylvania, surprising even its coach, Lajos Csizar, surged into the lead tonight after two weapons at the 75th Intercollegiate Fencing Association championships.

The signs on the wire fences surrounding the Aqueduct Race Track read, "No racing today," a situation to which the regular fan has now become accustomed. Since last Monday the action at the Big A has been halted by a strike called by the Independent Association of Mutuel Clerks.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 10 (AP) -- The United States military command today abandoned a new policy of barring television cameras from daily briefings on the war.
TOKYO, March 10 -- The first Chinese trade mission in six years arrived in Japan tonight to discuss the purchase of a synthetic-fiber plant and related technology.

DUBLIN, March 10 -- The wing of the illegal Irish Republican Army that has spearheaded the violence in Ulster today announced a three-day suspension of "military operations" in Northern Ireland beginning at midnight tonight.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- The Food and Drug Administration banned today all except trace amounts of lead in paint for interior use by the end of 1973 "to minimize the health hazard to future generations."

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, accused former Attorney General John N. Mitchell today of lying when he denied having knowledge of a financial commitment by a subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation to next summer's Republican National Convention.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, March 10 -- Lon Nol, Cambodia's ailing Premier, took supreme power as head of state tonight and nullified the nearly completed republican constitution.
With a nervous eye on the European monetary scene, the stock market moved decisively lower yesterday in active trading.

Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner led a diverse group of politicians, businessmen and labor leaders yesterday in a move to head off attempts to place a decentralization referendum on the ballot in November.

TRENTON, March 10 -- Two state troopers who were accused by a long-haired college youth of abducting him and locking him in the trunk of their police car for half an hour have resigned from the force.

BAKERSFIELD, March 8 -- California health officials have diagnosed at least 18 cases of snail fever, a major parasitic disease endemic to the Middle East, among the small but growing number of Arabs who are picking and cutting fruits and vegetables in the San Joaquin Valley.
The General Electric Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,800 jobs in the Syracuse area by the end of this year.

WASHINGTON, March 10 -- A catamaran named the Mop-Cat cleans up oil spills from waterways. A drum that revolves between the twin hulls absorbs the oil in its plastic-foam surface, from which it is squeezed out and collected. Patent 3,646,901, assigned to the Worthington Corporation, Mountainside, N. J., was granted for the catamaran this week to four Worthington employes and two staff men from the Marine Applications Company, Inc., Mineola, L. I.

MENLO Park, Calif., March 10 -- Representative Paul N. McCloskey Jr. became a casualty of the New Hampshire primary election when he announced today that he would abandon his campaign for the Republican nomination for President.

ST. LOUIS, March 10 -- Members of the Montreal Canadiens helped rescue their coach, Scotty Bowman, and several other persons today as fire forced 100 guests to flee from the suburban Hilton Inn early today.
The headline read: "Senate Approves Curb on Sex Bias by Universities." The subtitle read, "Measure Exempts Private Undergraduate Schools."
PRINCETON, N. J. -- On the theory that Wall Street can be bull or bear but never sacred cow, a group of Princeton University economics professors has investigated the beast -- and come out ahead.

Labor leaders and delegates from local unions in the New York and New Jersey area, meeting here in an all-day political session, gave Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine a slight edge over Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota in a Presidential preference poll yesterday.

Oh, the deviltry of that Pentagon, moaned Judge James J. Comerford yesterday when he learned that the military had declined an invitation it was never offered to march in this year's St. Patrick's Day parade.

DETROIT, March 10 -- Jacques Accambray set a national collegiate record in the 35-pound weight throw to highlight the opening day of competition at the National Collegiate Athletic Association indoor track and field championships today.

The American airline industry will not soon forget the distressing events of the past week, which now seem likely to leave a permanent impress as a result of President Nixon's orders for increased security. In retrospect it seems remarkable that it has taken so long to convince Government and industry alike that more stringent safety measures were necessary to protect planes and passengers.

As inconspicuously as possible for anyone 6 feet 8 inches and 255 pounds, Wayne Embry has eased into history as the first black general manager in major league sports. He has been entrusted with the "operation of the ball club," as he describes it, meaning the Milwaukee Bucks, the National Basketball Association champions. Incredibly, sports has survived the arrival of an Afro-topped brain in the front office.
HAUPPAUGE, L. I., March 10 -- A local law requiring the licensing of all manufactures of handguns and a serial number on each gun was introduced today in the Suffolk County Legislature.

Hope for substantial progress toward East-West detente in Europe during 1972 takes for granted two vital preliminaries: West German ratification of the non-aggression treaties with the Soviet Union and Poland, and Parliament's approval of legislation qualifying Britain for membership in the European Common Market.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 10 -- Communist China has plunged openly into the Latin-American commodities market by buying 100,000 metric tons of Brazilian sugar for immediate delivery at prices higher than world prices.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) -- Vice President Agnew announced last night that he would visit several college campuses in the coming months to present American students with the Nixon Administration's point of view and to find out what is on the young people's minds.

Recently, public attention has been focused on school busing because of its use in achieving racial balance. With the outcry against using busing for this purpose several important aspects of the problem have been missed.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) -- A Roman Catholic spokesman said today the Post Office was intruding into citizens' private lives by issuing a stamp on family planning.

The Pardo Palace provided a stagey setting. But politically the wedding last week of Maria del Carmen Martinez - Bordiu Franco to Alfonso de Borbon y Dampierre, a grandson of the late King Alfonso XIII of Spain, was no operetta.

WASHINGTON -- In his State of the Union Message on Jan. 24, President Nixon identified as an important national issue the turmoil over financing of the public schools.
