In spite of pubic and professional opinion that the controversial extension of the Capitol's West Front is a gross error of art and judgment, these gentlemen seem determined to proceed with this gigantic bungle and boondoggle.
Three managing directors of Lord Taylor stores have been appointed effective Aug. 1.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 12 -- The "golden triangle" in Southeast Asia has become the target of an intensive campaign to suppress the illicit opium trade.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has filed suit against W. J. Sloane's in an attempt to force the furniture store to change its method of computing finance charges on installment credit accounts.

PARIS -- The herd of brightly painted plaster cows that stand Swiss watch on the Champs-Elyseas, near the Presidential residence, provide the answer to the question: why, in the last two years, has Paris again become,

The state government switched one of its "major" bank accounts from Morgan Guaranty Trust Company to Bankers Trust Company less than two months after the treasurer of the Republican State Committee changed jobs from Morgan Guaranty to Bankers Trust, state and party officials said yesterday.

Thirteen countries have lower infant mortality rates than does the United States, and 10 countries outrank this one in maternal mortality. Approximately 15 per cent of the nation's births are "unwanted" and most of the hundreds of thousands of women who have abortions each year used either no contraceptives or an ineffective one.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) -- Dr. John R. Spencer, professor of art at Oberlin College and director of its Allen Memorial Art Museum, has been named director of the museum program of the National Endowment for the Arts.

MIAMI, March 12 -- Limiting the American League's most prestigious batting order to one hit in four shutout innings, Fred Beene extended his opportunity to become a major-league pitcher after seven seasons in the minors today as the New York Yankee defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 4-1.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday he would immediately suspend any policeman who refused to work. His warning was issued as Edward J. Kiernan, the head of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, threatened a job action before the end of the month.

Ten years after Broadway, the score of Richard Rodgers' "No Strings" is still the show. Thanks to an admirable and engagingly economic revival at the Equity Library's Master Theater uptown, the music surmounts the tamest of books like a halo.

LONDON, March 13 -- Forty leaders of Jewish communities in many countries expressed "satisfaction" in a statement today with the Soviet Union's "more realistic policy toward the demands of Soviet Jews to return to their historic homelands."

More than 300 parents and students demonstrated outside Board of Education headquarters yesterday in support of a zoning proposal that, they said, would assure an integrated enrollment and the continuation of quality education at Samuel J. Tilden High School in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn.
A Manhattan psychiatrist, until last Friday an Army major serving in a psychiatric clinic at Fort Monmouth, N. J., said yesterday that he regarded his discharge as both historic and spiteful.

BUFFALO, March 13 -- Three of upstate New York's major cities, under pressure to desegregate their neighborhood schools, are involved in disputes of the sort that have made busing the subject of a national controversy.

Jane Carlson, a member of the Juilliard faculty who has successfully combined teaching and performing careers, gave a generous piano recital at Alice Tully Hall Sunday evening. The program began with Bach's French Suite in G, proceeded chronologically through Mozart's Rondo in D (K.485), the Chopin B minor Sonata and Hindemith's Second Sonata, then backtracked for a pair of Rachmaninoff Preludes and Ravel's Rigaudon and Toccata.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested two men yesterday -- one here, the other in Salt Lake City -- and accused them of using bomb threats to extort money from airlines.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- The Senate gave final Congressional approval today to a bill extending the International Coffee Agreement until Sept. 30, 1973.

A heroin addict being held without bail on a murder charge hanged himself yesterday in the Manhattan Men's House of Detention shortly before he was to receive his final, detoxifying dose of methadone. He was the first prisoner to commit suicide in a city penal institution this year.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, March 13 (AP) -- Enemy troops reportedly increased their attacks across South Vietnam today, staging most of them in the Central Highlands provinces of Kontum and Pleiku.
WINCHESTER, England, March 13 (UPI) -- A Royal Navy officer was sentenced today to 21 years in prison for selling defense secrets to the Soviet Union at his wife's urging to pay household debts.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today a 15-week ban on transferring most personnel to new duty stations because it has run out of money to pay the moving costs.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (Reuters) -- United States intelligence officials tended tonight to minimize the possible impact on American defense planning of the Bingham case.
DENVER, March 13 -- A theologian who is a former inner-city priest warned today of what he viewed as a trend among American Roman Catholics to pull back from a commitment to social action.

UNION CITY, N.J. -- Heralded by the barking of her dogs, Duke and Duchess, Sister Mary of the Compassion came into the guest parlor of the Blue Chapel, as the Cloister of the Perpetual Rosary is known here. "

Simplicity is often valuable in a musical work if the composer knows exactly what he's doing. Frederic Rzewski's "The Last Judgment," given its local premiere by the New York Brass Society in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night, is a case in point.

Dr. M. Royal Schoenfeld is one sawbones who does most of his cutting in his basement. No, there are no bodies involved. Dr. Schoenfeld moonlights as a jewelry designer there. "I'm a doctor first, last and always, the 43-year-old Yonkers cardiologist insisted yesterday, before making a personal appearance with his complete line of baubles at the Marcus Jewelry counter in Gimbels East.

HONG KONG, March 13 -- Travel from Taiwan to Hong Kong will become a little more difficult as a result of the agreement announced today by China and Britain raising their relations to the ambassadorial level and closing British Consular offices in Taipei.

A memorial service for Basil O'Connor, whose fund-raising ingenuity as president of the National Foundation was a major impetus in the fight against polio, was held at Rockefeller University yesterday.

Carnegie Hall was the scene of a rather special event Sunday night, perhaps totally comprehensible only to the dedicated opera fan. Licia Albanese and Giuseppe Di Stefano, both distinguished singers backed by long years of operatic experience, appeared before a frankly adoring and easily excitable audience in a program of arias and duets.

Postmaster General Elmer T. Klassen said yesterday that neither the United" States Postal Service nor other ,mail users should provide subsidies to magazines and hewspapers to ease the impict of sharp increases in postal rates. "

About two years ago, when the quotation marks were still bracketing women's liberation, about 100 allegedly militant feminists staged a well-publicized invasion of the editorial offices of The Ladies Home Journal -- "trying to change attitudes," according to a spokeswoman for the invaders.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission and Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, each took another step today on what appears to be their collision course on the issue of institutional membership on stock exchanges.
PORTLAND, Ore., March 13 -- Former Representative Robert Duncan, Democrat, announced today that he would seek the Senate seat held by Mark O. Hatfield, Republican.

ZURICH, Switzerland, March 13 -- Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has reassured European central bankers on two of the points that worried them most in the recent dollar scare, European informants said today after the weekend meeting of central bankers in Basel.
Shepard Traube and Edwin S. Lowe will bring Ronald Alexander's new comedy, "Keep Off the Grass," to the Longacre Theater during the week of April 24 under an innovative plan.

Three years ago, in a candid magazine interview, Mrs. Hiroko Sato, wife of Japan's Premier, Eisaku Sato, told the world that in the early days of her marriage, her husband used to beat her. Now, in another interview, she has told a Tokyo magazine how sorry she was for having exposed Mr. Sato to criticism.

Your Feb. 18 editorial "Back on the Line" suggests that the Unemployment Insurance Fund is subsidizing strikers. We consumers are, in fact, subsidizing the strikebreakers. Management personnel from Bell System companies in other states were brought to New York to maintain telephone services.

CONCORD, N. H., March 13 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine picked up 15 pledged delegates to the Democratic National Convention in last Tuesday's New Hampshire Presidential primary, according to final figures made public today.
LONDON, March 13 (AP) -- South Africa's fate in the Davis Cup may be decided April 14 in Copenhagen, Denmark.

Stock prices staged their sharpest drop in four months yesterday amid jitters over the dollar's position in world monetary markets and indications that the Federal Reserve no longer was trying to push down short-term interest rates.

With the work of many artists it is apparent that the traditional boundaries between dance and theater are becoming deliberately obscured. Even such a work as Jerome Robbin's "Watermill," although staged by the New York City Ballet, is probably more profitably regarded as a work of the theater than as a ballet.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13 -- With an unearned run and a proclamation by their manager, the Atlanta Braves shut out both the Yankees and the Mets today.

RAHWAY, N. J., March 13 -- U. Samuel Vukcevich, superintendent of Rahway State Prison, escaped injury last night when a shotgun blast shattered a rear window in his home across the road from the prison.

Grand jury testimony by Seymour R. Thaler was introduced as evidence yesterday as the prosecution sought to show that the former State Senator had committed perjury about his handling of United States Treasury bills that had been stolen.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13 -- One unidentified member of the New York Yankees abstained today, but 28 others approved authorization of a major-league players' strike on March 31 for increased pension benefits.
MEXICO CITY, March 12 -- The bald eagle, brown pelican and other animals are still in danger of extinction, but at least five species that had been considered doomed appear to be making a comeback.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- In an apparent switch, a Pentagon spokesman said today that Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird "does not plan specific partisan political appearances" this campaign year.
Several important changes of responsibility in The New York Times advertising department, effective April 3, were announced yesterday by Max Falk, the advertising director.

Mrs. Aristotle Onassis insisted under cross-examination yesterday in Federal Court here that she had never said anything to a Secret Service agent who accompanied her and her son, John, on a bicycle ride through Central Park Sept. 24, 1969.
The time has come. Gulf and Western has decided -- after 14 years building up a conglomerate -- to tell the public just who and what it is.
Two teen-age baby sitters; trapped yesterday in a burning sixth-floor apartment, tossed four children across an eight-foot air shaft to waiting neighbors and then jumped themselves.
BUCHAREST, March 12 -- Diplomatic sources here believe that a Rumanian general rumored to have been executed for passing secrets to the Soviet Union is still alive and awaiting trial.

The Central and South West Corporation reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for 1971. The company's annual report, released yesterday, placed operating revenues at $386,322,272 against $358,402,082 a year earlier.

With today's Democratic primary in Florida largely drained of significance by an excess of candidates running on similar platforms, the entrance of Terry Sanford into the North Carolina contest raises the risk of a similar devaluation of the primary in that state.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- President Nixon resolved today one of the lesser controversies of his tenure by announcing that the giant pandas from China would reside here at the National Zoo and not in San Diego, St. Louis, Chicago or New York.

Florida Democrats and Republicans vote today for the candidates they prefer as their parties' nominees. The Democratic ballot lists in alphabetical order the following candidates: Shirley Chisholm, Vance Hartke, Hubert H. Humphrey, Henry M. (Scoop) Jackson, John V. Lindsay, Eugene J. McCarthy, George McGovern, Wilbur D. Mills, Edmund S. Muskie, George Wallace and Sam Yorty. The Republican ballot lists, in alphabetical order: John M. Ashbrook, Paul N. McCloskey Jr. and Richard M. Nixon.

In the annals of man's inhumanity to man, there are few names that evoke more horror than that of Auschwitz, the Nazi "death factory" in Poland. The systematic savagery practiced there against men, women and little children during the years of Hitlerian terror is shocking almost beyond belief.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (UPI) -- The Government's air surgeon complained today that some doctors permit airline pilots to continue flying by not reporting such serious ailments as alcoholism, heart disease or mental trouble.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The State Department said today that the United States and China had agreed to conduct their new diplomatic contacts in Paris under conditions of virtual secrecy to help insure their ultimate success.

MONTREAL, March 13 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich scored his 36th goal of the season with 1:04 to play tonight as the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-1, and moved within 4 points of the second-place New York Rangers in the National Hockey League's East Division.

PARIS, March 13 -- As a high military officer, a member of the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party and the head of the most important mission that China maintains in the West, Ambassador Huang Chen is a major figure in the Chinese hierachy.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation announced today that its president, Harold S. Geneen, had held discussions with more than a score of high Government officials including former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, about what it termed the "serious consequences" of the Justice Department's antitrust policies.
MILAN, Italy, March 13 -- The acting leader of the Italian Communist party opened its national congress here with a cautious appeal to Moscow and Peking to re-establish "normal" relations.

BALTIMORE, March 13 -- Duck Dance matched the track record of 1:09 1-5 for six furlongs today in winning the $27,850 Old Line Handicap as Pimlico Race Course opened a 63-day meeting before a crowd of 12,479.

FULDA, West Germany, March 3 -- For the 2,000 men of the United States Army's 14th Armored Cavalry Regiment, whose principal mission is to guard a section of the Soviet bloc border near here, the major enemy appears to be boredom.

An unexpectedly large number of choice Cambodian sculptures has appeared on the Western market in recent weeks. The fear of experts in this country and abroad is that these art objects have been stolen from the historic Angkor Park region with its incomparable 1,000-year-old treasure of sculptures, temples and other buildings.
Revlon, Inc., realized a 6.5 per cent increase in profits last year on a sales gain of 5.5 per cent, the cosmetic and ethical drug producer reported yesterday. Both profits and sales set records.

A make-or-break test for the Pay Board's anti-inflation standards will come today with formal hearings in Washington on the West Coast longshore strike settlement, an accord that provides increases in wages and fringe benefits nearly quintuple the board's basic 5.5 per cent guidepost.

Even when his English was limited, Igor Ter-Ovanesyan's warmth and charm overshadowed the politics of the cold war that surrounded early track and field meets between the United States and Soviet Union.

TOKYO, March 13 -- Japanese company songs are a source of wonder for foreign visitors. They can never quite believe the spectacle of hundreds of workers at, say, the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company, whose sales exceed $2-billion, bursting into song.
The New York Stock Exchange indicated yesterday that securities commission business remained unprofitable for retail brokerage firms in the fourth quarter of 1971.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Assistant Attorney General Ralph E. Erickson told a House Armed Services subcommittee today that "administrative and criminal sanctions may attach to the unauthorized release" of secret national security documents under a new Presidential order.

NEW DELHI, March 13 -- The Left Communists, long dominant in the volatile state of West Bengal, appeared today to have been routed by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's New Congress party in last week's elections for the state assemblies.
Village taxpapers are subsidizing the city dweller under the state's revenue-sharing plan, the Mayor and trustees of the Village of Lynbrook, L. I., charge.

Representative Jonathan B. Bingham announced yesterday that he would fight Representative James H. Scheuer in the June 20 primary instead of letting a convention of Bronx Reform Democrats decide between them to avert a head-on clash.

MIAMI -- Representation Shirley Chisholm, who has been unable to mount an impressive campaign in Florida, is nevertheless expected to cut into the thin ranks of liberal voters, especially among blacks, in tomorrow's primary election here.

MAEBASHI, Japan, March 13 (Reuters) -- Three more bodies of persons executed in a purge carried out by an ultralefist guerrilla group were unearthed today from mountain graves, bringing to 12 the number found in the last week.
NEWARK, March 13 (AP) -- The Coast Guard is now allowed to respect Polish fishing vessels in the North Atlantic, according to an agreement signed by both countries, it was announced today.

At a time when the proposed budget for New York City is almost $1 billion out of balance, and an expected rise in welfare costs accounts for much of this gap, reasonable suggestions to bring the soaring welfare rolls under some control deserve careful attention of city officials.

Several steel company executives joined the cautious optimism of Edwin H. Gott, the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, on the outlook for sales and earnings this year. Their views were expressed in annual reports released yesterday.

An Agriculture Department report indicating that acreage planted to soybeans and grains in 1972 may be higher than was planted in 1971 tended to lower prices in those futures traded yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

RIO DE JANEIRO, March 13 -- While United States industry struggles to keep European and Japanese competitors at bay, a new competitive force is massing south of the lucrative North American market -- Brazil.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., March 13 -- Conservative and Reform leaders of Judaism in this country agreed today on an immediate cooperative effort to cope with such nettling problems confronting American Jews as mixed marriages, education, the future of the synagogue and identity.
A symposium on ethnic communities organized by the Congress of Italian-American Organizations will be broadcast on WRVR tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- In consulting the following directory of this week's events, it should be noted that while admissions are free unless otherwise indicated, special credentials may be required in some cases.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market dropped sharply yesterday in slower trading.
The Harlem Urban Development Corporation said yesterday that it should be allowed to start building in Harlem two schools that have been cut out of the Mayor's proposed capital budget.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 13 -- Tom Seaver's sore right shoulder, which was reported improved yesterday, turned stiff again today and the ace of the New York Mets' staff was immediately scratched from tomorrow's exhibition game against the Cincinnati Reds.
Short-term interest rates continued their recent upward surge yesterday as the conviction spread that the Federal Reserve had ended its policy of aggressive credit expansion.

The New York Police Department is considering adopting a policy under which a patrolman suspected of corruption would be required to take a lie-detector test. The idea is sharply opposed by the Patrolmens Benevolent Association and other employs groups.
The Standard Poor's Corporation, one of two major investment services that evaluate the quality of bonds, has downgraded its rating of New York State bonds one level to "AA" from "AAA."
KANSAS CITY, March 13 (AP) -- Marquette's basketball team was reinstated tonight in the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

The Xerox Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Diablo Systems, Inc., a Hayward, Calif., manufacturer of computer disk drives and a recently developed communications printer.

Last month while making a nighttime shakedown cruise aboard his party boat, Jamaica, Capt. Howard Bogan of Brielle, N.J., saw a cluster of lights 10 miles away that, he said, resembled the Manhattan skyline.

Neither Maryland's 23-5 won-lost record nor Tom McMillen, its 6-foot 11-inch super sophomore, have impressed rival coaches sufficiently to establish the Terrapins as clear-cut favorites in the National Invitation Tournament that begins Friday night at Madison Square Garden.

MIAMI, March 13 -- Computerized campaigning has emerged as a major political technique in the Florida primary and promises to become equally important in Presidential politics for the remainder of this election year.

VIENTIANE, Laos, March 13 -- Enemy troops have captured Sam Thong, a key Laotian base near the Plaine des Jarres, and are threatening to engulf the nearby American-backed base at Long Tieng, military sources here reported today.

TOKYO, March 13 (AP) -- Peking accused Nationalist China today of illegally selling stock in the Bank of China and the Bank of Communications, and declared that it reserved the right to recover assets of the two banks.

For the remaining two weeks of the regular season, the New York Knicks have one primary objective: to get healthy and avoid new injuries so that they can go into the playoffs at full strength physically.
LONDON, March 13 -- Britons sharply increased their overseas buying last month, putting the nation's trade balance into deficit by $83.2-million, the Department of Trade and Industry said today.
WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today that it was beginning an investigation into airlines' becoming parts of holding companies.
To some people, he's an underpaid expert handling a tedious, pressure-packed job that requires speed, concentration and utmost accuracy.
Two Boston personalities, as familiar to many New Englanders as the Cabots and Lodges, were honored last night for contributions to amateur hockey at the annual Lester Patrick awards dinner here.

FAYSTON, Vt., March 13 -- In one of the most drawn out competitions in the history of the event, pigtailed Lyndall Heyer of nearby Stowe, won the national junior girls special slalom crown at the Glen Ellen area today.

I don't know whether it's anticipation of the spring or the result of overlong confinement indoors, but this is the time of year when the reviewer's mind begins to pace its cage and gnaw at its bars; and the only antidote, short of doing the real thing, is to read a book about trout fishing. Almost any book about trout fishing.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- With the national debt almost at the ceiling figure of $430-billion, quick Congressional action to raise the limit was blocked by a tax reform advocate today.

HONG KONG, March 13 -- Thousands of representatives of women's organizations attended a rally held in Canton, capital of Kwangtung Province in south China, to celebrate Women's Day last Wednesday, according to a broadcast from the city monitored here.
The New York Times's coverage of the Florida Democratic Presidential primary today will be augmented by the results of the first of a series of special surveys of voter attitudes.
MIAMI, Fla., March 13 (UPI) -- Heavily favored Eastern Fleet finished a distant sixth today as Raja Baba led all the way to win the feature race at Hialeah Park.

Sunday night's concert by the English singer, Shirley Bassey, at Philharmonic Hall was a study in the practice of musical melodrama. Miss Bassey is perhaps best-known in this country for her performance of the theme music for the James Bond film "Goldfinger" (or, as Miss Bassey sings it, "Goldddfingahh").

Bobby Knight is returning to New York for his fifth coaching effort in a National Invitation Tournament. It used to be that the former Ohio State player would bring his defense-minded Army team down the Hudson River to Madison Square Garden each year and the cadets would do much better than expected in the N.I.T.

C. L. Sulzberger in a recent column perceptively assesses the Egyptian "habit of developing excellent myths rooted in truth" when he asserts, "Cairo firmly believes that no American President -- especially at election time -- can politically afford to deny Israel whatever it requests for fear of losing the Jewish vote."

MIAMI, March 13 -- Six Democratic aspirants for the Presidency ranged across Florida today in last efforts to win support in tomorrow's Presidential primary, in which every other issue has been lost in a long and loud debate on school busing.

BOSTON, March 13 -- New American Library would not touch the manuscript. Neither would Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. It was a clever idea, several big New York publishers all agreed, but there wasn't enough production time and no one would buy it anyway.

HINGHAM, Mass. -- Back in the premature New England springtime of April, 1970, counsel for the commonwealth and the defendant assembled a jury of notable crankiness to consider what the state of Massachusetts had against a companion of Vinnie Teresa's, indicted after getting a loan from a bank.

A group of investors headed by Justin S. Colin, senior partner of Colin, Hochstin Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, has taken control of the Chelsea National Bank and has replaced Daniel K. Sobol, who has been head of the small Now York City bank since its inception in 1964.
LOS ANGELES, March 12 -- The deanship of a medical school, once a plum job for a lifetime, has lost much of its luster.
Oil industry observers took the agreement in principle between major international oil companies and six Persian Gulf countries in stride yesterday.

The Board of Estimate and leaders of the City Council reached agreement with negotiators for Mayor Lindsay last night on shifting funds in the capital budget to add 35 school, 30 library and 43 park projects.
DALLAS, March 13 -- Texas Democrats will vote May 6 on an antibusing referendum, but the state's party leaders decided today not to have a Presidential prefernce primary.
LONDON, March 13 -- Britain and China formally agreed today to establish full diplomatic relations after the British had acknowledged that Taiwan was "a province" of China.

Clifford and Edith Irving, publicly admitting for the first time their culpability in the $750,000 Howard Hughes "autobiography" swindle, pleaded guilty yesterday in the Federal District Court on Foley Square to charges of conspiracy.

ALBANY, March 13 -- After nearly three hours of haggling, the Assembly approved this evening a bill designed to block the controversial Forest Hills public-housing project by requiring county referendums on all such projects.
TRENTON, March 13 -- A Cahill administration measure that would give the state broad power over local flood-control plans in New Jersey was approved today by the State Senate, 33 to 0.
Columbia University Law School, reported yesterday that the job market for graduating law students had changed dramatically within the last year, with more jobs going to women and fewer to blacks.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., March 13 -- Stan Alex, a teacher at the modernistic Beech Avenue School here, recently asked his sixth-grade pupils how they felt about attending a racially integrated school.
WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- The Defense Department told Congress today that additional incentives might be needed to achieve an all-volunteer armed force by July 1, 1973.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 13 -- Boyd F. Douglas Jr., a paid F.B.I. informer, insisted today that he began spying on the peace movement only after he learned that a group of priests and nuns of the Catholic Left was, according to his testimony, plotting to blow up heating tunnels in Washington.

DACCA, Bangladesh, March 13 (AP) -- Some foreign relief authorities estimated today that a clash between Bengali and non-Bengali Moslems in Khulna over the weekend had left at least 200 killed or wounded.

In the first two months of this year, New York City and the District of Columbia -- which have the two largest methadone-maintained populations in the country -- have had more overdose deaths from the drug than in the previous 12 months.

As a Western Union stockholder I was intrigued by your unhappy March 4 editorial on the terrible telegram service. You say Western Union can "afford to do better by the public." It is just "too profitably engaged in selling complex services to business to bother about the personal messages of individuals."
PARIS, March 13 -- The United States and Chinese Ambassadors to Paris began a series of contacts today as the first tangible follow-up to President Nixon's visit to China.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Despite repeated insistence that preventive detention is essential to controlling crime, the Administration has failed to prove either its necessity or effectiveness, according to an independent study of the highly controversial procedure.
PHOENIX, Ariz., March 13 (AP) -- Charlie Scott, the American Basketball Association's leading scorer, signed today to play for the Phoenix Suns of the National Basketball Association.

Midway through its second season, the "Lyrics and Lyricists" series at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. seems to be changing its focus. Originally the lyricists presented at these Sunday evening sessions came, for the most part, from the musical theater, and their tendency was to analyze the craft of lyric writing on the basis of their individual experiences.

Pete McCloskey of California has become the first official victim of the 1972 primaries. He is dropping his insurgent's campaign for the White House because the 20 per cent of the vote he received against President Nixon in New Hampshire was not enough to bring in the funds needed to make other primary races or to cover the $45,000 debt he had already incurred.

WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP) -- President Nixon provided a new Bible as a gift for the swearing in today of Marina von Neumann Whitman, the first woman ever to serve on the President's Council of Economic Advisers.

Jack Kent Cooke, who provided a guarantee of $5-million purse money for a Joe Frazier-Muhammad Ali heavyweight championship fight last March; disclosed last night that he holds "in perpetuity" the rights to a rematch between the fighters.

A large body of American citizens suffered significant financial losses when, after 1949, their property was confiscated or nationalized by the People's Republic of China without compensation. Claims resulting from this action were processed by the U.S. Foreign Claims Settlement Commission under the International Claims Settlement Act of 1949, and valid awards were certified to the State Department.

TOKYO, March 13 -- The United States dollar firmed up slightly in foreign-exchange trading here today as a result of buying operations undertaken by the Bank of Japan to keep the currency from falling.
The city's first new subway tunnel in almost four decades moved a step closer to completion yesterday.

The robbery trial of twin brothers who have resisted efforts to bring them to court got under way yesterday, again after they had been tear-gassed in their cells and carried to a pen adjoining the courtroom where they could hear the proceedings broadcast.

LONDON, March 13 -- The Orion Banking Group, a new kind of international consortium organized to serve the capital needs of the world's leading multinational companies, reported today a profit of $2.18-million on its first year of operations and projected strong growth in 1972.

Bruno Sammartino returned to Madison Square Garden last night, defeating Smasher Sloan in a heavyweight wrestling exhibition. Sloan said he could not continue when, after 5 minutes 29 seconds, Sammartino slung him over his shoulder in a back-breaker.
FLORENCE, Italy, March 13 (UPI) -- One of Switzerland's best-known businessmen was indicted today on charges of having smuggled art treasures valued at $1-million out of Italy.

John P. Freeman Jr. has been elected president and John F. Ford vice chairman of the board of Aubrey G. Lanston Co., Inc. C. Richard Youngdahl, who was named chairman of the board, remains as chief executive officer.

Several recent columns (e.g. "Ecology and Politics" [Anthony Lewis] on March 4, "The Machine, the Fool and Doom" [Russell Baker] on March 5, and others) refer to the thesis that environmental protection is inconsistent with economic growth.

Lilly Endowment, Inc., Indianapolis, yesterday announced that its directors had requested Eli Lilly Co., to register a proposed secondary offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission of shares of Lilly's stock owned by the Endowment.

The Police Department introduced at a news conference yesterday six patrolmen who have come forward to replace the two "resident policemen" driven out of their home precincts by abusive telephone calls and other harassment after their selection had been announced publicly.

The Taxi Drivers Union and the Independent Taxi Owners Council jointly announced yesterday a working alliance to fight a proposed City Council bill that would regulate and license nonmedallion or gypsy cabs.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted tentatively today to give the states some say in how the money provided by a Federal revenue-sharing program would be distributed among the local governments within a state.

WASHINGTON, March 13 -- Seven prominent civil rights leaders asked President Nixon today to assume "strong moral" leadership in behalf of school desegregation and to grant them an audience before announcing any policy decision.
LISBON, March 13 -- African nationalist guerrillas destroyed a hamlet in northeastern Portuguese Guinea last weekend, leaving 14 dead and 12 seriously injured, it was announced here tonight.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 13 -- A British Army lawyer apologized today for official statements that four of the 13 persons killed by British troops in Londonderry on Jan. 30 were on the "wanted" list of suspected members of the Irish Republican Army.

NEWARK, March 13 -- Douglas J. Schotte, former president of the Eatontown National Bank, pleaded guilty today to three counts of a Federal indictment charging him with conspiracy and misapplying the bank's funds.

TAMPA, Fla., March 13 -- "When I heard how Johnny Unitas ripped his Achilles tendon," said Bobby Tolan, the once-wounded warrior of the Cincinnati Reds, "it sounded exactly the same as what happened to me. Unitas was playing handball with Tom Matte when he asked if Matte had accidentally kicked him in the heel. When Tom said he hadn't, Johnny said, 'Then I've ripped my Achilles tendon.'
